story:
Enjoy. is a one-man show about four disparate characters and how they try to navigate the pitfalls of everyday life.  It looks at universal experiences that we all share with a comical eye, reminding us of the joyful absurdity of our own lives.  This represents my first independent production, an original play inspired by the silent comedy of Buster Keaton, Pierre Etaix, and Jacques Tati as part of Philadelphia's SoLow Festival this June.  I first studied Lecoq Clown Technique four years ago and immediately fell in love with the way it allows a performer to connect with an audience on an intimate level and share in a unique experience.  I have always wanted to take the work further and this production is my first step in doing that, taking those skills into a larger world and a larger audience.  Enjoy. is also my first attempt at collaborating with a musician, Sonni Shine, who will be performing original music live every night.  So far it has been a fascinating and deeply rewarding experience, and we can't wait to share it with all of you.  I believe Enjoy. will bring something uniquely special to the vibrant and diverse Philadelphia theatre scene, and give audiences a unique perspective on themselves, the way we all deal with our daily struggles, and the inner clown in all of us.

What We Need & What You Get

Theatre is always an expensive business.  Luckily, Enjoy. is a minimalist show with few costumes, one actor, and no fancy lighting, but we still need money to pay for performance and rehearsal space.  Enjoy. is a very physical show, and the sooner we can rehearse in an open, professional theater space, the sooner we can share it with all of you.  With money being so tight, every donation, however small, makes a big impact on us.  We think we've got some fun and exciting perks for those of you kind enough to donate, and we'll be updating this page as we continue to make progress on the show.  If you're excited about this project but don't have a cent to spare, you can still help!  Share this page or the Facebook event to get the word out, and tell your friends about this exciting new show!  Word-of-mouth can make a big different for a little play like this. 


ABOUT THE ARTISTS

Sonni Shine (Musician) is a member of The Underwater Sounds, a Philadelphia-based band that has been described as a "reggae-funk-jam fusion".  Their self-titled first album was voted the #1 debut album by WXPN.org's The Key in 2010, and the following year they were nominated for  Best Groove Band and Top Female Vocalist at the Asbury Music Awards.  You can follow Sonni on Twitter at @Sonni_TheSounds and the band's albums are available for order online.

Meredith LaBoon (Director) is the producing artistic director for Rainy Day Players, and directed their inaugural production, Asylum.

Kathy La (Stage Manager) is a student at Temple University, where she has appeared in Macbeth and the Philadelphia Young Playwrights Festival.  She has previously stage managed for Rainy Day Players for their production of Asylum at last year's Philadelphia Fringearts Festival. 

Hank Curry (Actor, Writer, Producer) studied Acting at Temple University, where he recieved a Bachelor's Degree in Theatre and Communications.  He appeared in a number of University productions, including Cabaret, Stops, The Philadelphia Young Playwrights Festival, and the world premieres of Dreaming of Diamonds: The Russel Conwell Project and Kaleidoscope. He was a founding member of the Temple University chapter of Alpha Psi Omega, and also produced, co-wrote, and performed in two comedy revues, including the Lecoq Clown showcase "Clowns Are Coming". Professionally he has worked with EgoPo Classic Theatre, Simpatico Theatre Project, New City Stage Company, InterAct Theatre Company, Rainy Day Players, Power Street Theatre Company, Passage Theatre Company, and Save the Day Productions. He has also taught theatre as part of the Philadelphia Arts in Education Partnership and is an interviewer for the REP Radio Podcast Network.  You can follow Hank on Twitter at @HankCurryActor.

story:
More about the legend:

On a summer night in Florida, with the stars of magic and irresponsibility perfectly aligned, four friends have gathered to summon a hurricane, to rekindle lost love and to see if wormholes exist. Whoosh.

Produced and created by recent graduates and current students of the Carnegie Mellon School of Drama, "Freaks" is a new play coming to the NYC Fringe Festival with your help.

The Freaks:

Freaks is being created by current students and recent graduates of the Carnegie Mellon School of Drama who come from all around the country.

Written by Sam French; Directed by Kyle Wilson; Produced by Josh Buckwald
Designed by Bryce Cutler (set); Scott Epstein (costume); Jackson Gallagher (lights)
Starring: Carl Lundstedt as Danny, Sawyer Pierce as Carl, Colleen Pulawski as Jenny, and Cara Ronzetti as Flower.

The Budget:

  • $2400 to pay our creative team small stipends.
  • $1000 to build the set, clothe the actors, light the world.
  • $1025 for administrative fees.
  • $1000 for advertising.
  • $500 for contingency costs.
  • Any money we make that exceeds our goal will go to increasing the stipends for the creative team and to advertising the show.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can't contribute financially, you can still help.

    • Share this page. Share our posters. Share our videos. Spread the word.
    • Come see the show in NYC in August!

story:
What is TimelessTease?

TimelessTease Productions is a new Baltimore-based theater-burlesque company, curating a diverse cast of the best and brightest in Baltimore-area burlesque.

TimelessTease Productions was co-founded by Dr. Betty O'Hellno and Dr. Jules V. Moorhead, respectively portrayed by Aaron Barlow and Josh Aterovis. Josh, an author and artist, fell in love with burlesque after moving to Baltimore six years ago and seeing a magical performance by the Baltimore legends turned internationally respected and award-winning husband and wife duo Trixie Little and the Evil Hate Monkey. Since then, he's been fortunate enough to become friends with many of the local performers over the years.

Aaron studied burlesque under Trixie and Monkey while in college at MICA, first developing the character that would become Betty O'Hellno (pictured above). Betty has often performed in DC and debuted in Baltimore in our co-produced show 'Hot Dish' earlier this year. 'Hot Dish,' a fundraiser for Moveable Feast, was a huge success, sparking their desire to continue producing shows.

We've found the burlesque community to be wonderfully welcoming, supportive and creative. We're very honored to be a part of such a powerful art form.
Betty and Moorhead serve as your hosts, taking you on exciting journeys through time and space in their very own time machine. Each show will feature performers from the Baltimore/DC area, as well as guests from all over the globe. Hang on to your pasties as you travel through time and space!

Why Baltimore?



Baltimore has a long and proud tradition in the burlesque world, most notably with the infamous Blaze Starr (pictured above), and TimelessTease is hoping to be a part of its continued evolution. Burlesque is all about celebrating the human body in all its shapes, sizes, colors and variations. It's about sensuality and sexuality, but neo-burlesque also embraces the silly, humorous side of the art form. It's a blending of traditional burlesque with vaudeville to create stories told through striptease and humor that sometimes (often?) contain surprising truths.

And quite simply, we love Baltimore! We're proud to call it, and all its quirky charms, home!

Why TimelessTease?

So, what's different about TimelessTease?

TimelessTease Productions is a blend of scripted theater with live music and traditional and neo-burlesque.

We fully embrace the queer side of the art form while remaining inclusive and all-encompassing. We will include drag, aerial performers and boylesque, along with traditional burlesque performers.
The first TimelessTease production, "Steampunk Seductions: Adventures in Victoriana," is on Saturday, January 24, 2015 at Mobtown Ballroom in Baltimore, Maryland. Inventors Jules V. Moorhead and Betty O'Hellno's longtime dream of building a working time machine has finally come to fruition, and they're heading to Victorian Chicago on their maiden journey. But will a Victorian mad scientist strand them in the past?


Who is TimelessTease?

Dr. Betty O'Hellno
Your hostess with the mostest, Betty wears many fabulous hats at TimelessTease. She's a co-founder and co-creative director of TimelessTease, as well as a stripper with multiple personalities, graphic artist, photographer and videographer. She's Baltimore's Butterface Beauty Queen. That one flat-chested girl — Betty O'Hellno.

Dr. Jules V. Moorhead
Dr. Moorhead is your other co-host, as well as a co-founder and co-creative director of TimelessTease. Additionally, Moorhead is the PR and marketing director, managing director and head script writer. Moorhead, at your service.

Cherry BoomBoom
Miss Cherry BoomBoom is TimelessTease's very own sexy, silken-voiced chanteuse and stage kitten extraordinaire. Cherry is also a valued creative team member and scenic artist.


Lizzy Falltrades
Ms. Lizzy Falltrades is literally TimelessTease's Liz-of-all-trades. Our stage manager does everything from set design and construction to creative input to providing the muscle necessary to bring our vision to life.

How can you help?

You can be a part of bringing our vision to life by becoming a sponsor! We need your support to complete our time machine! Not to mention all the other incidental expenses of launching a new burlesque company.

(Note: While we are deeply grateful for any support, if you donate using PayPal we can access the funds immediately, meaning we'll be able to put your gift to work right away!)

Here's a breakdown of our budget:

  • $1,000: Time Machine Construction
  • $450: Set Construction
  • $370: Marketing
  • $350: Lighting and Sound
  • $330: Wardrobe/Costuming

    Other ways you can help!

    If you can't become a sponsor right now, there are many other ways you can help. Like us on Facebook! Share our campaign with your friends using the convenient share tools provided by Indiegogo! Come to our shows! Tell all your friends about TimelessTease!

    Thank you for your support!

story:
"He's found out about all the bad things i done since I quit him and . . . come to St. Louie."

One of Tennessee Williams' lesser known gems, a story of a woman at the edge of her career, and how far she will go to survive. It is 1937 in the wake of the Great Depression, a brothel in East St. Louis belonging to the Madame Goldie. Bertha, once one of the best girls in the brothel is now being told her career is over. An intimate look at the personal situations women in the sex industry face, and the brutal truth and courage they have to get through their every day. 
We are a Senior Thesis project at SUNY Purchase looking to present a piece of theatre that encourages an audience to rethink their perceptions of sex work (prostitution, stripping, escourts, etc) and view the women involved in the industry in a much more empathetic and humanistic light. With the help of contributions we can better tell this story and fully respect the marginalized group of women we are portraying on the stage. 

What We Need

We're aiming to create the best show we can on a cost-efficient budget. Here's the breakdown for where your money will go:

  • $200 for sultry, authentic costumes and lingerie for cast and crew.
  • $200 for an amazing set
  • $125 for properties (including breakaway glass!)
  • $125 for printing and merchandise costs

Cast and Crew

Starring:
Sarah Guzman
Iliana Paris
Caitlin McCutcheon

Directed by Gabriel Vasquez
Stage Manager: Asya Abdul Majid
Set Designer: Lily Guerin
Costume Designer: Iliana Paris
Dramaturg: Sarah Guzman
Sound Designer: Kevin Downing

February 20/21/22

story:
Valitut Lapset - tuotanto?

  • Mikkelissä harjoitteleva suomalainen näytelmätuotanto, joka on versonut rakkaudesta näytelmätuotantoon ja nostalgisten show-elämysten tuottamisesta suomalaisille esiintymislavoille
  • Saanut alkunsa keväällä 2016 kolmen intohimoisen populaarikulttuurin harrastajan toimesta
  • Tuottaa Digimon Adventuren ensimmäiseen 13 jaksoon perustuvaa näytelmää
  • Ensi-ilta toukokuussa 2019, esityskausi koko Digimonin 20-vuotisjuhlavuosi.
  • Joukkorahoitus tarjoaa tuotannolle avaimet tuotannollisten kulujen hoitamiseen ja

Mihin tähtäämme?

  • Vahvaan ja onnistuneeseen näytelmätribuuttiin, joka on samaan aikaan kunnianosoitus Digimon Adventurelle ja suomalaiselle vapaaehtoistyölle kulttuurin saralla
  • Omannäköiseen, persoonalliseen lopputulokseen joka miellyttää sekä tekijöitä että näytelmän kokijoita
  • Ikimuistoiseen elämykseen, joka tarjoaa toivon mukaan nostalgisia muisteloita monille suomalaisille Digimon-faneille <3

Miksi rahoitus?

  • Vapaaehtoistyötä ei rahoiteta pelkällä kovalla työllä, motivaatiolla ja sitoutumisella - saavuttaaksemme parhaan mahdollisen lopputuloksen tarvitsemme henkisen pääoman lisäksi taloudellista tukea
  • Haemme rahoitusta mm. puvustus- ja lavastustiimin materiaaleihin sekä logistiikkakuluihin
  • Rahoitustuotteinamme tarjolla mm. t-paitoja ja kangasmerkkejä

Sharing is caring!

  • Muista jakaa tietoa rahoituskampanjastamme kaikille tutuillesi, ystävillesi, äideille, isille, naapurin otakuille, mutuaaleille ja muille! Vaikka et itse saisi tuettua kampanjaa, informaation jakaminen joukkorahoituskampanjamme olemassaolosta on enemmän kuin toivottua <3
story_txt:
Valitut Lapset - tuotanto?

Mikkelissä harjoitteleva suomalainen näytelmätuotanto, joka on versonut rakkaudesta näytelmätuotantoon ja nostalgisten show-elämysten tuottamisesta suomalaisille esiintymislavoille
Saanut alkunsa keväällä 2016 kolmen intohimoisen populaarikulttuurin harrastajan toimesta
Tuottaa Digimon Adventuren ensimmäiseen 13 jaksoon perustuvaa näytelmää
Ensi-ilta toukokuussa 2019, esityskausi koko Digimonin 20-vuotisjuhlavuosi.
Joukkorahoitus tarjoaa tuotannolle avaimet tuotannollisten kulujen hoitamiseen ja

Mihin tähtäämme?

Vahvaan ja onnistuneeseen näytelmätribuuttiin, joka on samaan aikaan kunnianosoitus Digimon Adventurelle ja suomalaiselle vapaaehtoistyölle kulttuurin saralla
Omannäköiseen, persoonalliseen lopputulokseen joka miellyttää sekä tekijöitä että näytelmän kokijoita
Ikimuistoiseen elämykseen, joka tarjoaa toivon mukaan nostalgisia muisteloita monille suomalaisille Digimon-faneille <3

Miksi rahoitus?

Vapaaehtoistyötä ei rahoiteta pelkällä kovalla työllä, motivaatiolla ja sitoutumisella - saavuttaaksemme parhaan mahdollisen lopputuloksen tarvitsemme henkisen pääoman lisäksi taloudellista tukea
Haemme rahoitusta mm. puvustus- ja lavastustiimin materiaaleihin sekä logistiikkakuluihin
Rahoitustuotteinamme tarjolla mm. t-paitoja ja kangasmerkkejä

Sharing is caring!
Muista jakaa tietoa rahoituskampanjastamme kaikille tutuillesi, ystävillesi, äideille, isille, naapurin otakuille, mutuaaleille ja muille! Vaikka et itse saisi tuettua kampanjaa, informaation jakaminen joukkorahoituskampanjamme olemassaolosta on enemmän kuin toivottua <3

story:
Mabou Mines has a long history of fostering the next generation of artists through mentorships and residencies. Our new performance program SUITE/Space provides development, rehearsal space, and public performances to artists that reflect NYC's rich cultural landscape and share Mabou Mines’ commitment to breaking new ground in form and content.

From March 27-April 1, 2018 SUITE/Space artists will perform their work in a festival-like setting at the new Mabou Mines Theater in the East Village — 2 performances each night for 6 nights in a row.

Your contribution to this campaign not only guarantees you a ticket, but invests directly in the artists' work as well as the future of the program. All income will be shared equally between the SUITE/Space artists and SUITE/Space Program expenses.

For the 2018 inaugural year of the program, SUITE/Space artists were nominated by community and performing arts organizations. The artists were selected by Mabou Mines' curatorial team — Mabou Mines Co-Artistic Director Karen Kandel, Mabou Mines Associate Artist David Neumann, and playwright and former Mabou Mines Resident Artist Carl Hancock Rux. For 2019 and beyond, the SUITE/Space artists will be selected through nominations and a public RFP process.

 

Davalois Fearon /Time to Talk

March 27 @ 7pm, March 28 & 29 @ 9pm

Time to Talk is a multimedia dance-theater piece rooted in research on American history, dance history, racial identity formation and systemic racism. It is inspired by Davalois' own experience of oppression and racial bias within academia that she encountered in 2015. Dynamic fluid dance, live music, spoken word, projection art, and dialogue to call attention to racial inequalities within American concert dance and society at large. Performed with critically acclaimed Jazz multi-reedist Mike McGinnis, projection art by interdisciplinary artist Andre Zachery, and lighting by Sarah Hamilton. “Time to Talk” aims to encourage audience members to question how they may knowingly or unknowingly contribute to maintaining social norms that support a status quo of inequity. 

Tariq Al-Sabir / Unwanted

March 27 @ 9pm, March 28 & 31 @ 7pm

A multimedia song cycle written for a unique ensemble (including voice, actor, woodwinds, brass, percussion, synthesizer and electronics) that communicates real-time with film, focusing on the present trauma and cynical frustrations that plague social media oriented Black Millennials. Video direction by Monique Muse Dodd.

 

Tamar-kali / Excerpts from Demon Fruit Blues

March 29 @ 7pm, March 30 @ 9pm, April 1 @ 5pm

Demon Fruit Blues is an immersive music-based experience that explores the origin of misogyny and ‘curse of womanhood’ as outlined in Genesis 3:16, inspired by the majesty of female African deities, ‘goddess’ themed art and feminist theory. This collection of work speaks to how the perception of the female body in this context has reverberated throughout Western history and left an indelible sociopolitical mark on those who identify as women.

Sanaz Ghajar  /Red Wednesday

 March 30 & April 1 @ 7pm, March 31 @ 9pm

A multimedia production about a family brought together and torn apart by revolution. Inspired by the controversial story of Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, Iran's Foreign Minister during the 1979 hostage crisis, and written by his great-niece, the play investigates Iran and America's relationship through the lens of a growing young woman. An historical allegory that pays special attention to those left to clean up the mess when we blow each other up.

 

A key aspect of this program is to keep tickets affordable. Regular tickets are priced at $20, however as a non-profit with the goal of supporting artists and their work, individual donations like yours are crucial to our success.

The goal of this campaign is two-fold:

Your donation guarantees you a ticket, meaning that no matter what, you’ll be there for these performances. This is really important to us. In addition, you will be one of the first supporters of this new program.

What you get:

  • Early access to your pick of shows.
  • The opportunity to support the individual artists and the Mabou Mines SUITE/Space program at the same time.

What the SUITE/Space Artists will use the funds for:

  • Is up to them. From covering their costs to boosting their own outreach efforts, these funds will help them achieve their vision.

What Mabou Mines will use the funds for:

  • Funding the administrative aspects of launching a new program.
  • Increasing the marketing and outreach budget so that we can reach new audiences.

 

Mabou Mines develops original works and re-imagined adaptations of classics through multi-disciplinary, technologically inventive collaborations. Our artistic process challenges the “traditions” of conventional theater by applying formal and experimental concepts to performance. 

In addition, the Company serves the artistic community by mentoring emerging artists, and creating opportunities for strengthening the city’s cultural landscape via our longstanding Resident Artists Program (RAP) and now our new performance initiative, SUITE/Space.

The Company’s collective structure provides the artists an opportunity to work both inside and outside of the Company. Mabou Mines embraces the idea of the “artist as entrepreneur” and encourages artists to use the Company as both a point of departure and return. Mabou Mines extends this philosophy to its SUITE/Space and  RAP program artists.

The current Company includes four Artistic Directors: Founding Artistic Director Lee Breuer and co-Artistic Directors Sharon Ann Fogarty, Karen Evans Kandel and Terry O’Reilly, three Artistic Associates: Maude Mitchell, Clove Galilee and David Neumann and a wide network of collaborators.

 

Contributing to this campaign is not the only way to make a difference. Regular ticket sales will open at the end of February. Buy a $20 ticket there, or an Artist/Student ticket for $10, or usher to see the shows for free. Subscribe to our mailing list to find out more. 

Above and beyond, the most important way you can show your support is to be there in the audience.... and a little social love never hurts. We won't stop you if you'd like to spread the word about us on your Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and the works. Every little bit helps.

 

This program is supported, in part, by The New York Community Trust from the Lila Acheson Wallace Fund for the Arts, by public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in Partnership with the City Council and the Indie Theater fund.
story_txt:
Mabou Mines has a long history of fostering the next generation of artists through mentorships and residencies. Our new performance program SUITE/Space provides development, rehearsal space, and public performances to artists that reflect NYC's rich cultural landscape and share Mabou Mines’ commitment to breaking new ground in form and content.
From March 27-April 1, 2018 SUITE/Space artists will perform their work in a festival-like setting at the new Mabou Mines Theater in the East Village — 2 performances each night for 6 nights in a row.
Your contribution to this campaign not only guarantees you a ticket, but invests directly in the artists' work as well as the future of the program. All income will be shared equally between the SUITE/Space artists and SUITE/Space Program expenses.
For the 2018 inaugural year of the program, SUITE/Space artists were nominated by community and performing arts organizations. The artists were selected by Mabou Mines' curatorial team — Mabou Mines Co-Artistic Director Karen Kandel, Mabou Mines Associate Artist David Neumann, and playwright and former Mabou Mines Resident Artist Carl Hancock Rux. For 2019 and beyond, the SUITE/Space artists will be selected through nominations and a public RFP process. 
 
Davalois Fearon /Time to Talk
March 27 @ 7pm, March 28 & 29 @ 9pm
Time to Talk is a multimedia dance-theater piece rooted in research on American history, dance history, racial identity formation and systemic racism. It is inspired by Davalois' own experience of oppression and racial bias within academia that she encountered in 2015. Dynamic fluid dance, live music, spoken word, projection art, and dialogue to call attention to racial inequalities within American concert dance and society at large. Performed with critically acclaimed Jazz multi-reedist Mike McGinnis, projection art by interdisciplinary artist Andre Zachery, and lighting by Sarah Hamilton. “Time to Talk” aims to encourage audience members to question how they may knowingly or unknowingly contribute to maintaining social norms that support a status quo of inequity. 
Tariq Al-Sabir / Unwanted
March 27 @ 9pm, March 28 & 31 @ 7pm
A multimedia song cycle written for a unique ensemble (including voice, actor, woodwinds, brass, percussion, synthesizer and electronics) that communicates real-time with film, focusing on the present trauma and cynical frustrations that plague social media oriented Black Millennials. Video direction by Monique Muse Dodd.
 
Tamar-kali / Excerpts from Demon Fruit Blues
March 29 @ 7pm, March 30 @ 9pm, April 1 @ 5pm
Demon Fruit Blues is an immersive music-based experience that explores the origin of misogyny and ‘curse of womanhood’ as outlined in Genesis 3:16, inspired by the majesty of female African deities, ‘goddess’ themed art and feminist theory. This collection of work speaks to how the perception of the female body in this context has reverberated throughout Western history and left an indelible sociopolitical mark on those who identify as women.
Sanaz Ghajar  /Red Wednesday
 March 30 & April 1 @ 7pm, March 31 @ 9pm
A multimedia production about a family brought together and torn apart by revolution. Inspired by the controversial story of Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, Iran's Foreign Minister during the 1979 hostage crisis, and written by his great-niece, the play investigates Iran and America's relationship through the lens of a growing young woman. An historical allegory that pays special attention to those left to clean up the mess when we blow each other up.
 
A key aspect of this program is to keep tickets affordable. Regular tickets are priced at $20, however as a non-profit with the goal of supporting artists and their work, individual donations like yours are crucial to our success.
The goal of this campaign is two-fold:
Your donation guarantees you a ticket, meaning that no matter what, you’ll be there for these performances. This is really important to us. In addition, you will be one of the first supporters of this new program.
What you get:

Early access to your pick of shows.
The opportunity to support the individual artists and the Mabou Mines SUITE/Space program at the same time.

What the SUITE/Space Artists will use the funds for:
Is up to them. From covering their costs to boosting their own outreach efforts, these funds will help them achieve their vision.
What Mabou Mines will use the funds for:

Funding the administrative aspects of launching a new program.
Increasing the marketing and outreach budget so that we can reach new audiences.

 
Mabou Mines develops original works and re-imagined adaptations of classics through multi-disciplinary, technologically inventive collaborations. Our artistic process challenges the “traditions” of conventional theater by applying formal and experimental concepts to performance.

The Company’s collective structure provides the artists an opportunity to work both inside and outside of the Company. Mabou Mines embraces the idea of the “artist as entrepreneur” and encourages artists to use the Company as both a point of departure and return. Mabou Mines extends this philosophy to its SUITE/Space and  RAP program artists.
The current Company includes four Artistic Directors: Founding Artistic Director Lee Breuer and co-Artistic Directors Sharon Ann Fogarty, Karen Evans Kandel and Terry O’Reilly, three Artistic Associates: Maude Mitchell, Clove Galilee and David Neumann and a wide network of collaborators.

story:
BUTOH ENCOUNTERS is a creative platform initiated by Karolina Bieszczad-Roley and run together with Sophie Barth. Each year we create performances which combine Japanese dance Butoh with other fields, making it accessible to Norwegian and international audiences.

After having worked with Butoh for nearly 20 years, we still try to understand it and find answers why it fascinates us. We invite you to join us on this quest!

This year, we extend Butoh beyond the boundaries of dance again. Using modern technologies, we will present a holographic performance of 3 legendary Japanese Butoh dancers who, due to their age, no longer perform in Europe. This autumn, we will turn Yoshito Ohno (80), Daisuke Yoshimoto (77) and Saga Kobayashi (72) into digital ghosts and let them dance in one of the most exciting new venues in Oslo - Oxertårnet. We get a unique access to this 11 floors concrete tower, before it is rented out to various artists. Our team will transform it into mystic space, blending performance, music, technology and culture together to allow the audience experience a vanishing dance.

We plan 2 evening performances open for everyone and 1 extra performance for high school students during the day. We have already completed our work with the dancers in Japan and we are now moving into the digital phase - editing and creating special effects in the hologram. The funds gathered through our Indiegogo campaign will allow us to fulfil our artistic vision and expand on creating the mystic world not only in the performance room but also the rest of the tower.

By donating to our project, you will be part of opening uncharted territories where art can live longer and travel further than dancers’ bodies. Let’s discover together where it takes us.

Support Butoh Encounters and choose  one of Karolina’s photographs of legendary Butoh dancers. All who donate will receive their photos in the post the day after the campaign has ended. Choose from the photos on Karolina's website : http://www.karolinastie.com/ or from the photos on this page.

Photos to the right (from the top):

1. Daisuke with a rose

2. Mai Ishiwata

3. Kei Ishikawa

4. Eros and Thanatos

5. National Gallery

6. Daisuke performance

7. Ritsuko Takahashi

-----------

Who we are:

Karolina Bieszczad-Roley (artistic director) holds a PhD in Butoh photography and has photographed some of the biggest names within Butoh, including Yoshito Ohno, Atsushi Takenouchi, Katsura Kan and Daisuke Yoshimoto. She has followed various Butoh dancers around the world for the last 18 years, producing photo-performances based on their mutual artistic collaboration. The results have been shown at photographic exhibitions in Poland, England, Norway and the US. Originally from Poland, educated in England, Karolina is now residing in Norway where she works in the film industry.

Sophie Barth (producer) Sophie holds an MA in theatre directing from East 15 Acting School in London. She is currently based in Oslo, and alongside directing she also works as a physical theatre performer and producer. She works with theatre as a way in to exploring other fields of art, and now researches butoh dance to develop a physical language in her art. Sophie is the artistic director and producer of Schouskollektivet - a research platform for interdisciplinary arts in Oslo. She also works with communication at the Humanities and Social Sciences Library at the University of Oslo.

story:
• Il Progetto Teatrale "Piantando chiodi nel pavimento con la fronte" è nato nel 2009 con una prima messa in scena in forma di "Primo Studio", guadagnando il "Premio Giovani Realtà del Teatro (Premio Allievi) 2009 - Accademia D'Arte Drammatica Nico Pepe di Udine" e molte critiche positive.
NOTE CRITICHE della GIURIA ARTISTICA del Premio Nazionale Giovani Realtà del Teatro (2009)

"Molto efficace e d’impatto. Provocatorio e pregnante."

"Un ottimo lavoro d’attore già strutturato con un disegno registico ben tracciato. Se non fossimo in Italia potrebbe girare con successo. A me piacciano questi testi ‘cattivi’ che rivelano spesso (quando non sono gratuita ostentazione di violenza o volgarità) più umanità e disperata poesia di altre forme più edulcorate o cerebrali”.

"bravo l’attore, bello il testo."


  • Un anno più tardi grazie alla collaborazione di Cristina Palumbo, è stato portato in scena ad Asolo (TV), nella prestigiosa manifestazione dedicata a Leo De Berardinis "Maratona del Teatro e della Danza", dove conquista un gremito Teatro Duse.
VENEZIAMUSICA e DINTORNI sulla Rassegna “Maratona del Teatro e della Danza 2010”

“Per la drammaturgia contemporanea si cita lo sferzante “Piantando chiodi nel pavimento con la fronte” ispirato alla drammaturgia di Eric Bogosian, interpretato su un palcoscenico deserto da Stefano Skalkotos che forniva l’efficace e politico ritratto di un uomo che odia la vita (e la sua dominante declinazione occidentale)…”


  • Nel 2011 lo spettacolo va in scena a Prato presso il Teatrino delle Briciole diretto dall'Attore Daniele Griggio, dove conquista il pubblico e guadagna un'altra bellissima recensione.

Recensione rivista on line www.radiospin.poloprato.unifi.it (Gennaio 2011) di Rossana Buffone

“Uno spettacolo che per molti aspetti ha lasciato tutti a bocca aperta.”

“[…] parole e gesti che colpiscono la sensibilità degli spettatori e vanno a stuzzicare le corde più vulnerabili del sentimento […] persino il racconto della morte di Lennon sembra, grazie alla straordinaria interpretazione di Stefano Skalkotos, la migliore fra le morti possibili.”

“La bravura del “rappresentante della società” di Stefano Skalkotos e la maestria del regista, hanno fatto sì che lo spettacolo venisse rappresentato con una concretezza e forza tale da lasciare il pubblico letteralmente sconvolto emotivamente.”

“Ancora una volta il teatro ha da insegnarci qualcosa che ha a che fare con l’essenza spietata della Vita […]”


  • Oggi ho deciso che questa bel testo uscito dalla penna di Eric Bogosian, dovesse divenire uno Spettacolo vero e proprio. Per fare questo si è rivelata preziosa la collaborazione del Maestro Roberto Negri, al quale ho affidato la Regia dello Spettacolo. Oltre a lui ho avuto la fortuna di incontrare e poter coinvolgere nel Progetto due giovani e talentuose professioniste che si occuperanno di scene e costumi .Ci incoraggia, inoltre, la notizia  che il nostro progetto ha ricevuto l'approvazione dello stesso Eric Bogosian, che tramite il suo Agente Mr.William Morris, ci ha concesso i diritti di rappresentazione in Italia.

Lo spirito con cui verrà affrontata questa nuova messa in scena, è tradotto perfettamente dalle parole di un grande attore internazionale Vernon Dobtcheff, che un giorno di qualche mese fa in risposta a dei complimenti per una sua bellissima interpretazione in un film, alla veneranda età di settant'anni, mi ha risposto: 

"Cerchiamo sempre di migliorarci.".


Saremo in scena in Prima Assoluta a Roma dal 18 al 23 Marzo al Teatro Tordinona di Via degli Aquasparta, 16.  

Anticipatamente GRAZIE A TUTTI COLORO CHE DECIDERANNO DI SOSTENERCI.

Stefano Skalkotos

story:
Hi!

We are the blues dancers of Krakow, and we would like to invite you to the second edition of Hummingbird blues – a three days long dance party! 

Scroll down to read about our goal, look right to check our perks, click above to review the clip. For more information go to www.hummingbirdblues.com and don't forget to like us on facebook.

And, above all, come to dance blues in Krakow on 19-21 of August! Give us some sugar to get the party started! 

... blues dancers ...

Blues is a dance based on improvisation, musicality and connection between partners. It was born in crowded juke joints of the American south, and later evolved together with blues music. Its popularity is now exploding in Europe – Poland's scene has grown from its LindyHop beginnings to pure blues enthusiasts who are bringing this festival to you for a second time.

... Hummingbird blues, three days party ...

As hummingbirds are the most restless of all creatures - dancing till exhaustion and community cooking are just two from many other activities that will await you!  If there's anything else you like to do and would like to share with people – contact us without hesitation! Massage? Another dance style? Stretching? DJ-ing? It's all up to you.

... Goal ...

Never mind if we gather the minimum or triple the suggested costs of the party - it is going to be awesome regardless of its price!

Even though it is possible to have a great fun for very little (you know, dancing in squats to a hobo's guitar and stuff), with your help we can boost our party up to the sky!  

First of all – the music. Reaching our campaign goal will allow us to invite the best of local musicians. More bands, more live music, more electricity involved!

Secondly – venues. Smooth dancefloors of a decent size. No splinters in your feet! 

Last, but not least – treats and other surprises! 



We can't wait to see you there!

story:
Who are we?

We are Bhumi Collective, a not-for-profit multi-disciplinary performing arts company that produces inter-cultural work from different parts of the world. 

Last year, we went to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for the first time with bhumi  – a multi-disciplinary performance by Singaporean and British artists. Fringebiscuit said it was “Epic visual storytelling” while edfringereview  gave us ★★★★ and told everyone that the show dealt with “a relevant and important issue within our modern society”!

So this year we're back again with a one-man show called "LAST OF THEIR GENERATION" by Singaporean theatre-maker Shaifulbahri Mohamad which will be on at the Studio in ZOO Southside (Venue 82) from 4-13 August at 12:40pm.

What do we need?

To help Shai tell his story of fleeting relationships, lingering moments and heartfelt encounters, we've enlisted the help of Singaporean director Adeeb Fazah to direct the show. Except, there's one problem: Adeeb lives in Singapore and we need to get him to Edinburgh!

Bhumi Collective believes in creating a platform where upcoming directors have the opportunity to create work globally. We need to raise £1500, which is the cost of a plane ticket from Singapore → UK and accommodation for Adeeb throughout rehearsals and the duration of the show. 

Risks & Challenges

Putting together a show is never easy, it takes a huge amount of money and resources to take Last of Their Generation to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. This crowdfunding campaign is a small but crucial part of the whole process. 

No director = No show!

We've already applied to the National Arts Council of Singapore and the Singapore International Foundation for funding. Furthermore, we plan to reach out to private donors capable of giving a little more to the arts and who have been fans of our work since day one to ask for their continued support.

What do you get?

Your contribution will go a massive way in helping us get a talented young Asian director to the UK for the first time. To say thanks, we've got a couple of perks for you including a postcard sent by Adeeb from Edinburgh, the Last of their Generation script and a limited edition zine made by Shai which includes pictures and text from the show.

The Team

Mohamad Shaifulbahri – Performer, Writer & Producer (He's telling the story!)
He's the Joint Artistic Director of Bhumi Collective and has produced & directed in cities like Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, London and Edinburgh.

Adeeb Fazah – Director (We're trying to get him to Edinburgh!)
He's the Artistic Director of The Second Breakfast Company and has been identified as a rising star in Singapore theatre by publications like TimeOut Singapore & The Peak.

Petrina Dawn Tan – Scenographer
She's a highly experienced designer who's making strides in the UK industry. She was recently nominated for Best Lighting Designer at the M1-The Straits Times Life Theatre Awards 2017 in Singapore for her work on The Necessary Stage's Manifesto

Victoria Chen – Assistant Director
She's an emerging theatre-maker who's been making work in Singapore, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Reykjavik, Shanghai and Connecticut. She recently won the Best Performing Artist Award 2017 at the Edinburgh Student Arts Festival for her work on Charlie with Bhumi Collective.

Nicholas Tee – Assistant Producer
He's a performance artist and curator of #cam4art, an online performance art series. He has made work with Latitude Festival, Battersea Arts Centre, Rich Mix (UK) and Cake Theatre, Kaizen M.D. and Singapore International Festival of the Arts (Singapore). 

Press

The Straits Times, Singapore, 23rd May 2017

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the message by sharing this campaign with your friends and family.

Similarly, if you have any other resources that you feel could help, please get in touch! We need as much publicity, rehearsal space and other funding raising opportunities as possible.

We're also having a one-night-only preview of Last of Their Generation in London on Thursday 20th July at 8:30pm at The Bunker. Click here for more info.

Thanks for reading this and please come to watch the show.

Tickets are on sale here!

Much love,

Bhumi Collective xx

Follow us on Facebook or visit our website!
story_txt: Who are we?We are Bhumi Collective, a not-for-profit multi-disciplinary performing arts company that produces inter-cultural work from different parts of the world. Last year, we went to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for the first time with bhumi  – a multi-disciplinary performance by Singaporean and British artists. Fringebiscuit said it was “Epic visual storytelling” while edfringereview  gave us ★★★★ and told everyone that the show dealt with “a relevant and important issue within our modern society”!So this year we're back again with a one-man show called "LAST OF THEIR GENERATION" by Singaporean theatre-maker Shaifulbahri Mohamad which will be on at the Studio in ZOO Southside (Venue 82) from 4-13 August at 12:40pm.What do we need?To help Shai tell his story of fleeting relationships, lingering moments and heartfelt encounters, we've enlisted the help of Singaporean director Adeeb Fazah to direct the show. Except, there's one problem: Adeeb lives in Singapore and we need to get him to Edinburgh!Bhumi Collective believes in creating a platform where upcoming directors have the opportunity to create work globally. We need to raise £1500, which is the cost of a plane ticket from Singapore → UK and accommodation for Adeeb throughout rehearsals and the duration of the show. Risks & ChallengesPutting together a show is never easy, it takes a huge amount of money and resources to take Last of Their Generation to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe. This crowdfunding campaign is a small but crucial part of the whole process. No director = No show!We've already applied to the National Arts Council of Singapore and the Singapore International Foundation for funding. Furthermore, we plan to reach out to private donors capable of giving a little more to the arts and who have been fans of our work since day one to ask for their continued support.What do you get?Your contribution will go a massive way in helping us get a talented young Asian director to the UK for the first time. To say thanks, we've got a couple of perks for you including a postcard sent by Adeeb from Edinburgh, the Last of their Generation script and a limited edition zine made by Shai which includes pictures and text from the show.The TeamMohamad Shaifulbahri – Performer, Writer & Producer (He's telling the story!)He's the Joint Artistic Director of Bhumi Collective and has produced & directed in cities like Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, London and Edinburgh.Adeeb Fazah – Director (We're trying to get him to Edinburgh!)He's the Artistic Director of The Second Breakfast Company and has been identified as a rising star in Singapore theatre by publications like TimeOut Singapore & The Peak.Petrina Dawn Tan – ScenographerShe's a highly experienced designer who's making strides in the UK industry. She was recently nominated for Best Lighting Designer at the M1-The Straits Times Life Theatre Awards 2017 in Singapore for her work on The Necessary Stage's ManifestoVictoria Chen – Assistant DirectorShe's an emerging theatre-maker who's been making work in Singapore, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Reykjavik, Shanghai and Connecticut. She recently won the Best Performing Artist Award 2017 at the Edinburgh Student Arts Festival for her work on Charlie with Bhumi Collective.Nicholas Tee – Assistant ProducerHe's a performance artist and curator of #cam4art, an online performance art series. He has made work with Latitude Festival, Battersea Arts Centre, Rich Mix (UK) and Cake Theatre, Kaizen M.D. and Singapore International Festival of the Arts (Singapore). PressThe Straits Times, Singapore, 23rd May 2017Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help us spread the message by sharing this campaign with your friends and family.Similarly, if you have any other resources that you feel could help, please get in touch! We need as much publicity, rehearsal space and other funding raising opportunities as possible.We're also having a one-night-only preview of Last of Their Generation in London on Thursday 20th July at 8:30pm at The Bunker. Click here for more info.Thanks for reading this and please come to watch the show.Tickets are on sale here!Much love,Bhumi Collective xxFollow us on Facebook or visit our website!

story:
My Story

I started identifying as genderqueer and using they/them pronouns in 2018, the same year (and almost the same time) that I started studying clown. I was inspired by increasing visibility and acceptance of gender minorities, especially as I started seeing more and more content about non-binary identities online, and it really made me think. I remember watching one particular video by this amazing activist named Riley Dennis and just starting to sob uncontrollably because I realized, ‘oh, that’s me too’. So I started the process of coming out to people that week, which included throwing myself a non-binary birthday party!

My experience made me realize how important representation is for those who may feel like they don't fit in with the gender binary. As I started making more clown work, I realized that I was consistently making work that examined gender and expressed my own genderqueer and nonbinary identity. In 2019 I took part in an arts incubator, Undiscovered Countries, to help me turn my short clown pieces into a longer show and thus my solo show Transhumance was born.

I am now taking Transhumance on tour to Texas, New Zealand and Australia. While on tour I plan to do advocacy work and engage with Trans and Gender Non-Conforming (TGNC) communities. My goal is to open up the dialogue around non-binary gender identities while telling my personal story through clown.

If you have any questions about my genderqueer identity or the show, please feel free to get in touch!

 Why I'm Fundraising

All of the funds that I'm raising through this campaign will go to the amazing queer and TGNC artists who are helping me make this show. My dramaturg, scenic designer and sound designer have all be an integral part of this process and I want to make sure that I can pay them a stipend that is not dependent on ticket proceeds. They will also get a percentage of the overall proceeds of the show - if there are any! There's no guarantee that I will make any money at all from this show, and I'm willing to take on that financial risk, but I don't want to have to make them take the risk with me.

Other Ways to Help

No worries if you don't want to or can't contribute monetarily. If you could just 'Like' the Facebook page for the show (https://www.facebook.com/transhumanceshow) and invite your friends to, that would be an immense help!

You can also follow the show on Instagram at @transhumanceshow

story:
Hi! My name is Antu Yacob, I'm an Ethiopian born, American raised actor and playwright. My play Mourning Sun received its world premiere with Theatre167 in New York November 2015.  Through my non-profit organization, Shaggae Song's Performing Arts Collective*, I am raising funds to bring Theatre 167’s production* of the play to the Kampala International Theatre Festival in Uganda.  

The play  is an epic cross cultural love story that gives a unique immigrant experience tackling taboo subjects. With a first act set in Ethiopia and the second in New York, this play follows main characters Biftu and Abdi as they navigate young love with the mental, emotional and spiritual effects of irreversible fistula. Why did I choose to write a play about fistula?

Several years ago my sister, who is now a medical doctor, volunteered at the Addis Ababa Fistula Hospital in Ethiopia. Hearing the devastating stories of the young women she encountered there, I realized any of one of those women could have easily been me,  if not for my mother and the resources we had to leave the country. This realization hit me hard and I wanted to tell their stories, bringing awareness to those of us here in the United States.

My larger goal in writing the piece was eventually to present the piece throughout countries in Africa affected by the obstetric fistula epidemic. It is a dream of mine to  present the play to women who are fistula survivors, for them to see their experiences acknowledged.  Equally fulfilling is the idea of presenting it as an educational, possible preventative measure for those surrounding them. As artists, we would be given the chance to allow our art to reflect our deep care for the womens' wellness and desire to eradicate this condition throughout the globe.

The play's participation in the Kampala International Theatre Festival, an annual event that gives a platform to connect the East African theatre-making community as well as  develop new audiences, would be the first step in connecting the imaginary world created in the play and the real life struggles and hope it reflects. 

As stated above, the Kampala International Theatre Festival is covering some of our costs. They are providing housing accommodations, in country transportation, as well as giving the artists a small daily stipend. The Festival, however, cannot cover our airfare costs.  

This is where we could really use your help! We are seeking to raise $12,000.00 with our campaign to pay for the round trip airfare from New York to Kampala, Uganda. Right now the average cost of a single round trip ticket is ranging $950.00-$1200.00.  We are also including cost of travel for the artists to get to the airport in New York. There are 7 actors (including myself, the playwright), our director, and our stage manager attending the festival.  The closer we get to travel dates, the more the amount is likely to increase, which is why we would really appreciate your help in securing these tickets as soon as possible.  Every donation made here to Shaggae's Song P.A.C.  is fully tax-deductible and will go directly towards the airfare and travel costs. 

Take a sec to check out the Attending Flight, Main Cabin, Co-Pilot and Air Force One perks you will receive for helping us achieve our goal! Very Unique Indeed.

Don't forget to get a sneak peak of the play in our Mourning Sun trailer on the "Gallery" tab of this page!

If you are unable to donate money at this time, that's ok! Please help us get the word about this campaign and share this page with EVERYONE you know! Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools. Thank you so much for your time and your help!

 

*Shaggae's Song Performing Arts Collective is a 501 (c)(3) nonprofit organization that develops works focused on international womens' issues as well as provides fundamental performing arts education to grades 4-12.

*This production is a touring version of the original production premiered in 2015 by Theatre 167 (Artistic Director, Ari Laura Kreith; Artistic Producer, Jenny Lyn Bader).

 

For more information please visit:

 https://www.facebook.com/Shaggaes-Song-Performi...

 http://www.antuyacob.com/mourning-sun/

https://www.facebook.com/KampalaInternationalTh...

http://kampalainternationaltheatrefestival.com/

 

Love & Light,

Antu Yacob

story:
From The Page To The Stage

I began writing this particular piece while sitting contemplating life in a Botanical Garden in Edinburgh, Scotland. I am constantly in search of a quiet spot, a moment of peaceful reflection, or a tiny slice of silence, especially having lived and worked in New York for over 15 years. I became intrigued by the idea that peace and quiet could be a state of mind, something one could carry with them, boldly trudging forward in a chaotic world. But the fact of the matter is, that peace is fragile, delicately held and fiercely protected in a world where it often seems everyone around you is "taking the piss" as they say.  Even in one of the world's most beautiful cities, in a royal botanical garden surrounded by plants and flowers and trees from every corner of the globe, my peaceful contemplation was hijacked by inconsiderate park dwellers, lawn mowers, defecating birds and swarming insects. This short play is my attempt at exploring these ideas, and I'm thrilled to bring it to life!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Putting on a show requires money. In this case, I'm doing it on the cheap! Still, some costs are unavoidable, and necessary for the success of a production. Those costs include festival fees (which go towards theater rental, marketing etc), studio rentals for rehearsals, costumes for the actors, props which are essential for telling the story, and printing of programs. All funds received will be used towards those costs.

As an expression of gratitude for you contribution, I've come up with some fun perks to give out! Take a look to the right to see what goodies are up for grabs!

Info on the show and tickets can be found HERE: 

http://newyorktheaterfestival.com/peace-and-quiet/

Feel free to share this campaign with those you think may be interested! Thank you in advance!

story:
Necessary Support for Aspiring Artists

IPAY created this award in 2013 as a way to honor Colleen. In doing so we have met and supported outstanding artistic talent that have already given back and inspired our community through their participation, voice and work for young people. Colleen would be in awe of the talent we have supported and would be proud of this program.

Since 2013 we have supported:

Amanda Pintore - IPAY Showcase 2017 - Madison & IPAY Showcase 2018 - Philadelphia. Aprilfestival - Sonderberg, Denmark (with support from Teatercentrum, Denmark). http://www.amandapintore.com/

Dominic Moore - Dunson & Emily Davis. IPAY Showcase 2016 - Montreal & IPAY Showcase 2017 - Madison. http://www.inletdance.org/ts-teams/dominic-moore-dunson/ http://www.messengertheatreco.org/emily-davis/

Nadira Beard & Cassadie Petersen. IPAY Showcase 2015 - Philadelphia. 

Susanna Hamnett - Residency in Adelaide and Tasmania, Australia (2013) (with support from Slingsby Theatre, Terrapin Puppet Theatre). IPAY Showcase 2014 - Pittsburgh. http://www.susannahamnett.com/

Impact through your Support

Your contribution supports the costs associated with directly supporting selected artists. The Porter fund is a dedicated fund within the IPAY budget - 100% of the money donated goes towards the expenses of mentorship, participation in Showcase and the potential for additional residency opportunities for the selected artist(s) each year.

Specifically, your contribution makes it possible to:

  • cover the costs for an artist to attend and participate at IPAY Showcase in two consecutive years including airfare, accommodation, per diem and registration costs
  • potential to support the artist to attend and participate in international residencies - this year we are supporting Amanda Pintore for an two-week internship residency in Denmark at the Aprilfestival with support from our colleagues at Teatercentrum
  • contribute to the costs supporting our program mentor and Porter Residency Director - we have been fortunate to engage Tony Reekie as our Director of the program since 2016, helping to make connections within the community, guide conversations specific to the work undertaken by our residents and to continue to evolve this important project.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with your friends and colleagues that understand the value and importance of supporting development of the arts and supporting creation of performing arts for young people. We know that those that were lucky to have known and loved Colleen will want to support this. But we hope that even if you didn't know her, you will find this an important cause to support.

Please also share the Colleen Toohey Porter Artist Development opportunity with artists that you know that might benefit from this program. Our goal is to make this opportunity as equitable and inclusive as possible and you can help by sending this opportunity to as many artists interested in creating work for young people as possible. There will be a Call for Applications this Autumn - More information is available on the IPAY website at www.ipayweb.org.

story:
What Is Join our Family, Make an IMPACT?

For IMPACT 17, we wanted to tell stories for youth that are as diverse as their own experiences. We are thrilled to introduce our Theatre for Young Audiences and Family Pavilion programming, bringing multicultural performances and activities from across Canada that are appropriate for the whole family.

From Whitehorse, comes Gwaandak Theatre with Map of the Land, Map of the Stars, a show that weaves together untold story-beads from our northern land.

Calgary’s Making Treaty 7 and Quest Theatre bring us We are All Treaty People, and the companion shadow play for an even younger audience, As Long as the Sun Shines. This play promotes healing and inspires positive relationships across cultures and generations.

From Montréal comes Geordie Productions’ award-winning play, Jabber, a story about friendship, bullying, racism, and beliefs.

Locally, we have Shadow Puppet Theatre’s The Flood Project, which explores finding the truth behind an ancient story that has been changed, and perhaps also stolen.

We also bring Stories to Build a Home from MT Space's own Young Company, a group of youth, travellers, lovers, survivors, immigrants, and settlers, telling vibrant and joyful stories full of heart and rooted in ancestry.

In partnership with the Schneider Haus National Historic Site, we have established the IMPACT 17 Family Pavilion in order to bring theatre, storytelling, crafts, and music to people of all ages, where together we can exchange histories, experiences, and perspectives.

It is important for every child to see themselves and their stories reflected on stage. Art has the power to be validating and affirming, as well as to instill empathy and understanding in those experiencing it. We need your support to bring these important stories to the youth of Waterloo Region. Please consider donating in support of our new Theatre for Young Audiences and Family Pavilion programming so that we can ensure it continues to have an IMPACT for many years to come!

How You Can Help Join our Family, Make an IMPACT:

Join our Family, Make an IMPACT is the 2nd Indiegogo Crowdfunding Campaign held by MT Space in support of our biennial international theatre festival, IMPACT. With our first campaign in 2015 “We Make IMPACT,” lovers of theatre and cultural-creatives like yourself, came together to surpass our goal of $20,000.

This year, we are raising the bar to $25,000 to support the Theatre For Young Audiences and Family Pavilion programming and artists of IMPACT 17, and with your help, we expect to be successful in making this year's IMPACT a festival the whole family can enjoy.

Specifically, your contributions will support:

  • Artists fees
  • Getting the artists here! Transportation & housing costs
  • Production costs (lighting, sound, video, costuming, set, etc.)
  • Staffing costs (administration, promotion, design, volunteer coordination, etc.

Together, we can bring diverse and culturally relevant stories to youth across the Waterloo Region. Help us reach our goal by October 7th, 2017.

Visit our website for more info, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and Instagram, and help us by spreading the word far and wide!

Together, we tell stories as diverse as the families in our community.

Together, we make space to share our past and our present, and to build our future.

Together, we Make an IMPACT that the whole family can enjoy!

If you are unable to donate, there are many other ways you can help us. If you would like to show your support for the belief in the need for diversity of voices in arts and culture, please consider getting involved in any of the following ways:

• Attend our events - be part of our community, volunteer, say hi, and get to know us

•  Spread the word online - share our campaign, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and on Instagram, your blog or anywhere else online

•  Talk to your friends – discuss the ideas behind Join our Family, Make an IMPACT with those you know, like co-workers or members of your book club

•  Subscribe to our MT Space newsletter

Thank You

The MT Space would like to thank the following people and organizations for generously lending us their time and talent in the creation of the Join our Family, Make an IMPACT campaign video:

Theatre and Performance Program (University of Waterloo)

Duncan Finnigan

Ahmad Meree

Nivan ElSeweify

Zac Gungl

Hadi Abboud

Randa Smaidi

Ali Abboud

Colin Umbach

Hasmukh Patel

Madhu Patel

Isabel Cisterna

Rami Masri

Fawaz Almassri

Nada Humsi

Ayham Abu-Rshaid

Hiba Kassab

Kholoud Alkhaledi

Nelly Samad

Kareem Masri

Mia Abouchakra

Sabia Abu-Rshaid

Serena Abu-Rshaid

Priscilla Jamel

Gulce Oral

Rami Costandi

Shadi Costandi

Arlene Thomas

Nizar Abboud

Anne Vermeyden

David Celis-Parra
 

About MT Space

Waterloo Region's first and only multicultural theatre company continues to fulfill its mandate by creating, producing and presenting high quality artistic performances and cultural events reflective of the people who live in the area. The MT Space strives to develop forms and practices that speak to, draw upon, reflect, and constitute Canadian contemporary community. The MT Space was founded in 2004 by Artistic Director Majdi Bou-Matar. The company has toured to Hamilton, London, Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal QC, Saint John and Fredericton NB, Victoria and Vancouver BC, within Canada and to Jordan, Syria and Lebanon internationally. The company has garnered several awards and rave reviews. The MT Space also offers educational programs and professional development workshops, and provides mentoring and assistance to local artists. The MT Space continues to promote the cultural richness of our community by providing a space for meaningful interaction.

What Is Join our Family, Make an IMPACT?
For IMPACT 17, we wanted to tell stories for youth that are as diverse as their own experiences. We are thrilled to introduce our Theatre for Young Audiences and Family Pavilion programming, bringing multicultural performances and activities from across Canada that are appropriate for the whole family.
From Whitehorse, comes Gwaandak Theatre with Map of the Land, Map of the Stars, a show that weaves together untold story-beads from our northern land.
Calgary’s Making Treaty 7 and Quest Theatre bring us We are All Treaty People, and the companion shadow play for an even younger audience, As Long as the Sun Shines. This play promotes healing and inspires positive relationships across cultures and generations.
From Montréal comes Geordie Productions’ award-winning play, Jabber, a story about friendship, bullying, racism, and beliefs.
Locally, we have Shadow Puppet Theatre’s The Flood Project, which explores finding the truth behind an ancient story that has been changed, and perhaps also stolen.
We also bring Stories to Build a Home from MT Space's own Young Company, a group of youth, travellers, lovers, survivors, immigrants, and settlers, telling vibrant and joyful stories full of heart and rooted in ancestry.
In partnership with the Schneider Haus National Historic Site, we have established the IMPACT 17 Family Pavilion in order to bring theatre, storytelling, crafts, and music to people of all ages, where together we can exchange histories, experiences, and perspectives.
It is important for every child to see themselves and their stories reflected on stage. Art has the power to be validating and affirming, as well as to instill empathy and understanding in those experiencing it. We need your support to bring these important stories to the youth of Waterloo Region. Please consider donating in support of our new Theatre for Young Audiences and Family Pavilion programming so that we can ensure it continues to have an IMPACT for many years to come!

How You Can Help Join our Family, Make an IMPACT:
Join our Family, Make an IMPACT is the 2nd Indiegogo Crowdfunding Campaign held by MT Space in support of our biennial international theatre festival, IMPACT. With our first campaign in 2015 “We Make IMPACT,” lovers of theatre and cultural-creatives like yourself, came together to surpass our goal of $20,000.
This year, we are raising the bar to $25,000 to support the Theatre For Young Audiences and Family Pavilion programming and artists of IMPACT 17, and with your help, we expect to be successful in making this year's IMPACT a festival the whole family can enjoy.
Specifically, your contributions will support:

Artists fees
Getting the artists here! Transportation & housing costs
Production costs (lighting, sound, video, costuming, set, etc.)
Staffing costs (administration, promotion, design, volunteer coordination, etc.


Together, we can bring diverse and culturally relevant stories to youth across the Waterloo Region. Help us reach our goal by October 7th, 2017.
Visit our website for more info, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and Instagram, and help us by spreading the word far and wide!
Together, we tell stories as diverse as the families in our community.
Together, we make space to share our past and our present, and to build our future.
Together, we Make an IMPACT that the whole family can enjoy!
If you are unable to donate, there are many other ways you can help us. If you would like to show your support for the belief in the need for diversity of voices in arts and culture, please consider getting involved in any of the following ways:
• Attend our events - be part of our community, volunteer, say hi, and get to know us
•  Spread the word online - share our campaign, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter and on Instagram, your blog or anywhere else online
•  Talk to your friends – discuss the ideas behind Join our Family, Make an IMPACT with those you know, like co-workers or members of your book club
•  Subscribe to our MT Space newsletter
Thank You
The MT Space would like to thank the following people and organizations for generously lending us their time and talent in the creation of the Join our Family, Make an IMPACT campaign video:
Theatre and Performance Program (University of Waterloo)
Duncan Finnigan
Ahmad Meree
Nivan ElSeweify
Zac Gungl
Hadi Abboud
Randa Smaidi
Ali Abboud
Colin Umbach
Hasmukh Patel
Madhu Patel
Isabel Cisterna
Rami Masri
Fawaz Almassri
Nada Humsi
Ayham Abu-Rshaid
Hiba Kassab
Kholoud Alkhaledi
Nelly Samad
Kareem Masri
Mia Abouchakra
Sabia Abu-Rshaid
Serena Abu-Rshaid
Priscilla Jamel
Gulce Oral
Rami Costandi
Shadi Costandi
Arlene Thomas
Nizar Abboud
Anne Vermeyden
David Celis-Parra 
About MT Space
Waterloo Region's first and only multicultural theatre company continues to fulfill its mandate by creating, producing and presenting high quality artistic performances and cultural events reflective of the people who live in the area. The MT Space strives to develop forms and practices that speak to, draw upon, reflect, and constitute Canadian contemporary community. The MT Space was founded in 2004 by Artistic Director Majdi Bou-Matar. The company has toured to Hamilton, London, Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal QC, Saint John and Fredericton NB, Victoria and Vancouver BC, within Canada and to Jordan, Syria and Lebanon internationally. The company has garnered several awards and rave reviews. The MT Space also offers educational programs and professional development workshops, and provides mentoring and assistance to local artists. The MT Space continues to promote the cultural richness of our community by providing a space for meaningful interaction.

story:
Short Summary

Thank You Thank You Thank You Global Village For Contributing To Our Initial Funding Campaign! We Are Now on our way to building a world-class institute that represents art, integrity and humanity and we need your support. Through this page we can receive your ongoing support. Please donate and spread the word.  

- The Watah School

My name is d'bi.young anitafrika and I am the Founder & Artistic Director of The Watah School: a w/holistic Black trans-disciplinary arts institute and professional theatre company located in Distillery Historic District. The Watah School cultivates and nurtures artists as healers, mentors, and keepers of the sacred using The Sorplusi Method. 

Previously anitafrika dub theatre founded in 2008, The Watah School was officially incorporated as a not-for-profit in 2014.  Arts-engagement sits at the core of our commitment to providing world people’s who are newly emerged, mid-career and established artists such as Black womben, racialized young adults, new immigrants, First Nations and LGBTQQIP2SAA people, with the tools to self-actualize, create urgent art and uncover crucial mentorship skills for each one us to teach one of us.

Our flagship training program, Performing Arts Training Intensive (PATI) is a one year professional development process offered to emerging Black and racialized artists (18-29 years old) who are under-represented in mainstream theatre and who are challenged to find spaces where they can receive professional development as theatre practitioners without racially and economically restrictive selection practices. PATI is a bridge into professional theatre that provides both theoretical and practical performance training while enabling mentorship between emerging and established artists. 

WOULD YOU CONSIDER WATERING THE ROOTS OF THE WATAH SCHOOL

What We Need

WE NEED RESOURCES FOR OUR TUITION-FREE TRAINING PROGRAM

PATI is a made accessible and tuition-free to all 12 young people enrolled in the program. The program is currently not funded by any external, governmental, private nor public funding bodies. WE NEED THE SUPPORT OF THE VILLAGE.

ADMINISTRATIVE RESOURCES

  • 3000$ 2 desktop macs                          
  • 500$ an all-in-one laser printer          
  • 500$ admin software                              
  • 500$ office supplies                                  

EQUIPMENT
  • 5000$ theatre lights                    
  • 500$ a projector                                        
SPACE ENHANCEMENTS
  • 1000$ sprung floors for the studio       
  • 1000$ a kitchen sink for the studio   
12,000$ TOTAL
WE WOULD LIKE YOU TO CONTRIBUTE TO HELPING US RAISE $12,000. YOUR SUPPORT PROPELLED US PAST OUR ORIGINAL GOAL OF $7000 AND NOW WE DREAM BIGGER!!! PLEASE HELP TO TAKE US THERE!!!

The Impact

Through this model of consistent training and mentorship, our mission is to encourage young emerging artists to cultivate an intersectional w/holistic approach to their lives, their art and their communities; telling their stories, creating art and leading others, from a place of compassion and authenticity. Youth engaged in this cyclical mentorship framework, develop not only as artists but as community leaders and arts educators.

From it’s inception (in 2008 as anitafrika dub theatre) to present, The Watah School has facilitated the growth and development of over 500 artists locally, nationally and globally through residencies, workshops, courses, conferences, events and one-on-one mentorship. 90% of these artists today, are leaders in their own creative fields. 

Incredible artist-instigators such as Liza Paul, Bahia Watson, Amanda Parris, Jamilah Malika, Natasha Adiyana Morris, Kim Katrin Crosby, Lishai Peel, Randell Adjei, Anthony Gebrehiwot, Cassy Walker, Natalyn Tremblay and Che Kothari (to name a few) have all studied The Sorplusi Method with anitafrika dub theatre/The Watah School. 

Help us nurture the present generation of storytellers. Thanking you from the depths of our being, in advance :)

Other Ways You Can Help

  • PLEASE SPREAD THE WORD using any and/or all social media!
  • SHARE SHARE SHARE.Tell y/our family and friends via Indiegogo's share tools!
  • COME OUT & SUPPORT ANY OF OUR 3 ANNUAL ART FESTIVALS showcasing the works of our artists-in-resdence and our professional company!
  • APPLY TO A WATAH RESIDENCY OR WORKSHOP which run on-going through out the year!
  • AND THANK YOU!

In love and Solidarity 

d'bi.young anitafrika and The Watah School Team

*Images by Anthony Gebrehiwot & Piece of Mine Festival*

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing

My name is Sloan Thompson, and I am directing the Echo Collective's production of "Kayak" by Jordan Hall. "Kayak" is a play about climate change, about family, and about the lengths to which we will go in order to deny the truths that terrify us. In a world careening closer and closer to a climate catastrophe, I cannot think of any more important story to tell, and I believe that theatre is the form in which to tell it. Theatre gets us all in the same room, it makes us look each other in the eye, and unlike the screens that are constantly isolating us, theatre allows us to come together on the same emotional journey, not just with our fellow audience members but with the performers as well. 

Theatre has the power to provide emotional context to hard facts, and to make those facts urgent and memorable. With this in mind, I intend to use this play as a platform to engage our audience in a meaningful discussion about climate change, and as a vehicle for inspiring theatre-goers to participate in environmental activism. To accomplish this, I have organized a talk back on our opening night, October 29th, where Jordan Hall, myself, and two representatives from Extinction Rebellion Vancouver will answer questions about the play, its themes, and local climate activism. Also, a representative from Extinction Rebellion will attend each show to provide information to any audience members who are inspired by the play and want to take action. My formula is simple: show the audience a powerful story, get them emotionally engaged, and channel that engagement into action. 

What We Need & What You Get

To make this play as successful as possible, we are hoping to raise $1000. Here's where that money will go:

- Advertising! This project WILL NOT WORK if no one hears about our show! We will have 5 performances in our 60-seat theatre, so that means we can get 300 people talking about climate change and local environmental activism. Your donation will help fill every seat and have those conversations!

- Compensation for actors and designers! I have put together a team of talented, hard-working artists to tell this story, and they deserve to be fairly compensated for their time and work. As I am not working with an established theatre company to produce this show, your donations will go a long way in ensuring a fair wage for our team. 

-Materials! Our fantastic set designer, Cecilia Vadala, has designed a beautiful set for us, but she needs money in order to build it. Your donation will help her design become a reality!

As a thank you for your donation, we have some perks to offer you! These perks include:

- A personalized thank you email from the cast and crew!

 - A personalized thank you video!

- A video montage of clips from the performance! 

- Your name on the Official Sponsors List in our program!

I Want To See It! What Are The Details?

"Kayak" will be playing at the Havana Theatre in Vancouver, Canada. The Havana is located at 1212 Commercial Drive.

Performance Dates:

- October 29th, 30th, 31st, and November 1st, 7:30pm

- November 2nd, 1:30pm

*** There will be a talkback with Jordan Hall, Sloan Thompson, and representatives from Extinction Rebellion Vancouver following the performance on October 29th!

Tickets are $25, and can be purchased at the door or reserved online through the Havana Theatre's website:

https://www.showpass.com/s/events/vancouver,-bc...

Kayak is presented by special arrangement with Samuel French, Inc., a Concord Theatricals Company. 

Thank you for reading, and please share info about this campaign with your friends and family!
