story:
PEASEBLOSSOM

A farce about the fairies in Shakespeare's A Midsummer Nights Dream. Starring a combination of actors and dancers from Sonoma County and actors from the Oregon Shakespeare Festival. Mary Gannon Graham, Paul Huberty, Lauryn Hochberg, Allison Rae  Baker, Eric Thompson, David Yen, Bronwen Shears, Brenda Reed, Chris Sword and many more. This play was written by Patrick Devon and workshopped by actors at the Oregon Shakespeare Festival.

Who are we?

PERFORMING ARTISTS COALITION FOR THEATER (PACT) , the umbrella organization for Sebastopol Shakespeare Festival, is a 501c3, non-profit charitable corporation comprised of professional artists who support one another in the pursuit of excellence with the goal of providing top quality performing arts presentations and educational opportunities to West Sonoma County and beyond.

What We Need

Sebastopol Shakespeare/Main Stage West a non profit theatre company committed to producing high-quality plays, needs $7000 for its 2012 Season's production costs of Peaseblossom. This amount will also pay for our road trip to Ashland to perform for the members of the Oregon Shakespeare Festival.
 

Perk Levels:

With a donation of......

 

$20 - Your name will live in ultimate glory in the playbill!!

$50 - the previous perk level along with a single ticket to the show and a Sebastopol Shakespeare T-Shirt.Rick 

$75 - the previous perk level along with another ticket to the show (2 tickets total) and a Sebastopol Shakespeare T-Shirt

$100 - the previous perk level along with another ticket (3 tickets total), T-Shirt and a thank you during the curtain speech for the show!

$250  - the previous perk level along with an addtional ticket (4 tickets total), T-Shirt and a paid dinner out with the cast and crew.

$500  - the previous perk levels with an additional 4 tickets to any Main Stage West production.

 

Our History

The Sebastopol Shakespeare Festival was established in 1993. In February of 2011, The Sonoma County Repertory Theater was forced to close its doors due to financial hardship.  A non-profit corporation, The Performing Artists Coalition for Theater, was formed with a central mission to continue to provide the city of Sebastopol and West Sonoma County with professional theatrical performance at the 104 N. Main Street location.  Since 1993, the festival in Ives Park had served Sebastopol and has been run by the company housed at 104 N. Main Street.  In the summer of 2011, as a brand new company, it was not possible for PACT to shoulder the responsibility of both keeping 104 N. Main Street open and running the festival in the park.  For the summer of 2011 then, the Napa Valley Shakespeare Festival produced two shows in Napa, and then brought them to Sebastopol so that the festival could continue.  As of the summer of 2012, the responsibility for overseeing the festival has fallen back on the shoulders of PACT.

 

As illustrated above, Sebastopol Shakespeare has emerged from the brink of collapse and built a new organizational structure, developed a committed board of directors and advisory board, recruited and employed skilled actors, creative personnel, and academic scholars, and raised its public profile to insure the organization’s growth. 

 

The Impact

Each season of the Sebastopol Shakespeare’s short life has seen remarkable growth over its previous season. Sebastopol Shakespeare is on a steady upward trajectory, growing both its audience and its financial base, and it is crucial that the company continue to challenge itself and its patrons. $7000 in support from you for its 2012 production of Peaseblossom will assist Sebastopol Shakespeare in its mission. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, there are always other ways to support. Please send this link to others that you know that may be able to help or contact us to volunteer your time!!

 

Sebshakes.org

Mainstagewest.com

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Doug.  I'm the Co-Artistic Director of Drive Theatre Company and the director of our inaugural production, 44 Plays for 44 Presidents.  The play examines each president in a 2-minute scene, starting with George Washington and ending with Barack Obama.  Through each president's play, we get a window into their time in office, and are left to decide where we want our country to head next.  

Our production aims to inspire high school and college students to develop an informed opinion on their government leaders, and take an active role in electing them.  We've partnered with Rock the Vote, and each of our 13 performances will have a Rock the Vote-trained volunteer in our lobby registering any unregistered audience members to vote.  We'll also be promoting the website ElectNext.com, a candidate-matchmaking site where through a series of questions on where you stand on current issues, you're matched with the local, state and national candidates whom you most closely align with, giving you an objective evaluation of the candidates you have the power to elect.

Additionally, we are one of 44 participating productions in a national festival. We represent Los Angeles, but this play will be performed in states and cities all across the country, including Alaska, New York City, Chicago, Atlanta, Maine, Louisiana, Missouri and more.  Click to learn more about the festival.

By funding our campaign, you'll be paying actors, producers, designers, creatives (director, music director/composer, cinematographer, etc.) and crew for their work on this production.  You'll also be funding the budget for sets, lights, sound, costumes, props, projection, marketing and insurance.

What We Need & Why We Need It

As a company, we've raised $4,478.52 so far, and have been using that to cover early expenses for this production.  Our estimated budget is $8,092.81 and we're hoping to raise just $2,500 through this fundraiser.  The remaining $1,000 will be absorbed from ticket sales, unless of course we raise more than our target in this campaign, and then all ticket sales will go to helping us fund our next production.  Here's how the budget breaks down:

  • Performance Rights:  $1,042.81
  • Performance and Rehearsal Venue Rental:  $3,040
  • Insurance:  $200
  • Pay:  $2,110
  • Department Budgets:  $1,700

The Impact

This show does a lot of great things for a wide range of people.

  • Registers California residents to vote
  • Presents a factual, non-partisian look into our country's presidents
  • Educates and engages the community on local, state and national issues
  • Inspires young voters to care about the decisions being made by today's leaders
  • Provides a positive, proactive outlook on today's media-saturated politics
  • Offers a memorable evening of theatre that can only be seen live to be fully appreciated

To reach the high school and college students we're targeting, we'll be contacting and performing scenes from the play in local Los Angeles county high schools and holding a discussion with the actors and director afterwards.  We'll also distribute post cards, advertise on Facebook, and utilize members of our own team who either currently attend college or work in school systems to engage with their communities.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Email this campaign to a friend or family member you know is passionate about voting and may be able to help financially support our cause
  • If you have ties to Los Angeles/California government officials, contact them and spread word about our production
  • Share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hi, my name is Doug.  I'm the Co-Artistic Director of Drive Theatre Company and the director of our inaugural production, 44 Plays for 44 Presidents.  The play examines each president in a 2-minute scene, starting with George Washington and ending with Barack Obama.  Through each president's play, we get a window into their time in office, and are left to decide where we want our country to head next.  
Our production aims to inspire high school and college students to develop an informed opinion on their government leaders, and take an active role in electing them.  We've partnered with Rock the Vote, and each of our 13 performances will have a Rock the Vote-trained volunteer in our lobby registering any unregistered audience members to vote.  We'll also be promoting the website ElectNext.com, a candidate-matchmaking site where through a series of questions on where you stand on current issues, you're matched with the local, state and national candidates whom you most closely align with, giving you an objective evaluation of the candidates you have the power to elect.
Additionally, we are one of 44 participating productions in a national festival. We represent Los Angeles, but this play will be performed in states and cities all across the country, including Alaska, New York City, Chicago, Atlanta, Maine, Louisiana, Missouri and more.  Click to learn more about the festival.
By funding our campaign, you'll be paying actors, producers, designers, creatives (director, music director/composer, cinematographer, etc.) and crew for their work on this production.  You'll also be funding the budget for sets, lights, sound, costumes, props, projection, marketing and insurance.


What We Need & Why We Need It
As a company, we've raised $4,478.52 so far, and have been using that to cover early expenses for this production.  Our estimated budget is $8,092.81 and we're hoping to raise just $2,500 through this fundraiser.  The remaining $1,000 will be absorbed from ticket sales, unless of course we raise more than our target in this campaign, and then all ticket sales will go to helping us fund our next production.  Here's how the budget breaks down:

Performance Rights:  $1,042.81
Performance and Rehearsal Venue Rental:  $3,040
Insurance:  $200
Pay:  $2,110
Department Budgets:  $1,700



The Impact
This show does a lot of great things for a wide range of people.

Registers California residents to vote
Presents a factual, non-partisian look into our country's presidents
Educates and engages the community on local, state and national issues
Inspires young voters to care about the decisions being made by today's leaders
Provides a positive, proactive outlook on today's media-saturated politics
Offers a memorable evening of theatre that can only be seen live to be fully appreciated

To reach the high school and college students we're targeting, we'll be contacting and performing scenes from the play in local Los Angeles county high schools and holding a discussion with the actors and director afterwards.  We'll also distribute post cards, advertise on Facebook, and utilize members of our own team who either currently attend college or work in school systems to engage with their communities.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Email this campaign to a friend or family member you know is passionate about voting and may be able to help financially support our cause
If you have ties to Los Angeles/California government officials, contact them and spread word about our production
Share our campaign on Facebook and Twitter

story:
Catapult Love is a high-wire musical-comedy adventure of a woman in search of herself crow-barring her way through a catastrophic line-up of lovers. It is a head-to-head onstage throw-down between the comedic genius of Katie Goodman, her co-writer Soren Kisiel, and the high-energy, addictive wit and music of Pulitzer Prize-winning political cartoonist Tom Toles and his riotous band, Lethal Bark.


Who The Hell Are We?

Okay, half of you know Tom and half of you know Katie & Soren. And we’re betting there’s some overlap due to their careers and senses of humor. And if not, there is about to be. Ya love Tom? You’ll love Katie and Soren. If you enjoy the liberal-climate-change-feminist-satirical-anti-Tea-Party mischief of one of these guys you’ll love the same artistic shenanigans of the other. This unexpected and hair-brained collaboration between three of the country's most dexterous comedy writers, along with performances by Katie Goodman (it’s a one-woman show, people), Tom Toles (the band leader and lead singer) and Lethal Bark (the on-stage band), is a project that so far is proving to be unique, smart, energetic and hilarious.


Why This Show Matters

We’re all looking for ourselves, and most of us are looking for ourselves in the wrong places. Does that resonate with you? No, not at all? (Maybe you should ask your friends before you answer that one…)

Catapult Love traces the adventures of a woman trying to locate her authentic self. Katie has made a career out of writing from her authentic voice (okay she writes with her husband, but let’s not start out such a nice relationship with you guys undermining things with ironic commentary, okay??). Her TED Talk (https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_em...) and her book (http://katiegoodman.com/katies-book) both stress the importance of finding ones voice. But what happens when you want to connect deeply with others but don’t want to merge so much that you lose yourself in it?

Catapult Love helps us answer the question: “Who The Hell Am I??”  A stage aswarm with come-to-life cartoon art, a rare happy collision of collaboration of artists with comic talent in tubfulls, strange and unexpected new takes on stage traditions, and a narrative as dense with humor as stand-up comedy.

Help us breathe some fresh life and fire onto the stage, and create a show of pure delight, surprise and adventure.

What We Need

In order to free up our time from other paying projects, so we can focus on the development of this one, we need to raise moolah. This is really simple and straight-forward. We are seeking $9,000 which breaks down to $3k for each writer: Tom, Katie & Soren.

What you are helping us achieve:

This is stage one-- development of the script which is what is going to make something like this a success or not. No whipping out quick-o first drafts! (Well, actually Tom already did that but it was far from "quick-o." It was terrific. Wait, now that we think about it, he didn’t actually show us his veeeery first draft…) So, we need this support and time to really work through it and get it into shape ready for our first reading where we will shop it around to theatre companies that will want to jump on board and produce it.

The Impact of Your Donation

Seriously, if we can’t raise this we can’t do it. Plain and simple. The days of writing in a coffee shop for the fun of it are, unfortunately, over. Please, please don’t make us take that job writing funny slogans for Victoria Secrets' spring sale instead of writing this musical. Okay, that comes with some perks and Soren is across from me saying, “Did they offer?!?!?” Writing a musical is a long, hard, concentrated project. We can’t do it in our spare ten minutes a day. Because by the time we’d finish, well… we’d be dead. And then who the hell is gonna perform this thing?

What Will You Get?

#1: PERKS:

Check em out! They are on the right side of your screen! Buy an original caricature of you or your kids or partner drawn by Tom! Or signed original one-of-a-kind Washington Post political cartoons – you pick your fave! Books! CD’s! A show by Katie at your event! VIP theatre tix! Scroll down on the right!

#2: Bragging Rights Will Abound:

YOU WILL BE IN ON THIS FROM THE VERY BEGINNING!

Setting: Opening night after-party. Dimly lit swanky club.

YOU: So, you know I was in on this from the very beginning…

PERSON YOU’RE HITTING ON: Really?!?! How did you know it had such potential to be an Obie award winning musical?

YOU: Oh, I just felt it in my gut. I have an instinct for these things.

PERSON WHO’S NOW REALLY IMPRESSED WITH YOU: Wow. Well you really knocked it out of the park with this one. And you helped support them from the start? That really was so gracious. And so dedicated to supporting the modern American theatre scene. You’re not only good with your instincts, you’re good-hearted as well. You support art and know a good investment when you see it. Wow…

YOU: (Smiling seductively, staring into their eyes.) Yes. Yes I do. (You pull out your phone.)

PERSON WHO IS NOW TYPING THEIR PHONE NUMBER INTO YOUR PHONE: (Giggles shyly.)

Fade to black.


Okay A Little More Detail on the Plot of Catapult Love:

The story follows a smart yet utterly lost single woman, as she launches herself into relationships with all the power and inaccuracy of a catapult. Mid-air she questions her aim, her destination, her sanity and her mother as she chronicles it all for the audience with her lacerating narrative and loopy artwork. Yes, like co-author Tom Toles, she is a cartoonist and illustrates her stories and struggles with a dizzying constellation of caricatures, which come to life in animation and full-size two-dimensional puppets, designed by Toles. Her fatal flaw? Wanting everything to be one-dimensional. Life doesn't seem to want to comply.

The music, quirky original up-tempo quasi-rock, chronicles in song the cast of narcissists and losers that Lurid has the uncanny talent for attracting...and latching onto. Looking for wisdom in all the wrong places, she has asked the audience’s help in making a fateful decision, as she tries to sort out what she is learning in the middle of the maelstrom.

(Note: support of this project does not bestow or imply investment in or ownership of the material or production.)

Wanna see what we’ve done that’s rocked so far?

Go here for Tom:

http://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/toles/

And here for Katie & Soren:

http://katiegoodman.com

TOM TOLES is the Pulitzer-prize winning Editorial Cartoonist for the Washington Post. He has won the Herblock Prize, The Thomas Nast Award, the National Headliner Award and numerous other prizes for his editorial cartoons. He has been Editorial Cartoonist for US News and World Report, The New Republic, The New York Daily News, The Buffalo News and the Buffalo Courier Express. His cartoons are syndicated nationally to over 100 publications. He has drawn and syndicated two comic strips, Curious Avenue and Randolph Itch, 2am.  He has published several books of cartoons, and a short novel, My School is Worse Than Yours. Tom draws six cartoons a week for the Washington Post and blogs for the Post daily. Tom is also a musician, a singer and songwriter and drummer for two DC bands, Lethal Bark and Suspicious Package. He has performed in Washington, New York City and Europe.

SOREN KISIEL & KATIE GOODMAN are playwrights, humor writers, actors and directors, and the co-Authors and co-Directors of Broad Comedy, an all-women sketch comedy and political satire troupe, which has played to sold-out houses in extended runs at Boston’s Stuart Street Playhouse and at the Acme Comedy Theatre in West Hollywood, and has been showcased at Caroline’s Comedy Club in Times Square, won the Pick-of-the-Fringe Award at the Vancouver Fringe Festival, was listed as one of the top ten sketch troupes at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland and were also nominated for The EPIC Award from The White House Project. Soren and Katie have also used this material to create a one-woman show for Katie that is currently running monthly performances at Joe’s Pub at the Public Theater and at the Upper West Side’s Stage 72 in New York City. This work was also featured on Showtime’s The Green Room With Paul Provenza, as well as being the basis of numerous hit YouTube videos. Katie is a featured blogger for The Huffington Post, has contributed to O, The Oprah Magazine and is the author of “Improvisation For The Spirit.” Soren and Katie have been nominated for a MacArthur Foundation Genius Grant for their unique work in theater. Soren’s award-winning short play, Smooth Landings, is currently receiving a revival in the Los Angeles Science Fiction One-Act Festival.

Share

Please post this to your Facebook or email it to one friend you think might love to be involved in creating a brand new feisty musical from the ground up. You can use the Indiegogo share tools right at the top of this page. Thank you! You rock! Which is appropriate since this is a rock musical.

Catapult Love: Find yourself.

Love: Find yourself.

story:
Our Story

We're passionate about theatre that stirs and stimulates.  Whether it is through contemplative tellings of stories that are often marginalized or radically embodied forms of physical theatre, we care that our theatre is intelligent, ambitious, experimental, and exciting. 

Each of our projects began during our Master of Fine Arts in Performance/Creation at York University in September 2017.   As we embark on our first post-graduation adventure, we want to take our learnings and share them with the Toronto community.  Much of this work has been self funded but we reach out to you now to help us make this dream a reality.  Our main priority is paying all artists involved for their labour and contribution.  Your donations will almost entirely go towards real, working artists.  

Our work will span the complex conversations of queerness and race, capitalism and consumption, faith and fear, and beyond.  While much of the work tackles important and complicated issues, we take deep care to make our work as emotionally alive as they are intellectually dynamic.  

Your contribution will help situate new and experimental theatre work in Toronto by enterprising theatre artists.  It is these kinds of stimulating offers from you that contribute to a dynamic and alive Toronto theatre landscape.

What We Need & What You Get

OUR BUDGET:

$300 - Insurance

$1500 - Production Manager

$4000 - Artists (Performers, Technicians, Designers)

$500 - Marketing

$700 - Additional Production Costs (props, set, costume supplies)

Who Are We?

Mallory Fisher is a Toronto-based theatre creator, director, songwriter, and gin drinker from Newfoundland. She holds a BFA in Musical Theatre Performance from the Boston Conservatory. Her solo show, MAD GIRL'S LOVE SONG, is a three-dimensional poem derived from a combination of autobiographical sources and the life and writing of Sylvia Plath. MAD GIRL'S LOVE SONG is a reclamation of illegitimacy and a defence of girlishness. Set in an oven, one woman fights extinction while navigating questions about queerness, isolation, daughterhood, mediocrity, and food.

Desirée Leverenz is a director, creator and performer living in Tkaronto and hails from Treaty 6.  Desirée is a graduate of the BA Drama Honours program at the University of Alberta and is a current MFA candidate in Theatre at York University.  Desirée will be presenting an original devised piece: Eat Me.  Eat Me is an ensemble devised piece that takes form in a live abstract painting.  Blurring the lines between performance art and theatrical performance, Eat Me explores our obsession with consumption and the reasons behind it.  What are the impacts of living in a world that tells us to consume more and more and more? 

Jason Hildebrand leads a team at Jason Hildebrand Creative Arts, where he serves as a performer, creator, and communication coach. For over 20 years Jason has partnered with faith-based theatre and film companies, organizations and educational institutions around the world as an artist and coach. In his new solo exploration, Lost Fool, fragments of mythical, historical and personal stories create a complex and colourful theatrical mosaic. The work is an excavation of Hildebrand’s own wrangling of faith and brokenness as it relates to his Mennonite heritage. Using the Eastern Orthodox tradition of the Holy Fool as a launching point, this offering asks what it means to be lost while yearning for connection to the Divine.

Makram Ayache is a queer Arab-Canadian theatre maker, educator, and activist.  He is the founder and co-Artistic Director of In Arms Theatre Collective, an ad hoc, queer theatre company based out of Edmonton, Alberta.  His most recent play, The Green Line, began with a provocation: “How does intergenerational memory and trauma sit in our bodies, hearts, and minds?”  Set in a bustling Middle Eastern city, the play explores this question through queer memory. Following four characters who weave and braid into each other’s lives, the play asks: What should we remember?  What can we afford to forget? And just how close is cultural memory to our spine?

Gülce Oral is an actor and a theatre artist from Istanbul. Her passion in exploring ways of storytelling rooted in physicality and bodily impulse inspired her to continue her artistic research in this field; she pursued her MFA in Performance/Creation at York. I Thought I Could Live Without is a movement-based solo piece about losing and finding identity, about community and isolation, and about how memory both enslaves us to past and frees us to be who we are.

story:
Short Summary

Hi everyone. My name is Ian Knowles and I have been working professionally as a dancer since I was 17. I started early in television and clubs in Perth until I moved to Sydney to persue my career in Musical Theatre, Film, Television, clubs... Alongside my performance career I also started to choreograph - both small and large events. My last position was as Artistic Director of a pre-profesional at The Space Dance and Arts centre in Melbourne. Sadly this role was cut short by a terminal brain tumour diagnosis. I am happy to report that that I am still her 5 years down the track and ready to create.

This work was inspired by a street performer in Melbourne playing the piano accordion. Her playing was so beautiful that it transported me to Paris. From there other inspirations came into play; my love for the art work of Toulouse Lautrec, and my obersvations of cycles of life - and in this case cycles of abuse.

This workshop will give the creative team the opportunity to explore how the narrative will read and how the music will work to drive the story. The show is both beautiful and tragic but does offer some hope, and hopefully will inspire more conversation about this important topic.

The wonderful creatives are:

Choreography - Juliette Verne (http://j-foxx.com.au) Check out her amazing work

Musical Director - David Pritchard -Blunt (http://www.davepb.com) The master of music

What We Need & What You Get

All of the money raised goes to paying all of the artists in the room; choreographer, musical director and the dancers. I am committed to always paying artists as they are so often asked to do this type of work for free. Because this is a passion project for me, I am taking no fee. I just want the show to begin to come to life.

If we don't reach our entire goal we will have to reduce the amount of days we can workshop not the amount people get paid. We are not working to a particular outcome, it is an exploratory process for both the team and the dance artists.

Unfortunately we have nothing to offer as a perk aside from a shout out on social media and the gratitude of all of us!

Risks & Challenges

The only risks and challenges are raising the money we need. This process is so important to develop the story for maximum impact. The story is strong and the message is clear, now we need to give it life.
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hi everyone. My name is Ian Knowles and I have been working professionally as a dancer since I was 17. I started early in television and clubs in Perth until I moved to Sydney to persue my career in Musical Theatre, Film, Television, clubs... Alongside my performance career I also started to choreograph - both small and large events. My last position was as Artistic Director of a pre-profesional at The Space Dance and Arts centre in Melbourne. Sadly this role was cut short by a terminal brain tumour diagnosis. I am happy to report that that I am still her 5 years down the track and ready to create.
This work was inspired by a street performer in Melbourne playing the piano accordion. Her playing was so beautiful that it transported me to Paris. From there other inspirations came into play; my love for the art work of Toulouse Lautrec, and my obersvations of cycles of life - and in this case cycles of abuse.
This workshop will give the creative team the opportunity to explore how the narrative will read and how the music will work to drive the story. The show is both beautiful and tragic but does offer some hope, and hopefully will inspire more conversation about this important topic.
The wonderful creatives are:
Choreography - Juliette Verne (http://j-foxx.com.au) Check out her amazing work
Musical Director - David Pritchard -Blunt (http://www.davepb.com) The master of music

What We Need & What You Get
All of the money raised goes to paying all of the artists in the room; choreographer, musical director and the dancers. I am committed to always paying artists as they are so often asked to do this type of work for free. Because this is a passion project for me, I am taking no fee. I just want the show to begin to come to life.
If we don't reach our entire goal we will have to reduce the amount of days we can workshop not the amount people get paid. We are not working to a particular outcome, it is an exploratory process for both the team and the dance artists.
Unfortunately we have nothing to offer as a perk aside from a shout out on social media and the gratitude of all of us!

Risks & Challenges
The only risks and challenges are raising the money we need. This process is so important to develop the story for maximum impact. The story is strong and the message is clear, now we need to give it life.

story:
Who Are we?

From a small town nestled amongst the golden hills in the Southern part of Humboldt County, California, come an amazing group of highly talented and extremely excited women with an impressive vision! Combining bold entertainment with conscientious giving, we sing, dance, flirt and fundraise. With your generosity, we can continue to bring laughter, joy and inspiration to the many.

We are the Bada Bling! Burlesque. A troupe made up of fifteen unique and talented women who write, choreograph, dance and produce our own shows. Mixing the sultry and the sexy in with the comedy and the cabaret, we infuse our performances with variety. From hip-hop and jazz, to new world beats and burlesque classics, we perform in front of hundreds, bringing a professional show that has the crowd whooping and hollering, giggling and roused every time. Believing that all women deserve to shine, we offer an opportunity for ladies of many ages, shapes, styles and backgrounds to have their moment in the lime light .We believe we can uplift women to be the beautiful sexy gals that they are. 

What do we do?

Beyond enriching our own lives and entertaining the towns, we take it one step further. We strive to support our communities that surround us by fundraising for local and international non-profits. From selling cupcakes or hosting parties to performing full length theatrical shows we make it our mission to dance for a cause! So far we have raised funds for our local volunteer fire department, and our 430-acre community park as well as to raise funds to continue to protect an important and diverse primary rainforest in the mountains of Ecuador. In the works are shows to benefit our local historic town theatre.

Why we need your help?

Of course to raise money we must spend money! And we do love baking cupcakes, but its time to reach out to you and ask for some real cash. The money raised here will cover costumes, rehearsal space, hall rental, performers fees, lights, sound, camera, and Action!!!!! We bring a professional show, and that ain’t cheap!

Coming Up!

Our next performance, will be participating as special guests for internationally acclaimed theatre production company, Dell Arte ,in their adult cabaret, “Red Light, Blue Lake” on July 6th.  Followed by our full-length show, “Back in Business” on July 27th and 28th that will benefit the Garberville Theatre!  After that, you may see us in your hometown!

Love from the Babes of the Bada Bling!

 

To contact us:

Visit our Facebook page at Bada Bling! Burlesque

or email:burningleaf@asis.com


To learn more about projects we have supported visit:

www.garbertvilletheatre.com 

www.reservaloscedros.org

www.sohumpark.org

 

Don’t forget to share the love....even if you cant contribute… others can… spread the word and share the link…..

story:
"An inventive, nutty, and wonder-inspiring production."
- Washington Post, Editor's Pick


*****
Best of the Fringe!
Planet Egg is one of the most ingenious shows at the Capital Fringe Festival... simply magical.” - DC Metro Theatre Arts

 

 

“This is the kind of stuff Jim Henson would definitely be proud of.” - MD Theatre Guide

 

After a successful run at the Capital Fringe Festival this summer, PuppetCinema has been given another opportunity to take Planet Egg on the road....

Thanks to the extreme generosity of the Consulate General of Israel in Los Angeles & the entire Oahu Fringe organization, PuppetCinema will be taking Planet Egg to Hawaii to perform in the 2nd annual Oahu Fringe Performing Arts Festival, November 8-10, 2012! 

We are SO thrilled by the enthusiasm from the Consulate, who believes our show can have an impact on the festival and arts scene in Oahu this fall. We look forward to bringing our unique performance concept to the pacific islands AND to teaching a puppet-building workshop while we're there! 

Please support the company by helping us raise the remainder of our production expenses, so we can show those Pacific Islanders what PuppetCinema is all about!

 

What We Need & What You Get

Thanks to the Israeli Consulate, most of our travel expenses are covered! But of course, producing a show (anywhere) costs money. Here's where our funds will go:

$1000 - Shipping equipment to Hawaii
$400 - Rental van to transport equipment and company to/from the theater + insurance, gas, parking
$350 - Marketing materials (postcards, posters, printing programs, press kits)
$100 - Vegetables, Dry Ice, and other perishable props
$450 - Additional equipment (renting tables, projection screen, mic stands, equipment replacements, materials for the puppet-building workshop)
$1400 - Accommodations in a hostel for 4 people
$100 - Projector bulb
$200 - Contingency, food, emergency funds
$300 - IndieGoGo transaction fees
______

$4300



In return for your generosity, donors will receive all kinds of swag! See the *Rewards* section below! Go to http://www.cafepress.com/puppetcinema to see images of the cool stuff you can get for donating. 


There are other ways you can help, too! Spread the word to your friends, engage with us online, buy merchandise, and come to Hawaii to see the show!  :-)

story:
Richmond, Virginia's KARAR DANCE COMPANY is a modern and contemporary dance company led by Artistic Director Kara Robertson, a Richmond native and VCU alumna.  Through powerful, deep-rooted modern dance performance, KARAR DANCE COMPANY investigates the complexity of human emotion and experience through highly physical and athletic movement. KDC believes that dance positively impacts the community and its inhabitants.  We seek to engage and connect with the people of Richmond and beyond via performance and education. KARAR DANCE COMPANY looks forward to establishing more opportunities that inspire choreographers and young dancers to continue creating work and performing.

“Across Disciplines” is a celebration of art and collaboration to be presented on October 5th and 6th at 8 pm at The Grace Street Theater in Downtown Richmond.  KARAR DANCE COMPANY engages with creatives from various disciplines to present the community with multi-dimensional dance performance. Join us in celebrating Richmond artists and their work.  Our campaign exists to support all artists and performers involved and to compensate them for their dedication and craft. Partner with us by donating! If you are unable to make a contribution please share with family and friends.  We appreciate your support.

Grab your tickets at tututix.com/karardancecompany!  $12 adults, $8 students.  Cash/check at the door ONLY.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $3,000 and here is where that money goes: Dancers, Collaborators, Theater Rental & Fees, Lighting Design, Stage Management, Promotion Materials, Costuming.

Perks of donating:

$25 - 1 FREE Ticket

$50 - 2 FREE Tickets

$100 - 2 FREE Tickets & a SHOUT OUT in our performance program

$200 and above - 4 FREE Tickets, SHOUT OUT in our performance program, & a signed poster from all artists and professional dancers

KARAR DANCE COMPANY is in continuous growth.  We are adding performances and events to our calendar including a presentation of “Amid” for the American Dance Guild Festival in New York City at the Ailey Citigroup Theater on October 27.  Your support and generous donation allows us to continue educating and offering rich performance to our community of RVA and beyond! Assist us in developing our reach as we continue to inspire young dancers and choreographers and provide arts professionals with more work and a platform to showcase their work.

KARAR DANCE COMPANY currently operates as a professional project-based modern dance company.  What does this mean? We are not a 501(c)3 Non Profit and therefore do not qualify for grant funding and community donations can not be written off.  We rely on the leadership of Artistic Director Kara Robertson and generous gifts from the public to fund our work. Dancers and other artists will also rehearse and create for free.

We appreciate donations from someone like you because it allows us to continue working towards becoming a Non Profit company to receive more funding and reach our company goals and objectives.  You help us establish relevance and permanency.

We understand that you may not be able to assist us financially.  However, you can still help in big ways. Spread the word and MAKE SOME NOISE about our campaign.  Share with you friends, family, and even enemies. Don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools! And don’t forget to see the performance on stage October 5th and 6th!

story:
Who are you?

The San Francisco Olympians Festival has been gaining momentum since its first year, with twenty plays that were commissioned by the festival having gone on to full productions: 2010’s Hermes (No Nude Men Productions, Dramaworks, Bread and Water Theatre), Juno En Victoria (Wily West Productions), and Salty Towers (Thunderbird Theater Company); 2011’s Cassiopeia (Eat Street Players), Chronus (Bread and Water Theatre), You’re Going To Bleed (DIVAFest), Io (Off The Cliff Theatre), and Pleiades (No Nude Men Productions); 2012’s Caeneus and Poseidon (Dragon Theatre) and Twins (PianoFight Productions); 2013's Take Me Home: a One-woman Odyssey (Salon San Carlos, Lucy Tafler Presents, The Edinburgh Fringe Festival); 2014’s Satyr Night Fever (San Francisco Theater Pub), Centaur or The Horse’s Ass (Repurposed Theatre), and The Dryad of Suburbia (PianoFight); 2015’s Cymopoleia or Wave Walker (Pear Avenue Theatre), Christian Teen Dolphin-Sex Beach Party (Awesome Theatre), and Brizo (EXIT Theatre); 2016’s Drumming With Anubis (Left Edge Theatre Company) and Ferryman (Black Sheep Theatre); 2017’s Hedetet (PianoFight). Many have also received additional readings on local and national stages, or other development or workshop opportunities, including: 2010’s Juno En Victoria (Pacific Play Company); 2011’s Joe Ryan (Impact Theatre), Pleiades (Atlantic Stage), Io (Chameleon Theatre Circle), and Selene, or Someone Like The Moon (EXIT Theatre); 2012’s Caeneus and Poseidon (Playwrights’ Center of San Francisco, City Lights Theater), and Twins (San Francisco State, Custom Made Theatre Company); 2013's Under The Gods' Golden Cleats (Dramatist Guild); 2014’s Beauty Secrets (Cutting Ball Theatre Company) and Finding Medusa (Musical Café); 2015’s You’ll Not Feel The Drowning and Oceanus (Custom Made Theatre Company), Ino Leucothea (Red Bull Theatre); 2016’s Ceres En Victoria (The Swedish American Hall), Lethe (Artists at Albatross Reach), Drumming With Anubis (Left Edge Theater Company), and Erinyes/Eumenides (Custom Made Theatre Company). Additionally, 2015’s You’ll Not Feel The Drowning was the recipient of the Custom Made Theatre Company’s New Development Program Workshop in 2017, and 2013's Walls Of Troy was a finalist for the Stanley Drama Award. The entire festival won "Playwriting Series Most Likely to Win a Gold Medal" from the SF Bay Guardian in 2013. EXIT Press has released a collection of five plays from Year One of the festival, Songs of Hestia, and ten plays from Year Two, Heavenly Bodies, both available for purchase on Amazon.com and at bookstores across the country. Steel Spring Stage Rights has published Ino Leucothea as part of Volume IV of Red Bull Shorts. 

Since 2010 the festival has featured the work of 110 Writers, 85 Directors, 447 Actors, and 45 Fine Artists!

This year we are excited to debut 27 new plays by 28 writers, 10 of whom will be contributing written work to the festival for the first time! The plays range from shorts to one-acts and full-lengths, and each one explores a different legend or god from the mythology of Ancient Rome. Though exclusively local in the past, the 2018 festival includes a number of non-Bay Area writers, brought into the festival for the first time to honor the expanding spirit of Rome that built the Roman Roads! This year’s festival also features a serial, created by a team of writers and other artists, played out over eight separate nights!

Why do you need so much money?

Over the years, the festival has grown and shrunk and grown again, adjusting itself to best serve the community it has come from. Though in the past we have raised as much as 12K, this year we're only looking to raise $5,000. 

$3,100 of the money we raise goes to keeping the doors of the theater open, the lights turned on and the water running- all really necessary! So, when you donate to the Festival you're actually also donating to the EXIT Theatre, the cornerstone of San Francisco's small and indie theatre scene. The rest of the money we raise is split three ways...

One third goes to marketing and materials: postcards, posters, programs, high quality printings of the work created by our fine artists, the catering for our opening night party, and of course, all the photocopies of these brand new scripts we need for the readings.

One third goes to paying our staff, which consists of an Art Director who runs the art side of the festival, a Technical Director who keeps the festival moving the nights of the Festival itself, and a Box Office Manager who runs front of house and assists our audiences with having the best possible experience they can when coming to the festival. Our Executive Director/Producer doesn't get paid and donates all his time. Our actors, directors and playwrights are paid from the box office itself each night, something we can do because our administrative staff is paid through gifts from generous benefactors like you! 

The final third of the money raised this year goes to funding an experiment we're doing for the first time: including a multi-discipline, 8 part serial that brings new theater development together with fine art creation, music, movement, and non-traditional storytelling. This work, which is being led by two of San Francisco's most exciting experimental artists, is pushing the boundaries of what the festival can do, and helps keep us a place where artists get to flex their muscles in a way they might not otherwise get to do! 

Perhaps most importantly, if we manage to raise all of our funds, we'll be able to keep our ticket price (which is only $10) low, and our comp policy generous, ensuring that the wide variety of audiences looking to experience these new works can do so affordably.

Okay, but why should I support you?

When you support this festival, you're not just supporting the 32 writers whose work will be presented this year, but also the 80+ actors we predict this festival will use, a dozen directors, and a dozen fine artists, the staff of the festival, and the theater where we work, the theater itself, the neighborhood it is located in, and the cultural life of the city that is our home. Events like the San Francisco Olympians Festival are part of what make the Bay Area a unique and inspiring place to be, a leader in the arts nationally, and a center for intellectual experiment and advancement.

Thank you for giving whatever you can give, for passing this campaign on to others you know who may want to support us, and for helping this festival continue to grow!

Find out more about the festival at www.sfolympians.com.

This year's line up: 

The 2018 festival is 12 nights from October 3rd to the 20th, Wednesday through Saturday, at the EXIT Stage Left Theatre in San Francisco (156 Eddy Street). Tickets are $10.00 at the door, and can be purchased starting at 7:30 the night of the show, or for $12 in advance at Brown Paper Tickets. All shows begin at 8 PM. Audience members who attend more than four nights get the fifth free.

SF OLYMPIANS IX: ROMAN HOLIDAY (10/3-10/20)

Wednesday, October 3: The Way In

JANUS by Ai, Directed by Finn Ware

Thursday, October 4: The Venerable Father

SATURN by John Lamar Elison, Directed by Dan Kurtz

Friday, October 5: Capitoline Triad

JUPITER/JUNO/MINERVA by Laylah Muran de Assereto, Directed by Dan Wilson

Saturday, October 6: The Prodigal Son 

Directed by Sara Judge

MARS by John Lennon Harrison 

CUPID by Jason Mendez 

PSYCHE by Terezi Harrison

Wednesday, October 10: The Legacy

AENEAS by Stuart Bousel, Directed by Alejandro Torres

Thursday, October 11: The Founders

Directed by Juliana Lustenader  

ROMULUS by John Patrick Bray

REMUS or THE FIRE WOLVES by Jessica Chisum

Friday, October 12: The Inheretors

JULIUS CEASAR by Allison Page, Directed by Allison Page  

OCTAVIAN AUGUSTUS by Nic Sommerfeld, Directed by Kieran Beccia

Saturday, October 13: The Origin

VENUS by Christine Keating, Directed by Alessandro McLaughlin

BELLONA by Bridgette Dutta Portman, Directed by Jerome Josephe Gentes

VICTORIA by Annette Roman, Directed by Jerome Josephe Gentes

Wednesday, October 17: The Secret Keeper

VESTA by Veronica Tjioe, Directed by Lily Sorenson

Thursday, October 18: Gods! Gods! Gods!

Directed by Sophia Mia Dipaola

NEPTUNE by Elizabeth Flanagan 

MERCURY by Nicole Jost

APOLLO by Kirk Shimano 

VULCAN by Casey Busher

SOL by Christian Simonsen and Lisa Kee-Hamasaki

QUIRINUS by Eve Edelson

DIS by Maury Zeff

FAUNUS by Meghan Kathleen O'Connor

Friday, October 19: Aventine Triad

CERES/LIBER/LIBERA by Barry Eitel, Directed by Cole Ferraiuolo

Saturday, October 20: The Triple Goddess

Directed by Stuart Bousel

DIANA by Libby Emmons

LUNA by Neil Higgins

TRIVIA by Alan Coyne

AND FOR THE FIRST TIME EVER:

A SERIAL: CLEOPATRA or NOT THAT CLEOPATRA or NOT CLEOPATRA: A SEARCH FOR THE UNKOWABLE QUEEN by Carson Beker and Nara Dahlbacka (With Patricia Reynoso, Cody Rishell, Kitty Torres) Directed by Carson Beker and Nara Dahlbacka, October 3, 4, 5, 10, 11, 12, 17, 19

The entire festival won "Playwriting Series Most Likely to Win a Gold Medal" from the SF Bay Guardian in 2013. EXIT Press has released a collection of five plays from Year One of the festival, Songs of Hestia, and ten plays from Year Two, Heavenly Bodies, both available for purchase on Amazon.com and at bookstores across the country. Steel Spring Stage Rights has published Ino Leucothea as part of Volume IV of Red Bull Shorts. Since 2010 the festival has featured the work of 110 Writers, 85 Directors, 447 Actors, and 45 Fine Artists!This year we are excited to debut 27 new plays by 28 writers, 10 of whom will be contributing written work to the festival for the first time! The plays range from shorts to one-acts and full-lengths, and each one explores a different legend or god from the mythology of Ancient Rome. Though exclusively local in the past, the 2018 festival includes a number of non-Bay Area writers, brought into the festival for the first time to honor the expanding spirit of Rome that built the Roman Roads! This year’s festival also features a serial, created by a team of writers and other artists, played out over eight separate nights!Why do you need so much money?Over the years, the festival has grown and shrunk and grown again, adjusting itself to best serve the community it has come from. Though in the past we have raised as much as 12K, this year we're only looking to raise $5,000. $3,100 of the money we raise goes to keeping the doors of the theater open, the lights turned on and the water running- all really necessary! So, when you donate to the Festival you're actually also donating to the EXIT Theatre, the cornerstone of San Francisco's small and indie theatre scene. The rest of the money we raise is split three ways...One third goes to marketing and materials: postcards, posters, programs, high quality printings of the work created by our fine artists, the catering for our opening night party, and of course, all the photocopies of these brand new scripts we need for the readings.One third goes to paying our staff, which consists of an Art Director who runs the art side of the festival, a Technical Director who keeps the festival moving the nights of the Festival itself, and a Box Office Manager who runs front of house and assists our audiences with having the best possible experience they can when coming to the festival. Our Executive Director/Producer doesn't get paid and donates all his time. Our actors, directors and playwrights are paid from the box office itself each night, something we can do because our administrative staff is paid through gifts from generous benefactors like you! The final third of the money raised this year goes to funding an experiment we're doing for the first time: including a multi-discipline, 8 part serial that brings new theater development together with fine art creation, music, movement, and non-traditional storytelling. This work, which is being led by two of San Francisco's most exciting experimental artists, is pushing the boundaries of what the festival can do, and helps keep us a place where artists get to flex their muscles in a way they might not otherwise get to do! Perhaps most importantly, if we manage to raise all of our funds, we'll be able to keep our ticket price (which is only $10) low, and our comp policy generous, ensuring that the wide variety of audiences looking to experience these new works can do so affordably.Okay, but why should I support you?When you support this festival, you're not just supporting the 32 writers whose work will be presented this year, but also the 80+ actors we predict this festival will use, a dozen directors, and a dozen fine artists, the staff of the festival, and the theater where we work, the theater itself, the neighborhood it is located in, and the cultural life of the city that is our home. Events like the San Francisco Olympians Festival are part of what make the Bay Area a unique and inspiring place to be, a leader in the arts nationally, and a center for intellectual experiment and advancement.Thank you for giving whatever you can give, for passing this campaign on to others you know who may want to support us, and for helping this festival continue to grow!Find out more about the festival at www.sfolympians.com.This year's line up: The 2018 festival is 12 nights from October 3rd to the 20th, Wednesday through Saturday, at the EXIT Stage Left Theatre in San Francisco (156 Eddy Street). Tickets are $10.00 at the door, and can be purchased starting at 7:30 the night of the show, or for $12 in advance at Brown Paper Tickets. All shows begin at 8 PM. Audience members who attend more than four nights get the fifth free.SF OLYMPIANS IX: ROMAN HOLIDAY (10/3-10/20)Wednesday, October 3: The Way InJANUS by Ai, Directed by Finn WareThursday, October 4: The Venerable FatherSATURN by John Lamar Elison, Directed by Dan KurtzFriday, October 5: Capitoline TriadJUPITER/JUNO/MINERVA by Laylah Muran de Assereto, Directed by Dan WilsonSaturday, October 6: The Prodigal Son Directed by Sara JudgeMARS by John Lennon Harrison CUPID by Jason Mendez PSYCHE by Terezi HarrisonWednesday, October 10: The LegacyAENEAS by Stuart Bousel, Directed by Alejandro TorresThursday, October 11: The FoundersDirected by Juliana Lustenader  ROMULUS by John Patrick BrayREMUS or THE FIRE WOLVES by Jessica ChisumFriday, October 12: The InheretorsJULIUS CEASAR by Allison Page, Directed by Allison Page  OCTAVIAN AUGUSTUS by Nic Sommerfeld, Directed by Kieran BecciaSaturday, October 13: The OriginVENUS by Christine Keating, Directed by Alessandro McLaughlinBELLONA by Bridgette Dutta Portman, Directed by Jerome Josephe GentesVICTORIA by Annette Roman, Directed by Jerome Josephe GentesWednesday, October 17: The Secret KeeperVESTA by Veronica Tjioe, Directed by Lily SorensonThursday, October 18: Gods! Gods! Gods!Directed by Sophia Mia DipaolaNEPTUNE by Elizabeth Flanagan MERCURY by Nicole JostAPOLLO by Kirk Shimano VULCAN by Casey BusherSOL by Christian Simonsen and Lisa Kee-HamasakiQUIRINUS by Eve EdelsonDIS by Maury ZeffFAUNUS by Meghan Kathleen O'ConnorFriday, October 19: Aventine TriadCERES/LIBER/LIBERA by Barry Eitel, Directed by Cole FerraiuoloSaturday, October 20: The Triple GoddessDirected by Stuart BouselDIANA by Libby EmmonsLUNA by Neil HigginsTRIVIA by Alan CoyneAND FOR THE FIRST TIME EVER:A SERIAL: CLEOPATRA or NOT THAT CLEOPATRA or NOT CLEOPATRA: A SEARCH FOR THE UNKOWABLE QUEEN by Carson Beker and Nara Dahlbacka (With Patricia Reynoso, Cody Rishell, Kitty Torres) Directed by Carson Beker and Nara Dahlbacka, October 3, 4, 5, 10, 11, 12, 17, 19

story:
HERE'S WHAT WE'RE ABOUT:

Mitch and Murray Productions is a new Vancouver theatre company with a mandate to present west coast premieres of plays from Canada and around the world.   Our focus is on intimate, gritty, realistic, character-driven comedy/drama with small casts, focusing on modern relationships as a reflection of the world at large.  Our mission is to stage these works in unconventional aesthetic ways, while attracting new audience members to the theatre.  

In 2009, the company staged the Vancouver premiere of Neil Labute's "Fat Pig" at Performance Works in Vancouver.  The play was nominated for three Jessie Richardson awards and it attracted several packed houses.

Our next production is the Vancouver premiere of Michael Weller's "Fifty Words", Michael Weller's haunting new play detailing one night in the life of a married couple, alone for the first time in years as their son is at his first sleepover.  The play goes on an emotional roller coaster and never gets off for the full 90 minutes, examining every beautiful and ugly detail of a troubled marriage.  It will be directed by Jessie Award winner John Murphy and it features Vancouver actors Kirsten Robek and Aaron Craven.  The design team includes the brilliant Itai Erdal and Naomi Sider.  The play runs October 25th - November 5th at the Vancouver East Cultural Centre Culture Lab.

We'll be staging the play in the intimate confines of The Culture Lab and our concept is hyper-realism.  That is, you as the audience will be walking into a set which is completely non-theatrical.  Every light, every bit of food cooking, every prop will be real and functioning.  As you watch the two characters descend into a most unexpected night, you will smell the cooking and literally be on top of the action as if you were a fly on the wall of the living room.  This is what theatre can do!

WHY WE NEED YOU:

The theatre scene in Vancouver has been devastated by public arts funding cuts, plain and simple.  As a young emerging theatre company, we are finding innovative ways to engage audiences and raise money privately. You, the individual, are both our audience member and our lifeblood, which is why we strive to produce work which appeals to audiences on a universal level while pushing the boundaries of what theatre can be as an entertainment experience.

When you see a play, you sit in a theatre with a relatively small group of people and you connect to something that you are very much involved in.  Your reactions - your laughter, your tears, your applause, they have the ability to change the dynamics of that particular performance.  No two performances are exactly the same, and as an audience member, you are part of an experience that is completely unique to that moment, that is vital and that is very much alive in front of your eyes.

When we buy "limited edition" clothing, wine, paraphernalia, etc, we feel a bit of an extra buzz as we feel we have purchased something rare or special.  When you invest in theatre, you are buying into something that is always limited edition, captured only by the eyes and the minds of that night's audience.


WHAT YOU GET OUT OF IT:

For our upcoming production of "Fifty Words", our funding goal for individuals investing on this site is $3000.  We are purposeful in our use of the term "investing".  We are not asking for help for a charity.  We think of it as investing in a young, energetic company that will involve you not only as audience members but in other means of audience outreach.

Funders on this site, staring at an investment of only $5, will automatically be entered in our monthly prize draws and will be listed as a patron on the site. You will have the opportunity to comment on our fundraising campaign as well as be involved in the goings on of our show through all of it's production phases, including a website blog and audience feedback page. Higher levels of contribution will receive mention in the playbill, discounted tickets, sponsor prize packages, dinner for two, wine and much more!  We have received amazing support from the business community in the form of in kind donations - all as an incentive for you to support our fundraising drive.

Prizes include one night's stay at The Sakinaw Lake Lodge, dinners for two, free tickets to the show and much more!

We will also be organizing a wide-ranging audience outreach campaign, including a contest associated with the production.  Because the play is, at its core, about love, we plan to do a play on words with our title and start a contest related to our production.  People will have the chance to email us and use "fifty words" or less to describe love.  Any form will be accepted - poetry, prose, stream of consciousness, personal anecdotes, etc.  The winner will win free tickets to the show as well as a prize package from our participating sponsors.  At the theatre itself, the lobby will be plastered with the best letters we receive from participants.  This is the type of creative marketing that we believe local theatre is in need of.!

Invest what you can, ultimately.  You might think of it as a drop in the bucket, but if we get a lot of drops, we'll have a bucket.  Your support will mean the world to our company as we look to gain a further foothold in the city's arts scene.

You can also invest anonymously on this site or by sending a cheque to:

Mitch and Murray Productions   /  #910-525 Seymour Street; Vancouver, BC;   V6B 3H7


If you'd like to sponsor business in exchange for ad space on our website and promotional materials, please get in touch - contact info is below.

Thank you for your support and we'll see you at the show!

www.mitchandmurrayproductions.com

story:
SHORT SUMMARY

THE QUIET CLOCK is a new children’s musical with exciting and colorful characters; wonderful fun, up-beat songs, and great moral lessons! 

THE QUIET CLOCK, based on the book by Britt Nichols, is a charming chlidren’s tale of a young inventor who invents an alarm clock that does not ring. 

Close your eyes, think of it, imagine the sound
of a clock so silent, no sound could be found.
No bleeping, no blurping, no ringing of bells,
no senseless loud noises, no scary loud yells,
not one single sound that could disrupt your sleep,
not even a pin drop, not one little beep.

With melodies based on Swiss children’s songs, comical scenarios, and delightful rhyming characters this show has been called, “Terrifically created for kids of all ages,” by Broadway Musical Director, Lynn Crigler; and “Smart, charming and absolutely adorable,” by Off-Broadway producer, Jared Hershkowitz.

There is no big surprise
that we would all like to rise
to a clock that doesn't just jolt us awake.
And in this whimsical show,
all kids will learn and will know,
so much more from what the clockmaker makes.

For a full description of the show synopsis, please consider visiting the website at: www.quietclockthemusical.com.

A2K Productions, LLC is a theatre and film production company based in New York City.  Founded by Adam Karsten and Karen Sieber in 2005 they have been involved in theatre and film productions from Broadway to PBS (www.A2KProductions.com).

Weathervane Playhouse is Ohio’s longest running professional, non-proft, summer stock theatre (www.weathervaneplayhouse.org).  Weathervane had it's birth in a barn in Heath, Ohio, July 8, 1969, opening with a most appropriate musical, Good News!. From the first moment, Licking County's professional summer theater grew in the hearts and minds of the local community. As a tremendous supporter of Children’s Theatre through its continuing theatre education program (Weathervane Young Artist Repertory Theatre-WYART), Weathervane is proud to be part of this new production.

With your help A2K Productions and Weathervane Playhouse can produce this new Children’s Musical in October of 2013 at a designated Off-Broadway theatre in New York City.

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

Producing a quality musical, even a children's musical, in New York City is expensive.  The funding raised by this campaign will cover some of the rehearsal costs and theatre rental.  But most importantly, the money you give will go to opportunities for children of all ages to experience the joy of live theatre. 

We are committed to producing the highest quality production of this children's musical.  With your help, children can enjoy a stylish, exciting theatrical experience of genuine worth.

A breakdown of our costs for production can be found below: 

 
Physical Production Cost
Scenery $2,000
Costumes $2,000
Lighting $2,000
Props $1,000
Salaries  
Actors $2,000 (est. $14,000 total)
Understudies $1,200
Stage Management $1,200
Rehearsal Expenses  
Rehearsal Space (rental) $500 (two weeks)
Theater Rental  
Theater Space $12,000 (22 perfs)
Box Office $100 (per show)
Programs $20 (per show)
Advertising/Marketing  
Advertisement/Marketing $1,800
General Admin  
Insurance $250
Total $38,570

 

With your donation you get the knowledge and the gratification of improving the lives of hundreds, if not thousands of young people.  Our goal is to genuinely produce a high quality theatrical event that can be enjoyed by children of all ages.

THE IMPACT

Theatre offers people the values of genuine creativity, expressiveness, unity, emotional growth, imagination, musicality, moral ethics and the recognition of true human nature.  It offers a new perception on life and should certainly not be denied to children.  Helping us reach our goals for THE QUIET CLOCK musical will give children of all ages the opportunity to recognize some of these benefits.

The creative team for THE QUIET CLOCK musical believes that we are creating a real value for the future of children.  It offers them multiple ways to learn; from the book, the music, and the additional moral lessons in the expanded musical.

Any and each contribution gives you the comfort of providing learning and growing opportunities to today’s children.
