story:
Our Story

Chasing the Wind is ultimately a story of self-discovery. Solomon, a slave to his pretty gruesome past (sibling murder, incest, rape and failed coup d'ètat) feels trapped in his privileged yet highly dysfunctional surroundings. He wants to find his own way. He wants to find meaning and a sense of destiny. He wants to feel alive. In our privilege, we are taught very early on to pursue our dreams and ultimately to pursue our happiness. But where has it gotten us? Where is life found? As we engage in Solomon’s story, perhaps we enter into our own. His story is our story. His story matters. So his story must be told. With your help and support, we can tell our story. 

Where Are Your Donations Going? 

The process of developing a musical happens in stages. One would think a group of talented enthusiastic writers come up with an idea, write it, find skilled actors, and off they go to Broadway! Even the best of shows are not developed this way. In fact, many of the greatest musicals tend to take more time and undergo more phases.

The next developmental stage for Chasing the Wind is an orchestrated Concert Reading of the full show where we can invite higher-ups who can move our musical along. But the cost of this type of performance is high. We have to cover the fees, travel and lodging for a cast of at least 12 actors; the fees for the musicians in the orchestra; the Music Director and Director, Stage Manager, Audio Engineer, printing fees, and orchestrations. The cost of the venue for the performance as well as rehearsal space alone can be very expensive. Even on a tight budget, it all adds up very quickly.

$25,000 will allow us to have a high caliber performance so that we may pitch Chasing the Wind to agents, theaters, and producers who can take our show to the next stage of development. If we go beyond our goal, we will make a professional studio recording of one or two of the songs which would help greatly with promotion.

The Cast

André McRae - Composer & Lyricist
André McRae, a native of Philadelphia PA, is the proud winner of the Oxnard Gold Award in the American Traditions Competition, a competition celebrating the diversity of American music. He took home the top prize singing Operatic repertoire and Musical theatre songs. André is no stranger to being awarded for his talents. He received scholarships for all three of his degrees at the Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music (BM, MM, and an Artists' Diploma in Opera).

André quickly began performing upon graduating from the Conservatory, in theaters all around the country scoring the lead in Ragtime, Joe in Showboat, and principal roles in Smokey Joe’s Café, Dreamgirls, Godspell among others. He also toured Europe and Japan in Porgy and Bess. McRae has been a featured soloist and performer with the National Symphony Orchestra, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, the Cleveland Pops Orchestra and The Broadway Concert Series, Encores! at New York City Center.
 



Melvin Tunstall III - King Solomon 
A graduate of the acclaimed Musical Theater Program at the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music, Melvin is currently appearing in the Broadway smash hit Beautiful: the Carole King Musical and has been seen internationally in the original Toronto company of Rock of Ages, and the new European Tour Cast of Ain't Misbehavin. Other professional credits include Judas in Jesus Christ Superstar, Flick in Violet, Jim in Big River and Victor in Smokey Joe's Cafe. Also a budding writer/director, Melvin wrote the book to the TYA phenomenon Polkadots and continues to work on his newest project Higgins in Harlem: a new Pygmalion in New York City.



Carolyn Cole - Queen of Sheba
SIGNATURE: Hairspray (2012 Helen Hayes Award), Spin, Company, Tina GirlStar! (reading), Hello, Dolly! (Ford’s Theatre co-production, 2013 Helen Hayes Award); OFF-BROADWAY: The New Hopeville Comics; a rock opera. NATIONAL TOUR: Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat (with Donny Osmond), Martha Speaks. REGIONAL/DC AREA: The Mikado, The Stephen Schwartz Project, You’re a Good Man Charlie Brown, Women of the Blues. CABARETS/CONCERTS/BENEFITS: Carolyn in the City, Monday Nights New Voices, An Evening with Carolyn Cole, Born to Take the BELTway, Carolyn Cole: The Farewell Tour (Live CD Recording).
 



Awa Sal Secka - Abby
REGIONAL: ArtsCentric: MEMPHIS (Felicia Farrell). Signature Theatre: Jesus Christ Superstar (Simon, King Herod u/s), U.G.L.Y. workshop. Round House Theatre: Caroline, or Change ( Dottie Moffet. Theatre Alliance: Black Nativity (Narrator/Elder). Creative Cauldron: Chasing the Wind (Abby), Caroline, or Change (Washing machine/Moon). Mosaic Theatre: Eretz Chadasha: The Promised Land (Mother). ATMTC: James and the Giant Peach (Aunt Sponge). Studio Theatre: SILENCE! The Musical (Ardelia). Olney Theatre: Avenue Q (Ensemble/female swing). NATIONAL TOUR: BIG NATE the Musical (Ms. Godfrey/Nate's sister). UPCOMING: Signature: Gun and Powderworkshop. Kennedy Center: Me...Jane (As Cast). Ford’s Theatre: The Wiz (Ensemble/ Dorothy u/s). Olney Theatre: On the Town (As Cast). A.A. in Theatre Performance from Montgomery College.




Sue Gaukel - Haggith
Susan has been a professional performer, teacher, director and vocal/theatre coach for over 20 years. She earned her MFA in Musical Theatre Performance from the Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music and is currently Assistant Professor of Musical Theatre Direction at Shorter University. Susan has performed professionally in various cities such as New York City, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, and Tacoma. Favorite roles include Mother in Ragtime, Roxanne in Cyrano the Musical, Florence Vassy in Chess, Eva Peron in Evita and Audrey in Little Shop of Horrors. She trained with Sara Louise Lazarus, ( New York City) Paul Gemignani, Victor Garber, (Manhattan School of Music PMTW) and Dona Vaughn and Maitland Peters ( Manhattan School of Music NYC), among others. Susan also writes and performs cabarets which she has performed or directed in Cincinnati and the Seattle area. Susan’s very favorite roles however, are being the wife of her wonderful husband and mother to her amazing daughter.
 



Christian Hoff - Nijah
Christian Hoff is a tenor in The U.S. Army Chorus. He is a graduate of the University of Maryland, earning his bachelor degree in vocal performance under the tutelage of Gran Wilson. As a member of the UMD Chamber Singers, Christian has performed major choral symphonic works such as Handel's Messiah, Britten's War Requiem and Brahms' German Requiem, in collaboration with the NSO and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra. Christian recently performed the lead role of Eddie Birdlace in Pasak and Paul's "Dogfight" with the Red Branch Theatre Company. He has also performed the role of Tobias Ragg in Stephen Sondheim's Sweeney Todd as a member of the Janiec Opera Company at the Brevard Music Center. Christian has most recently performed as a tenor soloist with the U.S. Army Chorus at venues such as The White House, The U.S. Capitol and the Pentagon. 
 

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.

Firstly, thank you so much for taking the time to read our page and watch our video! In fact we are so thankful, we have decided to assign every level of giving a special "Thank you" in a different language! We are so excited to bring Chasing The Wind to the world. Please consider donating as you are able, any amount is appreciated. If you cannot donate at this time, please share this campaign with your friends and family. 

For more information, contact ctwthemusical@gmail.com.

Thank you for your support.
André McRae
story_txt: Our StoryChasing the Wind is ultimately a story of self-discovery. Solomon, a slave to his pretty gruesome past (sibling murder, incest, rape and failed coup d'ètat) feels trapped in his privileged yet highly dysfunctional surroundings. He wants to find his own way. He wants to find meaning and a sense of destiny. He wants to feel alive. In our privilege, we are taught very early on to pursue our dreams and ultimately to pursue our happiness. But where has it gotten us? Where is life found? As we engage in Solomon’s story, perhaps we enter into our own. His story is our story. His story matters. So his story must be told. With your help and support, we can tell our story. Where Are Your Donations Going? The process of developing a musical happens in stages. One would think a group of talented enthusiastic writers come up with an idea, write it, find skilled actors, and off they go to Broadway! Even the best of shows are not developed this way. In fact, many of the greatest musicals tend to take more time and undergo more phases.The next developmental stage for Chasing the Wind is an orchestrated Concert Reading of the full show where we can invite higher-ups who can move our musical along. But the cost of this type of performance is high. We have to cover the fees, travel and lodging for a cast of at least 12 actors; the fees for the musicians in the orchestra; the Music Director and Director, Stage Manager, Audio Engineer, printing fees, and orchestrations. The cost of the venue for the performance as well as rehearsal space alone can be very expensive. Even on a tight budget, it all adds up very quickly.$25,000 will allow us to have a high caliber performance so that we may pitch Chasing the Wind to agents, theaters, and producers who can take our show to the next stage of development. If we go beyond our goal, we will make a professional studio recording of one or two of the songs which would help greatly with promotion.The CastAndré McRae - Composer & LyricistAndré McRae, a native of Philadelphia PA, is the proud winner of the Oxnard Gold Award in the American Traditions Competition, a competition celebrating the diversity of American music. He took home the top prize singing Operatic repertoire and Musical theatre songs. André is no stranger to being awarded for his talents. He received scholarships for all three of his degrees at the Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music (BM, MM, and an Artists' Diploma in Opera).André quickly began performing upon graduating from the Conservatory, in theaters all around the country scoring the lead in Ragtime, Joe in Showboat, and principal roles in Smokey Joe’s Café, Dreamgirls, Godspell among others. He also toured Europe and Japan in Porgy and Bess. McRae has been a featured soloist and performer with the National Symphony Orchestra, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra, the Cleveland Pops Orchestra and The Broadway Concert Series, Encores! at New York City Center. Melvin Tunstall III - King Solomon A graduate of the acclaimed Musical Theater Program at the Cincinnati Conservatory of Music, Melvin is currently appearing in the Broadway smash hit Beautiful: the Carole King Musical and has been seen internationally in the original Toronto company of Rock of Ages, and the new European Tour Cast of Ain't Misbehavin. Other professional credits include Judas in Jesus Christ Superstar, Flick in Violet, Jim in Big River and Victor in Smokey Joe's Cafe. Also a budding writer/director, Melvin wrote the book to the TYA phenomenon Polkadots and continues to work on his newest project Higgins in Harlem: a new Pygmalion in New York City.Carolyn Cole - Queen of ShebaSIGNATURE: Hairspray (2012 Helen Hayes Award), Spin, Company, Tina GirlStar! (reading), Hello, Dolly! (Ford’s Theatre co-production, 2013 Helen Hayes Award); OFF-BROADWAY: The New Hopeville Comics; a rock opera. NATIONAL TOUR: Joseph and the Amazing Technicolor Dreamcoat (with Donny Osmond), Martha Speaks. REGIONAL/DC AREA: The Mikado, The Stephen Schwartz Project, You’re a Good Man Charlie Brown, Women of the Blues. CABARETS/CONCERTS/BENEFITS: Carolyn in the City, Monday Nights New Voices, An Evening with Carolyn Cole, Born to Take the BELTway, Carolyn Cole: The Farewell Tour (Live CD Recording). Awa Sal Secka - AbbyREGIONAL: ArtsCentric: MEMPHIS (Felicia Farrell). Signature Theatre: Jesus Christ Superstar (Simon, King Herod u/s), U.G.L.Y. workshop. Round House Theatre: Caroline, or Change ( Dottie Moffet. Theatre Alliance: Black Nativity (Narrator/Elder). Creative Cauldron: Chasing the Wind (Abby), Caroline, or Change (Washing machine/Moon). Mosaic Theatre: Eretz Chadasha: The Promised Land (Mother). ATMTC: James and the Giant Peach (Aunt Sponge). Studio Theatre: SILENCE! The Musical (Ardelia). Olney Theatre: Avenue Q (Ensemble/female swing). NATIONAL TOUR: BIG NATE the Musical (Ms. Godfrey/Nate's sister). UPCOMING: Signature: Gun and Powderworkshop. Kennedy Center: Me...Jane (As Cast). Ford’s Theatre: The Wiz (Ensemble/ Dorothy u/s). Olney Theatre: On the Town (As Cast). A.A. in Theatre Performance from Montgomery College.Sue Gaukel - HaggithSusan has been a professional performer, teacher, director and vocal/theatre coach for over 20 years. She earned her MFA in Musical Theatre Performance from the Cincinnati College-Conservatory of Music and is currently Assistant Professor of Musical Theatre Direction at Shorter University. Susan has performed professionally in various cities such as New York City, Philadelphia, Cincinnati, and Tacoma. Favorite roles include Mother in Ragtime, Roxanne in Cyrano the Musical, Florence Vassy in Chess, Eva Peron in Evita and Audrey in Little Shop of Horrors. She trained with Sara Louise Lazarus, ( New York City) Paul Gemignani, Victor Garber, (Manhattan School of Music PMTW) and Dona Vaughn and Maitland Peters ( Manhattan School of Music NYC), among others. Susan also writes and performs cabarets which she has performed or directed in Cincinnati and the Seattle area. Susan’s very favorite roles however, are being the wife of her wonderful husband and mother to her amazing daughter. Christian Hoff - NijahChristian Hoff is a tenor in The U.S. Army Chorus. He is a graduate of the University of Maryland, earning his bachelor degree in vocal performance under the tutelage of Gran Wilson. As a member of the UMD Chamber Singers, Christian has performed major choral symphonic works such as Handel's Messiah, Britten's War Requiem and Brahms' German Requiem, in collaboration with the NSO and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra. Christian recently performed the lead role of Eddie Birdlace in Pasak and Paul's "Dogfight" with the Red Branch Theatre Company. He has also performed the role of Tobias Ragg in Stephen Sondheim's Sweeney Todd as a member of the Janiec Opera Company at the Brevard Music Center. Christian has most recently performed as a tenor soloist with the U.S. Army Chorus at venues such as The White House, The U.S. Capitol and the Pentagon.  Thank you. Thank you. Thank you.Firstly, thank you so much for taking the time to read our page and watch our video! In fact we are so thankful, we have decided to assign every level of giving a special "Thank you" in a different language! We are so excited to bring Chasing The Wind to the world. Please consider donating as you are able, any amount is appreciated. If you cannot donate at this time, please share this campaign with your friends and family. For more information, contact ctwthemusical@gmail.com.Thank you for your support.André McRae

story:
About COCO Dance Festival

The Contemporary Choreographers’ Collective (COCO) is a Trinidad and Tobago based organization which presents an annual dance festival, thereby providing a platform of innovation, experimentation and excellence in the world of contemporary dance for emerging and established choreographers in the region.  In the past, we've hosted the contemporary works of our Caribbean brothers and sisters, including works from Barbados choreographers. We plan to present our ninth installment of COCO from October 27th to October 29th, 2017 in Port of Spain.

 

ABOUT CARIFESTA

Established in 1972 among Caribbean nations, CARIFESTA (the Caribbean Festival of the Arts) aims to bring together various aspects of performing and visual culture of the Caribbean region. It's a prime space to share cultural experiences and to learn about each others' artistic practices.

COCO has been invited to perform at CARIFESTA – hosted by Barbados this year. We plan to present the work of two Trinidad and Tobago choreographers, encompassing fourteen dancers. We are funding a large part of this ourselves (and we thank CARIFESTA for their invitation and assistance), but we need you to help us get to the finish line!

story:
Help fund A Streetcare Named Desire -- our new IndieGoGo campaign for our January production!


Thanks to everyone who contributed and to those that came out to see Alcestis!

Our first IndieGoGo campaign is over -- but we'll be back.  In the meantime, if you'd like to support The Tampa Repertory Theatre, please go to our website:  www.tamparep.org, and click the button to donate through Fractured Atlas.


Thanks, again.


C. David Frankel

Artistic Director

The Tampa Repertory Theatre



The Tampa Repertory Theatre hits the stage with Euripides’ Alcestis

Who We Are

Tampa Rep joins a vibrant and growing theatre community in Tampa, Florida.  We will offer plays and musicals from the full spectrum of theatre, from the earliest plays – we’re starting with the Greeks – to contemporary musicals and dramas (and lots in between).  We’re also committed to bringing more classical American theatre to Tampa, from O’Neill to Williams, and beyond.  Our goal is to utilize the finest theatrical talent in the area, and to create a permanent presence here in Tampa.  But to achieve that goal, we need your help.

What We’re Doing

Our first production, Euripides’ Alcestis, directed by Megan Lamasney, fresh from her exciting production of Disco Pigs, is up and running, and winning praise from the audience:


  • "We thoroughly enjoyed the production. Thanks again." Travis Ann Sherman
  • "Excellent production and an auspicious beginning!"  Bill Zewadski
  • "Great play!"  Mia Sadler
  • "The play was just what was to be expected...every married couple needs to see it!   We enjoyed it completely!"  April Rose


The production plays in the Studio Theatre at HCC Ybor, Performing Arts Building at the corner of E Palm Ave. and N. Avenida Republica de Cuba (11th Avenue), Tampa‎ FL‎ 33605, from July 8-24 (8 performances left!).  We need backers to support this production, and to lay the foundations for our future.  Your help will go toward:


  • The Studio Theatre rental cost for Alcestis
  • Production expenses for costumes, sets, props, etc.
  • Marketing costs such as programs, posters, and so on
  • Support the the actors, designers, and technicians of the production


What You Get

We’ve got some premium gifts listed in the sidebar – not available anywhere else!  You can make a donation now, through IndieGoGo, or by going to our website (www.tamparep.org) and clicking on the donation link. The Tampa Repertory Theatre is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Tampa Rep must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.   

What Else You Can Do

Help us even more by spreading the word about the Tampa Repertory Theatre and our production of Alcestis.  Better yet, come see Alcestis – and bring some friends. (If you can't come, "buy" a virtual ticket -- one of our custom perks.)

story:
GREAT NEWS!  

Through a number of generous offline donations, we have raised our total to just under $25,000, bringing us within reach of our funding goal!

Your support means everything to this project - please help us get to Norway by making a donation or sharing this campaign!

COME TO NORWAY WITH THE PEER GYNT PROJECT

Please help!  We just found out that The Peer Gynt Project has been selected to present at the International Ibsen Festival in Norway. 

This is the first time that we have the opprtunity to present our work to the public and to bring UK based and wheel-chair using lead actor Neil Hancock to Norway.

Please help us get there - and experience a piece of the journey yourself!

About The Peer Gynt Project:

Sponsored by the Royal Norwegian Consulate General in New York and the Nationaltheatret in Oslo, the Peer Gynt Project is a Norwegian/UK/US multi-media production conceived by Caroline von Kuhn and now being developed in collaboration with Jennifer Gibbs and John Gould Rubin, Produced by Robyn Hussa.  

This multi-media conflation of Ibsen’s Peer Gynt with modern transcriptions, texts and recordings proposes the corollary between Peer’s struggle to find his identity in a world more tempered and inhibiting than he can tolerate, and our Peer: Wheel-chair using, British actor Neil Hancock’s pursuit of an acting career despite his physical handicap.

We have been granted the incredible opportunity to unite our international cast and creative team in a rigorous workshop that is integral to the future development and staged performance of this project.

Our Invitation to You:

As a supporter of this project, we invite you to embark on this incredible journey with us.

$30,000 will help cover our team's travel costs and housing in Norway.

Your travel partners:

Neil Hancock (lead actor - Peer Gynt) is a UK based actor. $5000 helps cover airfare and lodging.  $2500 will pay for the rental of his wheelchair in Oslo.

Jennifer Gibbs (co-creator) is a New York based playwright and performer.  $3000 buys her a plane ticket to Norway and covers housing for the workshop.

John Gould Rubin (co-creator) is an admired New York based theatre director and teacher. $3000 buys him a plane ticket to Norway and covers housing for the workshop.

Caroline von Khun is a New York based theatre and film director and producer. $3000 buys her a plane ticket to Norway and covers housing for the workshop.

Additional funds help cover ground transportation in Norway and travel and accomodation for our other collaborators.

You: Become a donor and become part of the journey.  Donate $25 and you will receive a credit on our wesite. $50 buys a postcard signed by Neil - a giimpse into the world of Peer Gynt. $5000 and we will video conference you into our exclusive workshop sessions.  $15000 and you can experience it all with us...

What Your Pledge Means

In order to get to the Ibsen Festival in Oslo this August, we need to raise $30,000.  Collectively we have almost 12,000 miles to travel.  That means that for every $2.50 raised we get one mile closer to our goal.

If we do not reach out goal for this summer, all donations will go towards making the trip at a later date within a year from now.

Other Ways You Can Help

Every dollar helps, but is you cannot give, please consider sharing this campaign with a friend and posting it to your networks.  We appreicate your support and will continue to share our adventures with you!

story:
Short Summary

Bad Idea Productions is a theatre production company started by Joseph Cunningham and Chris Cartwright. The two decided to submit a play to the 2014 Minnesota Fringe Festival, and it got accepted! Their play, "The Five Thousand" is a satirical comedy which tells the story of a small, struggling, all-male theatre troupe trying to survive amidst a bunch of new changes.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to produce this show however, we need your financial support! Because we are just two high-schoolers producing a show downtown, we don't have enough money on our own to make it happen. Costs include venue rental fees, production fees, script production/distribution fees, props/costume costs, etc. With your support, even if it's just a donation of $1, it will help us immensely, so that we can put on a fabulous show!

So what do YOU get by donating? Depending on how much you donate, you could get anything from name recognition on our website and program to free tickets to future EVHS theatre productions! Check out the "perks" on the right-hand side.

Why It Is Important To Us

Chris Cartwright, the director, has had experience in directing since 2012, when he assistant directed 2 productions at a middle school in the south metro. More recently, Chris has assistant directed productions at Eastview including Almost, Maine, and Legally Blonde: The Musical, earning him the 2013 Hennepin Theatre Trust Spotlight Award for Outstanding Student Direction. He just finished directing a one-act play that he wrote, called Awaiting Patients. Joseph Cunningham has been writing plays, musicals, and screenplays for the past several years as well. This will be Joseph's first play to be professionally produced! With Chris and Joe's creative backgrounds and passions, this project means a whole lot to the both of them, and they are excited to produce it!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support as financially right now, don't worry about it! There are other ways you can help out:

  • Spread the word - tell your friends, neighbors, family members, fellow theatre-goers and supporters of the arts!
  • Attend our play, which will be performed August 3rd-9th at the New Century Theatre in Minneapolis, MN.

story:
We didn't know Cincinnati had improv either.

For too long, Cincinnati's brave improv artists have struggled in the shadows, dealing with blank, puzzled expressions when they tell people they improvise, yes really, yes right here.  Well, no more.  From now on with the people that love and support them, they will spread the message that Cincinnati is a great place for improv.

How we spread that message:

It is time for Cincinnati to host an improv festival.  And it will.  On Sept 12th and 13th, 2014 at the Know Theatre in Over the Rhine, performers from across the country and your hometown favorites will be performing two nights of improv.  With a day of workshops in between, this is going to be huge.  Get on board now.  You can say you knew us when.  And we will agree, because we are really bad with names. 

We need your help to spread the message:

  • Your money goes toward the cost of bringing in nationally known performers
  • Nationally known performers will bring more attention to the festival
  • More attention to the festival means more attention to the city
  • Therefore, your money is going to show off our city (because Aristotle says so) 
  • Oh, and we have t-shirts

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this page on your social media
  • Email the campaign page info to your friends
  • Talk about it at family dinner
  • Threaten to quit unless your boss and all your coworkers support it
  • Most of all, be creative and overdramatic
  • indiegogo has sharing tools (at the top of the page, just below the video) to make all this easier

This is the campaign which helped us to produce our first, award-winning production of Henry V! It is now closed. Thank you so much for your support!

We are now campaigning as a NON-PROFIT!

Our campaign is live at http://www.igg.me/at/newfortune

Thank you!

story:
Our Story

Christina Giannelli, Founder of Dance Source Houston, began producing Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance seventeen years ago in an effort to boost both the quality and profile of contemporary dance seen in Houston.  She created a platform to showcase 8-10 small to medium sized contemporary dance companies each year in front of a very broad and diverse audience.  Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance takes place each September at Miller Outdoor Theatre, a world class outdoor venue dedicated to presenting quality performing arts performances in Houston. Every event at Miller Outdoor Theatre is FREE, thereby granting access to great art to those without the means to purchase a ticket.  


In order to get a spot on the program for Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance,  individual choreographers, dance artists and dance companies from anywhere in Texas must apply and submit a video of the work they want to see produced.  Dance Source Houston assembles a curatorial committee to review the applications and select a program that accurately represents the breadth and high caliber of contemporary dance in Texas.  


This year, Dance Source Houston is happy to present the following companies for the 17th Annual Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance on September 23rd and 24th.


Ad Deum Dance Company

Earthen Vessels/Sandra Organ Dance Company

HIStory

Houston Metropolitan Dance Company

Infinite Movement Ever Evolving

Psophonia

Vault

Choreographer Ashley Horn

The Impact


Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance makes an impact in both the dance community and general populations of Houston.  For the dance community, it is an opportunity to perform on a world class stage, in front of an audience that doesn't often attend contemporary dance.  And most importantly it is an opportunity for them to get paid.  

Most of the dance companies performing in Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance rarely get a chance to dance on a stage of the quality of Miller Outdoor Theatre and rarely dance in front of such a large and diverse crowd.  It is an unfortunate fact as well, that dancers of small to medium size contemporary dance companies frequently do their job without getting paid.  Many are forced to work in other jobs, in other fields in order to support their time in the studio and on the stage.  Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance is one of the few showcase events where the companies involved know they will be compensated for their work. 

What We Need & What You Get

Although all the events at Miller Outdoor Theatre are free to attend, they are not free to produce.  One of our biggest expenditures are the fees we pay to the artists and companies to perform and that is what we're asking for your help with.  Our goal is $3,000 which is close to half of what we need to cover the artist fees.  Every penny we raise through this campaign will go directly to paying the artists for their craft. 


Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance is the single biggest program that Dance Source Houston produces.  It represents a huge portion of our budget. We believe strongly in paying artists for their work and will pay all the companies/artists the full amount we have contracted with them.  However, not meeting our fundraising goal will mean using funds intended for other programs and activities essential to the Houston dance community.  This will place a great strain on our organization.  Your support will help ensure that the artists performing at Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance are properly compensated and that the rest of Dance Source Houston's programming  will continue as planned.


Beyond our enduring gratitude and the warm fuzzies you'll feel for supporting dance, we've set up a few perks for you.  All the details can be found on the right. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with your friends and family on Facebook and Twitter!  We don't have a lot of time and the more you can help us spread the word, the more likely we are to reach our goal!


And put Weekend of Texas Contemporary Dance on your calendar!  Plan to bring your friends and family, bring a picnic (or donate $50 and we'll provide the picnic) and join us to celebrate dance!  We hope to see you there!

story:
Our Story

As a group of Houston's High School for the Performing and Visual Arts juniors and seniors, we want to take on responsibility for creating our own theater to share with our community. Our beginnings as a production company originated this past August when, through solely student efforts, we produced Rabbit Hole by David Lindsay-Abaire. Always looking for more and more ways to express our style of art, we have decided to put on David Auburn's fantastic show Proof. We strive to give artistic opportunities that may not always be available to our age group, and to create entertaining and engaging theater for our community to enjoy.


The Impact

Proceeds of this campaign to support the production of Proof will allow us to afford more extensive scenery and costumes, as well as pay for the printing of posters and flyers and other forms of advertisement. 


All profit from this show, once all of the fees from this production have been paid, will go towards the National MS Society and help fund their own efforts towards researching cures for multiple sclerosis.


What We Need & What You Get

The $1500 dollars we hope to raise through this campaign would go towards making this production a reality. Expenses include a performance space, technical elements to add to the production, advertisement, and acquiring legal rights to the show.


Those who donate any amount have our undying gratitude and thanks for supporting our endeavor and, in turn, a charitable and noble cause. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Through our production we hope to plant the idea in people of all ages everywhere that they are able to make their own art, that their imagination is the limit. With your help and support, this idea can travel farther and faster and have a larger impact on young and budding artists everywhere.

story:
Count Down My Life

       Japanese Original Musical     

                  日本語はこちら

 

 

 

Our Japanese musical “Count Down My Life” will be presented as part of the 2013 New York International Fringe Festival. It will have 5 performances between August9th –15th. This is a big chance for us to bring Japanese born musical into the world. To make this dream performance a success we need your generous support! With only your generous support we can get the Japanese cast and musicians to fly to New York and to stay for rehearsals and the performance in New York. Please help us to bring Japanese musical talent into the world.

 

________________________________________________________________                　　　　　　　　　

   About Tip Tap      

A theatrical produce unit, founded by voluntary alumnus members of Waseda University in 2006.  Although it started out as a theatrical company, now we work as a producing unit, casting different actors for each show. Our show covers all types of categories such as ensemble plays, situation comedies, nonsense, and serious dramas.  We try to create high quality entertainment of all kinds that can match the world. From 2011 we performed “Count Down My Life” which started as a workshop performance and after two successful revival performances in Japan, our dreams came true this summer, and it will be performed in New York.

TipTap Official Page

 

Tip Tap has 9 original musical, all written and directed by Ikko Ueda.

「Flag of Pirates」「Sumidaza Kabuemaki」「The Dish of Life」「Riot!」

「Oh! my Funeral」「Takadazuka Rapsody」「Space Diamond」「Gon Valjuan」

「Count Down My Life」 

_______________________________________________________________

About Fringe NYC

It is one of the largest multi-arts festivals in North America.  More than 200 companies gather to perform in more than 20 theatres located in Downtown Manhattan. In other Fringe festivals, as long as the applicants pay their participation fee applicants are given an equal chance to perform by lottery. However in New York they employ the jury-based selection process and so the acts are selected based on their artistic qualities. Notable shows that premiered at the New York Fringe include “Urinetown” and in recent “Silence! The Musical!”, a parody musical of the movie”Silence of the Lambs” has been premiered in this festival and has been a long hit off Broadway. Every year more than 75000 people gather to the New York Fringe Festival. 

   

         Feinge NYC Official Page

  

__________________________________________________

       About Count Down My Life

 Dreaming to be someday performed in New York this    performance was first performed after 2week workshop in October 2011.We received many favorable reviews and so it was performed again as an official theatre performance in February 2012. We performed for 2 weeks which is a long-run for fringe theatres in Japan. In August 2012 we brushed up this performance and moved our theatre to Nakano the Pockets and made our revival performance. We have topped 2600 audience in total.

Last Production Movie

Count Down My Life Official Page  


 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

________________________________________________________________

   Story

 

 A would-be playwright has given his dream a time limit to either succeed by 30 or if not to give up his dream. However so far almost turning 30 he is not seeing positive results. On his 29thbirthday he fail the New Playwright Award which the results get announced every year on his birthday.

One year left until the age of 30. The man decides to give  in all his energy to take his last chance to write a new play, the one play to continue his career as a playwright. He begins to write a play based on his girl friend he lost 5 years ago in an accident. After starting to work on this play suddenly a mysterious boy appears as his fan.

Who is this mysterious boy?  As his script writing proceeds he suddenly finds an letter from his dead girlfriend and finds out an shocking truth that was hidden from him. “Count Down My Life” is a rock musical questioning the meaning of life. 

 

________________________________________________________________

About Creator

 

　　　Ikko Ueda　

　　　(Playwright/Lyrics/Director)

 

  A founder of the theatre company “Tip Tap” and is the director    and playwright for all of the company’s shows. Graduated Waseda 　University and now works for TOHO Co.,LTD.

　

Worked as assistant director with directors such as,

“Enron” (David Grindley)

“Rudolf” (David Leveaux)

 Worked as an assistant stage manager for

“Les Miserables” (John Caird)

“Rent” (Erika Schmidt)

“Grey Gardens” (Amon Miyamoto)

 From 2012 Ikko is studying in New York for a year as a fellowship of the Agency for Cultural Affairs’ Japanese Government Overseas Study Program for Artists.

__________________________________________________＿＿＿＿＿＿＿＿＿＿

       The necessity of your support!

         (How You Can Help Us)

 

 

We have been requested by the NYC Fringe organization to perform our show “in Japanese with the Japanese cast”. Therefore we must invite the Japanese cast and staff to travel abroad to the United States. This production includes 5 cast members and 5 musicians including the composer.

For travel fee and accommodation fee for 10 people to stay in New York for 10 days,

we would need $20,000 at the least.

We have been asking for support in Japan as well,

but we hope to raise $10,000 here. We ask you for your generous support!

________________________________________________________________ 

The Impact

Our goal is to create a worldwide recognized musical and to raise the standard of Japanese theater industry. Compared to the United States and Europe, Japan has low standard of recognition and understanding for theatre culture. Rather than just importing foreign shows to Japan, we must start to export our shows to the world. Therefore despite all the possible risks, we have decided to take the offer and perform in this festival. We believe that this is a big chance for us and for other theatre creators in Japan. To support the chances for Japanese theatre creators and to be able to bring more Japanese born talent into the world, we ask for your generous support!

________________________________________________________________ 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for reading. Even if you cannot clic the raising bottons, 
you can help us very well!


　●　Post this link to your blog, twitter, or facebook.

　●　Introduce this campaign to people who loves theatre and Japanese culture. 

　●　Come to our Show....... Fringe NYC Tickets   $15~18$    8/9~8/14   

         https://www.facebook.com/CountDownMyLife

         http://www.tiptap.jp/TipTap_HP/ny_english.html

story:
Short Summary

Stone and Carrie have been accepted into the actor exchange between San Francisco's own Dickens Christmas Fair and Kentwell Hall in England. Stone is the first person under the age of 18 to be accepted. Carrie, an accomplished actor, teacher and friend will go for a second year, and has offered to be his guardian while they are there. This is the opportunity of a life-time for Stone! Please help make his dream come true!

Stone has been a serious actor for over ten years. He has worked locally and in LA in television, theater and film. He currently plays the Artful Dodger from the novel "Oliver Twist" at the Dickens Christmas Fair. His dream is to attend university in England and to work professionally in the theater industry.

At Kentwell Hall, Stone will work in the stables, demonstrating the ways of Tudor England to school kids during the week and to the public on the weekends. As in their roles at Dickens Fair, Stone and Carrie will be in character all day long.

In preparation Stone is learning dialect, dancing, martial skills, acting, singing and costuming.

Carrie and Stone will spend a few days in London before heading up to Kentwell Hall for three weeks. In London, Carrie hopes to introduce Stone to future opportunites in the acting world.
 
This is Stone's dream come true. The opportunity to do this was a wonderful surprise and can only happen with your help. Thank you for supporting this great dream!

What We Need & What You Get

We are hoping to fund round-trip air faire for both Stone and Carrie. Stone will also need costume pieces made before he goes and a few things he will pick up when he gets there. Stone, Carrie and friends are offering high quality and really fun thank you gifts that will bring you into their world.

Help us spread the word.

Please share this page with your friends. Thank you!

story:
Mythos: The Crimson Chorus is an original vampire rock musical debuting this summer with your help.

Listen to sample demo tracks from our show in the gallery or on YouTube

THE PEOPLE BEHIND THIS


Do you remember the first time you fell head over heels for music?  Heather Jopling does. She was three years old. Listening to the concept album for Jesus Christ Superstar, she held the libretto and traced her fingers over the ink drawings of the cast, wondering which drawing was Ian Gillan.  She begged her parents to play the record over and over again.  

Fast-Forward 40 years.  In the spring of 2011, Heather, a playwright for 2 decades, starts writing songs.  She writes one and then another and by July, she has completed the libretto for a vampire rock opera.  A... (wait for it) DRAMATIC vampire rock opera.  Yep, you read that right.  In a world of ironic genre send-ups and comic remakes of established films, she creates Mythos: The Crimson Chorus  -  an original dramatic vampire rock opera in two acts.  Problem is, she doesn’t have a composer who can put music to her libretto... yet.

Enter composer David Velarde – the friend of a friend of a friend who is just crazy enough to say “Sure I’ll give it a go.” By Halloween of 2011,  he creates melodies for the entire show and sucks in (pardon the pun) more orchestrator friends of friends to flesh out the music. David Hoare, Jerry Steelfox, Jim Maresca, Martin Bejerano all contribute orchestrations to this project.   

THE SHOW

The score runs the gamut: from traditional 1970s-inspired rock, to blues, dance, musical theatre and modern alternative-rock.  

Listen to sample demo tracks from our show in the gallery or on YouTube

The action takes place in an urban dance club, catering to the gothic set, in the sub-basements of a refurbished factory.  We are introduced to Aethan, a vampire. Through his selfish arrogance, he has been cursed to love and lose the same human for all eternity.  We watch as he struggles for salvation and to save the woman he loves. Abandoning camp, the plot is steeped in rich human emotion and drama: vengeance, love, hope, betrayal, redemption.  

Mythos: The Crimson Chorus is told through music, recitative, movement and dance. The cast is comprised of 2 male rock tenors, 2 rock mezzo-sopranos, 1 rock soprano and a large chorus.   

OUR GOALS

We have the show, now we need to get this sucker on its feet!  That’s where you can help.   Your donations will allow us to realize our dream: a creative development workshop and showcase performance of Mythos: The Crimson Chorus.  In August of 2012 we will be working with outside rock vocalists, session musicians, and a musical director to create a cohesive sound for our show in a week-long workshop in Toronto at Buddies In Bad Times Theatre.  Our workshop will culminate is a showcase performance of the production, on Saturday, August 25, @ 7:00pm.

WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES:

Funds raised are for production costs of the workshop and the showcase performance. At this stage in our process we need to have outside input from other professional actor/singers, musicians and director types to create a show with true BITE. 

We're aiming to raise $8,500.00 here on Indiegogo to cover 75% of our total production budget.  Our budget includes:

  • Renting our audition venue

  • Renting our workshop/showcase venue

  • Paying Collaborative Artists
    (musical director, musicians, actor/singers)

  • Creating costumes for the showcase performance

  • Marketing
    (ads, fundraising, programs, posters, press releases)

  • Equipment rentals
    (mics, projectors etc.)

  • Find lodging for out-of-town collaborative artists

In the span of 9 short months, we have created a piece of theatre with engaging characters, global themes and great musical scope.  Working in our spare time, late into the night, we have come very far on our own.  We need a little more help to get this sucker ready to hit the big stage.  Please help make our vampire dream come true!

Listening to the concept album for Jesus Christ Superstar, she held the libretto and traced her fingers over the ink drawings of the cast, wondering which drawing was Ian Gillan.  She begged her parents to play the record over and over again.   Fast-Forward 40 years.  In the spring of 2011, Heather, a playwright for 2 decades, starts writing songs.  She writes one and then another and by July, she has completed the libretto for a vampire rock opera.  A... (wait for it) DRAMATIC vampire rock opera.  Yep, you read that right.  In a world of ironic genre send-ups and comic remakes of established films, she creates Mythos: The Crimson Chorus  -  an original dramatic vampire rock opera in two acts.  Problem is, she doesn’t have a composer who can put music to her libretto... yet.Enter composer David Velarde – the friend of a friend of a friend who is just crazy enough to say “Sure I’ll give it a go.” By Halloween of 2011,  he creates melodies for the entire show and sucks in (pardon the pun) more orchestrator friends of friends to flesh out the music. David Hoare, Jerry Steelfox, Jim Maresca, Martin Bejerano all contribute orchestrations to this project.   THE SHOWThe score runs the gamut: from traditional 1970s-inspired rock, to blues, dance, musical theatre and modern alternative-rock.   
Listen to sample demo tracks from our show in the gallery or on YouTube
The action takes place in an urban dance club, catering to the gothic set, in the sub-basements of a refurbished factory.  We are introduced to Aethan, a vampire. Through his selfish arrogance, he has been cursed to love and lose the same human for all eternity.  We watch as he struggles for salvation and to save the woman he loves. Abandoning camp, the plot is steeped in rich human emotion and drama: vengeance, love, hope, betrayal, redemption.  Mythos: The Crimson Chorus is told through music, recitative, movement and dance. The cast is comprised of 2 male rock tenors, 2 rock mezzo-sopranos, 1 rock soprano and a large chorus.   OUR GOALSWe have the show, now we need to get this sucker on its feet!  That’s where you can help.   Your donations will allow us to realize our dream: a creative development workshop and showcase performance of Mythos: The Crimson Chorus.  In August of 2012 we will be working with outside rock vocalists, session musicians, and a musical director to create a cohesive sound for our show in a week-long workshop in Toronto at Buddies In Bad Times Theatre.  Our workshop will culminate is a showcase performance of the production, on Saturday, August 25, @ 7:00pm.
WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES:Funds raised are for production costs of the workshop and the showcase performance. At this stage in our process we need to have outside input from other professional actor/singers, musicians and director types to create a show with true BITE.  
We're aiming to raise $8,500.00 here on Indiegogo to cover 75% of our total production budget.  Our budget includes:


Renting our audition venue 

Renting our workshop/showcase venue
Paying Collaborative Artists(musical director, musicians, actor/singers) 
Creating costumes for the showcase performance
Marketing (ads, fundraising, programs, posters, press releases)
Equipment rentals (mics, projectors etc.)
Find lodging for out-of-town collaborative artists
In the span of 9 short months, we have created a piece of theatre with engaging characters, global themes and great musical scope.  Working in our spare time, late into the night, we have come very far on our own.  We need a little more help to get this sucker ready to hit the big stage.  Please help make our vampire dream come true!

story:
Step Into a Steampunk State of Mind

Imagine a world of Victorian sensibilities and captivating steam-driven technology.

The Importance of Being Earnest features the handsome gentlemen John Worthing and Algernon Moncrieff, as they pursue the fair ladies Gwendolen Fairfax and Cecily Cardew. Matters of the heart are slightly complicated by the invention by both men of imaginary characters to help cover for their own activities — not to mention the disapproval of Gwendolen’s domineering mother, Lady Bracknell.

Adding a steampunk flair to this classic production might be unexpected, but it melds together perfectly.

Who We Are

The Brelby Theatre Company is a grassroots theatre troupe, founded by Northern Arizona University alumnae, Brian & Shelby Maticic. We kicked off our fifth season by opening the doors to our own storefront studio theatre in the charming Historic Downtown Glendale, AZ. We're delighted and proud to have joined such an amazing and eclectic community, and we look forward to providing intimate theatre to the West Valley, including new works from local playwrights.


What We're Fundraising For

The costs of opening a small business can be daunting, but we believe in our company and the quality of theatre that we produce. We're delighted to be putting down roots in Historic Downtown Glendale. 

We’re looking for help from our wonderful community to assist us in raising the funds to cover the costs of the mechanical set for "The Importance of Being Earnest."

Covering the costs of scenic construction will help us to recover from a lot of unexpected fees during the construction process leading to our recent opening in February.

We are working to raise $1000 to cover the costs of the materials.

The Impact

We’re excited to bring quality theatre to the Downtown Glendale community, and your contribution will help make it a possibility. The Brelby studio is not only offering a full season of six mainstage productions, but also a variety of original plays, classes and workshops for the West Valley community in 2013.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that times are tough, and some people aren’t in a position to contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help.

Word of mouth is the most valuable marketing tool out there. Help us to spread word about our campaign, our 2013 season, and our new Glendale location. Use the Indiegogo share tools, post this to your Facebook/Twitter page. Send an email to your friends.


We appreciate the support of theatre lovers like you.

story:
The Ukulele Orchestra Of Great Brooklyn, a musical comedy troupe, has devised a play that was accepted into the Dream Up festival, hosted by Theatre for the New City in NYC! But they need $2500 in order to fully participate! The Theatre for the New City is a Pulitzer Prize winning community cultural center, known for its artistic standards and community service. The Theatre for the New City produces 30-40 premieres of new American plays per year, at least 10 of which are by emerging and young playwrights.

This play is outrageous, hilarious, and inappropriate. But it is also an earnest examination of companionship. ItÊ¼s a story about the lifelong bonds we sustain - especially between women. It was created in the spirit of those friendships that withstand the test of time - through loss, through great joy, through the excitement and disappointments of living in New York City, through loosing and sustaining love. So, in Missionary in Manhattan, the play that will be performed in the Dream Up festival, is a deeper look into the lives of these three women who have followed their brother husband Charles Gregory Howard to New York City...their brother husband with an affinity for his "vocal coach" named Gerard.


                                      Missionary in Manhattan, A Mormon Musical

                                 Presented by the Ukulele Orchestra of Great Brooklyn

                                  Starring Caitlin Davis, Elizabeth May, and Dave May

                                                   Directed by Kaleigh Malloy

                  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help our cause:

You can always get the word out or make some noise about our campaign by sharing this link via Facebook and Twitter!

OR

You can come see the performance! The show will be held in The Theatre for a New City's Community Space and the performance dates are:

August 23, 2012 at 6:30pm
August 29, 2012 at 9:00pm
September 6, 2012 at 9:00pm
September 8, 2012 at 5:00pm
September 9, 2012 at 5:00pm

story:
Short Summary

Set in New York 1997, this brutally honest drama explores fidelity and redefines relationships.

Starring Lindsay Nelson, Meeshelle Neal and Johnny Gingell with Kristina Soroff and David Cambeitz.

Produced and Directed by Gregory Milne.

Set Design and Stage Managed by Cathrin Parkin.

Hair and Make-up by Alison Gorka.

 

The show will be up at Spectral Theatre, 350 Powell Street in Vancouver.

Show dates are:

November 22, 23, 24, 29, 30 and December 1st.

Doors at 7:30pm, Show at 8:00pm

Tickets will be $15 at the door.

 

**Suggested 18+: Suggestive/course language, sexual themes.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This has been a dream project for many years and we want to put on the best show possible for our audience. All funds will be put towards rental for the space, creating a dynamic, detailed set and of course for advertising.

Right now we are offering a number of ticket bundles along with a few bonus "freebies". We will add more incentives as they come along. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Gregory Milne is also raising money for this project via a September Photography Sale with packages starting at only $50! If you need headshots, portraits, promotional photos, book/CD/poster design or just about anything else that requires photography and graphic design, feel free to email gregorymilne@gmail.com for more information.

story:
THE PROJECT

This amorphous book musical, drawing on sea chanties and operetta, has been in gestation for many years. It's one of those crazy pet projects. And, not surprisingly, it's a project about pirates. More accurately, it's a project about our blatant cultural infatuation with piracy. We love the fighting, we love the fashion, we love the adventure, the lingo, the exotic locales, and, most of all, we love the fantasy of becoming pirates ourselves; the tantalizing prospect of shedding all moral, legal, and social obligations simply to bask in the freedom of the open seas.

 

We call the piece a fantasia in reaction to the slew of pirate oriented films and musicals that have attempted to stuff the concept of piracy into a traditional narrative arc – a choice we consider anathema to piracy’s inherent anarchy. Instead we want to trace three analogous stories in three different time periods – the Bahamas (1717), Hollywood (1943), and present day Manhattan and Somalia – music, text and movement chaotically interweaving in an epic poor-theatre experience that asks: is our romance with piracy – built upon a factual foundation of rape, pillage, rebellion and murder – a legitimate expression of our unquenchable thirst for freedom?

 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT YOU'LL GET

For the upcoing workshop, we are thrilled to have free rehearsal space and a brilliant crew of musicians and actors on board.

We're doing it on the rough, attempting to mount this version as free and cheap as possible. But for the few things that unavoidably require money, we need to raise $1000.

Supporters will receive a personalized sea shanty from Josh and Stephanie - performed by the entire cast of the workshop!

story:
Oakland Ballet Turns 50!

In 2015, Oakland Ballet Company celebrates its 50th anniversary! Planning is underway to commemorate this milestone event with cherished historical masterworks and new dances commissioned from local choreographers whose early careers were nurtured by the Oakland Ballet.

OBC was recently lauded by both audiences and critics for making a breakthrough in ballet relevance with our 2014 spring repertory production, "Oakland-esque," a program inspired by Oakland's rich arts heritage. Carla Escoda from “The Huffington Post” wrote, “A program that celebrates this spirited city with such style and invention deserves a long run, in many different venues. Purists may grumble, but this is the future of ballet. Companies in other cities should pay attention.”

Our exciting 50th Anniversary Season will include the favorite programs our community has come to expect: Production of the East Bay holiday treasure, Artistic Director Graham Lustig's The Nutcracker, and arts education for public schools students of the East Bay, an ongoing commitment that is core to our mission. Public exhibitions of OBC photos, costumes and playbills are planned for Bay Area libraries and museums.

The 50th Anniversary Fund will be used to fund three productions during the 50th Anniversary season, continuing OBC's "Discover Dance" arts education program, prepare materials for public exhibitions and support the publication of a book about the history of OBC. Help us to celebrate a legacy of dance by making your contribution to our fund. 

About Oakland Ballet Company

Mission and Programs:

The mission of Oakland Ballet Company (OBC) is to inspire the community and keep the tradition of ballet exciting, vibrant and accessible. To fulfill this mission, it is OBC’s goal to:

  • Champion innovative choreographers;
  • Provide ballet training and performance opportunities for professional and aspiring dancers in both classical and contemporary works; and
  • Partner with all segments of the East Bay arts and education communities and share enrichment programs that bring the value of the arts to those who might not otherwise have access to the arts.

Each season, OBC provides the community with a variety of dance related programming, including:

  • Annual production of Graham Lustig’s “The Nutcracker” at Paramount Theatre. 
  • Spring repertory production of new, contemporary works.
  • “Discover Dance,” a year-round community outreach program, offering “OBC in the Schools,” educational programs in East Bay schools; “Production in Action” in-theater educational performances; free performances at community events, ticket donations to OBC productions, and scholarships to OBC training programs.
  • Training programs for young dancers including weekly technique classes and two-week summer workshop, “Ballet Boot Camp.”
History:


OBC was founded in 1965 by Ronn Guidi and gained international recognition through the reconstructions of ballets from the legendary Ballets Russes as well as the creation of innovative contemporary choreography. In 2000, Ronn Guidi retired and Karen Brown was appointed Artistic Director.  Brown continued the company’s commitment to performing classical works of ballet, while focusing especially on commissioning new, contemporary dance. 

In 2010, OBC celebrated the arrival of internationally acclaimed choreographer, Graham Lustig as Artistic Director. Lustig’s career as a dancer and director parallels OBC’s tradition of presenting historically vibrant work while championing new choreography, and he shares OBC’s commitment to providing the community with accessible arts experiences.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are grateful for all types of support from the community. If you are unable to contribute a monetary donation, you can help in the following ways:

  • Spread the word. Please share this fundraising campaign with your networks via email and social media.
  • Volunteer for OBC. We are always looking for volunteers to assist us during production and around the administrative offices. If you would like to volunteer, please email info@oaklandballet.org.

With your help, OBC will commemorate a successful 50th Anniversary Season and continue to grow and thrive as a performing arts institution.  We look forward to seeing you at performances and events, celebrating together our new and returning partnerships. We truly believe Oakland Ballet Company is integral to the quality of life in our community, making Oakland and the East Bay a better place to work, live and visit.

story:
LETTERS FROM HOME is a stage play produced by Cheryll San Juan and Jill Javelosa-Alvarez to promote theatrical arts as a means to inspire pride in and awareness of Filipino art, culture and history, and showing how these are an integral part of the Filipino identity.

Together, Cheryll and Jill make the appreciation of Philippine art and culture accessible to the multi-cultural community they serve and awaken the cultural consciousness of the Filipino audiences through production of spectacular theatrical plays and other related engaging activities like forums, workshops and special events.

GET INVOLVED. CREATE OPPORTUNITY. BUILD COMMUNITY

The production of LETTERS FROM HOME aims to contribute to enhancing the quality of life of Filipinos in the Greater Toronto Area through creation of business and job opportunities using their talent and passion in theatre. Arts has a measurable economic impact that help increase social vitality of our community.

LETTERS FROM HOME spotlights the lifelines of Filipinos overseas:  first, vital relationships within their virtual family or support system abroad and second, the unbreakable ties to dependent families back home whose lives are uplifted, if not sustained, by their hard work and sacrifice.

The play offers an opportunity for companies and individuals like you to create shared value and hand back an edifying theatre experience for the Filipino diaspora in Canada.

HELP US REACH OUR GOAL.

Every contribution counts.  Support us to continuously produce professional Filipino theatre.  The cost of this event is much higher than the Indiegogo goal we have set. The $10,000 funds we need to raise is the basic cost to cover only theatre rental for rehearsal and performances, production related expenses such as props, costumes, stage set and minimum allowance for 14 cast and 6 crew members.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can donate, then we thank you! Any donation, no matter how small, will help. But even if you can't you can still help us out!

Email the link to this campaign and information about Letters from Home to friends, family, colleagues and anyone you know who would like to make a difference.

Watch more on our Website or on Facebook.  

Purchase tickets Online.

Post the campaign link to your Facebook page, Twitter feed or other social media.

Watch us!

story:
OPPRESSED IN HEELS:
Living in a community where gender, oppression, justice and opportunity appear everywhere in our national dialogue, the time is perfect to examine the stories we tell about these issues.

Oppressed In Heels is a three part series that uses the theatre of the past to illuminate the present. By creatively adapting traditional narratives exploring the role of a woman’s voice, we aim to foster discussion in the here and now around what these stories can tell us about our world today. By creating a communal experience, and great art, we can empower our audience to question the forces that shape these stories, and examine their role in defining our beliefs.

THE SHOW:
"The Trojan Women" is a devised piece working hand-in-hand with Cyd Igot's "A Letter For You Project"( http://aletterforyou.org/), a non-profit organization that collects handwritten letters of support and encouragement for survivors. This production will share real stories gathered from a wide cross-section of female victims of war (understanding this as both the general definition, as well as the more nuanced definitions, of the word), and blending them with Euripides' classical text as well as other found text. 

Through this myriad of perspectives, this devised version of "The Trojan Women" will shed light on the paradox of how much and how little has changed since Euripides penned "The Trojan Women" hundreds of years ago.  With nine actors, led by director Nathaniel P. Claridad ("Here Lies Love"), and Lynnsey Ooten (founder of the "Oppressed in Heels" project), "The Trojan Women" opens at The Access Theatre (380 Broadway, New York, NY 10013) October 22nd through November 1st.

What We Need 

We have to raise all funds to get this show up. Unlike other shows that are being produced by existing companies, this is just us. We need any and all help we can get.

Retreat

$1,000

Insurance for Cast & Crew

$200

Performance Space

$3,950

Audition Space

$100

Equity Actors Pay

$2,000

Production Team Stipend

$1,000

Set

$200

Costumes

$200

Props

story_txt:
OPPRESSED IN HEELS: Living in a community where gender, oppression, justice and opportunity appear everywhere in our national dialogue, the time is perfect to examine the stories we tell about these issues. 
 Oppressed In Heels is a three part series that uses the theatre of the 
past to illuminate the present. By creatively adapting traditional 
narratives exploring the role of a woman’s voice, we aim to foster 
discussion in the here and now around what these stories can tell us 
about our world today. By creating a communal experience, and great art,
 we can empower our audience to question the forces that shape these 
stories, and examine their role in defining our beliefs. THE SHOW:"The Trojan Women" is a devised piece working hand-in-hand with Cyd Igot's "A Letter For You Project"( http://aletterforyou.org/), a non-profit organization that collects handwritten letters of support and encouragement for survivors. This production will share real stories gathered from a wide cross-section of female victims of war (understanding this as both the general definition, as well as the more nuanced definitions, of the word), and blending them with Euripides' classical text as well as other found text.  Through this myriad of perspectives, this devised version of "The Trojan Women" will shed light on the paradox of how much and how little has changed since Euripides penned "The Trojan Women" hundreds of years ago.  With nine actors, led by director Nathaniel P. Claridad ("Here Lies Love"), and Lynnsey Ooten (founder of the "Oppressed in Heels" project), "The Trojan Women" opens at The Access Theatre (380 Broadway, New York, NY 10013) October 22nd through November 1st. What We Need  We have to raise all funds to get this 
show up. Unlike other shows that are being produced by existing 
companies, this is just us. We need any and all help we can get.




Retreat

  for Cast & Crew

story:
GOING UP

(The Elevator Musical)

Our original musical comedy was selected for the New York New Works Festival. We have a special opportunity to present our work to Tony and Emmy award winning producers who can help take our work to the next level.

We are very excited to have made it to the semi-final round of the festival. The more we perform the more producers have an opportunity to see our work and also the more our production costs rise.

ABOUT THE SHOW:

INSPIRATION

We all ride elevators. Some of us multiple times a day. And every time we get inside, trapped in the corner or squished next to the huge-summer-sweaty-guy, our bubble space invaded, and listening to the Muzak drone on we think, even if it is just a flash through our minds, we think, “Is this the time I’m going to get stuck?” And we scan the elevator to see who our fellow ragtag inmates will be. And we wonder if we might escape through the trapdoor in the ceiling. And we wonder if we have anything to eat because we missed breakfast. And we pray to God that we won’t have to pee. Or worse. And what about the overly pregnant woman by the buttons? Is she going to blow? 

SYNOPSIS

Going Up is a musical comedy that plays on our collective thoughts and fears; a musical that takes place entirely within a seven by seven space. Five New Yorkers on an average day in the city get into an elevator. There is an overweight animator who is going to pitch his newest idea for a cartoon about vampire kittens, a bicycle courier from the Middle-East with his bike and heavy package, an angsty teenager meeting her boyfriend for a sex-romp in her mother’s office, a hard-nosed pregnant business woman and a woman overcoming her fear of elevators. In mid-travel the elevator gets stuck between floors and they must deal with the troubles of being in cramped quarters including: stir-craziness, fatigue, hunger, bladder control and climaxing with an unplanned elevator birth.

THEME

Going Up explores the moment when strangers become friends, when differences are accepted, and all within a fun situation that everyone can recognize. Going Up is deliciously uncomfortable, amusingly awkward, with songs you will hum to yourself every time you get into an elevator much to the chagrin of your fellow riders.

CREATIVE TEAM

Our team is made up of talented creators and performers who have been on Broadway and toured internationally.

  • David Hersh - Concept/Book/Director
  • Stephen Hersh - Lyrics
  • Shami Arslanian and Steve Weisbart - Composers

ACTORS

  • Jackson Mercado - Bicycle Courier (Tariq)
  • Rebecca Ruttle - Neurotic Woman (Nora)
  • Daniel Walstad - Big Personality (Albert)
  • Pam Zazzarino - Angsty Teen (Anastasia)
  • Emmanuelle Zeesman - Pregnant Woman (Corinne)

PRODUCTION TEAM

  • Toby Singer - Musical Director/Accompanist
  • Kelsey Goldman - Stagemanager

WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES

Funds raised on our Indiegogo campaign will help fund our participation in the New York New Works Theatre Festival. We plan to raise $2,500 to cover our production costs. Our budget includes:

  • Renting rehearsal and recording spaces in New York
  • Paying Collaborative Artists
    (performers, director, musician, technical team)
  • Stage props and Costumes
  • Marketing
    (programs, postcards, social networking, press releases)
  • Equipment rentals
    (microphones, lights, keyboard)

Your contributions will help make the show a success and attract the right producer who can give it a big, bright future.

story:
Short Summary

Hi! We are raising money to replace the well worn Theatre Chairs at the Sidewalk Studio Theatre.  

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are raising 5,000 dollars to purchase Theatre Chairs. Any extra funds will go to purchasing necessary Lighting Upgrades in the Theatre. 
  • We have some fun and exiting Perks! Have a look and chose what best fits your desires!

The Impact

Honestly, this will benefit anyone that wants to sit down at the Theatre. 

Risks & Challenges

Without Chairs... watch the video...

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word by sharing the link throughout the month long campaign.

story:
Update and Stretch Goals

We reached our target! Thank you so much to all our magnificently generous donors. The constant confirmation that my story is welcome in the world is extremely moving. That I don't have to hide any more. That women everywhere do not have to hide anymore - this is the most welcome realisation of all.

We have just heard that a funding bid fell through so are pushing for a further £1,230 in the next week as of 25th May 2016. This money will be used to pay our awesomely talented creative and technical team as well as rehearsal space, transportation and design costs.

Please help us to get this story out in the world and destigmatise the dialogue around sexual violence.

All donations and support will be so hugely valuable to us. Please keep sharing and donating. There are many perks still to claim!

Thank you a thousand times,

Imogen and all the Foreign Body team xx

Full Budget

£500 each for designer, movement director, musician, sound designer, performer, producer (3 weeks rehearsal + 3 performances). 
£400 for stage manager (1 week rehearsal + performances)
£400 to build the set and make costume
£300 for transportation to and from rehearsal rooms and festival venues
£360 rehearsal space
£150 graphic design
£150 insurance
£40 print

Why?

Survivors of sexual violence are marginalised by the stigma attached to their stories and we aim to help break that stigma and offer up a path of healing and expansion. At least 1 in 3 of our women have survived sexual violence. We are all affected and we are all responsible.

This solo performance piece is the epitome of the personal passion project. It is a hopeful piece that, although it deals with hard-hitting subject matter, has been described as “inspiring”, “liberating” and “enlightening”. It is my own account of finding healing and forgiveness after sexual assault. Not only does it tell my story, but also includes an often unheard perspective: that of the perpetrator of the assault.


The Story So Far

In development the play has been supported by Arts Council England, Rich Mix and the Lyric Hammersmith. A 15-minute work-in-progress was performed at the One Festival at the Space Theatre and A Pleasance Scratch in February and at Tristan Bates Theatre's First Scratch in April.

Audience feedback from these development showings has been overwhelmingly positive:
“Groundbreaking”  ”Incredibly important”  “Moving and powerful”
“A story that needs to be told”  “An absolutely fascinating piece of theatre”
“I feel liberated. A sense of hope. A solidarity of spirit”
“I feel very privileged to bear witness to this account”
“I was really struck by the power and depth in the simplicity of what you are doing”
“The trance-like meditative quality of the physical body was healing and profound to watch”


What Happens Next?

We will perform the show at two festivals this summer: the RADA Festival on 27th and 29th June and the inaugural Off Beat Festival, Oxford, on 23rd June.

This campaign will help us to pay for the most magical elements of creating a brilliant theatre piece: design by award-winning designer Ana-Ines Jabares Pita and the creation of an original soundtrack by brilliant Quest Ensemble musicians Tara Franks and Filipe Sousa as well as day-to-day rehearsal space, transportation costs.


Not Just a Play

In support of our aim of destigmatising dialogue around sexual violence we will be presenting Q&As alongside the show featuring performer Imogen Butler-Cole, whose story the play tells; Marina Cantacuzino, founder of extraordinary charity The Forgiveness Project and Winnie Li, founder of the festival Clear Lines - the first festival in the UK to revolve around sexual assault and consent. This gives audience members the opportunity to explore further the subject matter in a safe space. We are also planning to present The Forgiveness Project's exhibition The F-Word, which has so far been shown in over 550 venues worldwide.


What's In It For You?

Our incredibly generous and imaginative team have all offered to donate real rewards. 

Imogen, the performer, coaches business professionals in communication skills. Through RADA In Business she has worked with clients such as Chanel, Dove, Sony, Santander and the BBC - and now she can coach you!

Niamh, the movement director, coaches movement for individuals, theatre companies and business executives. Transform the way you move with a special one on one session with her!

Ana Ines will create a postcard of an image from her design process. Unique artwork for your home in return for your wonderful generosity.

Quest Ensemble are generously donating digital downloads of their stunning album Footfall.

Photographer Grace Gelder will donate copies of her stunning black and white production photographs. 

Our supporters The Forgiveness Project are kindly donating copies of their extraordinary book "The Forgiveness Project, Stories for a Vengeful Age" by Marina Cantacuzino.


It's Not (all) About The Money, Money, Money

We'll be hugely grateful for whatever help we can get in getting the word out there. If you aren't able to contribute financially please do share this campaign among your networks by using the buttons below. And let us know if you can come to any of the shows listed above - it would be a pleasure to meet supporters and hear their responses to our project.
