Imogen, the performer, coaches business professionals in communication skills. Through RADA In Business she has worked with clients such as Chanel, Dove, Sony, Santander and the BBC - and now she can coach you!
Niamh, the movement director, coaches movement for individuals, theatre companies and business executives. Transform the way you move with a special one on one session with her!
Ana Ines will create a postcard of an image from her design process. Unique artwork for your home in return for your wonderful generosity.
Quest Ensemble are generously donating digital downloads of their stunning album Footfall.
Photographer Grace Gelder will donate copies of her stunning black and white production photographs. 
Our supporters The Forgiveness Project are kindly donating copies of their extraordinary book "The Forgiveness Project, Stories for a Vengeful Age" by Marina Cantacuzino.
 


    It's Not (all) About The Money, Money, Money We'll be hugely grateful for whatever help we can get in getting the word out there. If you aren't able to contribute financially please do share this campaign among your networks by using the buttons below. And let us know if you can come to any of the shows listed above - it would be a pleasure to meet supporters and hear their responses to our project.

story:
Shakespeare for Everyone!

Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park uplifts and enriches the lives of local residents through a classical theater experience. We believe the arts are an important part of the fabric of a community and we want to do our part to ensure a thriving arts environment and help foster the value of the arts as a public good. 

Residents of all ages and economic backgrounds are invited to come together for free outdoor theater in Vallejo, Martinez and Oakland. We are passionate about creating, producing and presenting live theater, and introducing non-theater goers to the visceral, cathartic experience of watching a live performance in the company of other audience members. Because this is a free event, all funds to pay company members and operations must be raised through grants and other fund raising sources such as asking generous community members like you to contribute to this campaign. 

Your contribution will go directly to paying our fabulous and well deserving actors. 

Matinee performances, using natural light and sound, means we will not use or need lighting and sound equipment or techs, keeping our production costs low and our performance values high! Still, we need $3000 to cover our 20 actors' pay for our upcoming free performances. 

Then, why, you ask, are we asking for $3300? Fees. Up to 10%. Indiegogo (4%), plus paypal and credit card fees (3% ea.). In order for us to get the full $3000 we need to help pay our hardworking actors, we need to add the additional cost for the fees.

A free community event.

Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park is preparing for our sixth season! Once again our production will be directed by Clinton Vidal. Performances will be held at the Hanns Park Amphitheater in Vallejo July 25 and 26, at the Martinez Waterfront Amphitheater in Martinez, August 1 and 2, and the Peralta Hacienda Historical Park in Oakland on August 8 and 9, 2015. All performances at 3 pm.

Our 2015 show will be another “bare-bones” production, concentrating on the actors performances, with minimal set and modern dress. As is our tradition we will be announcing which show in April on Shakespeare's possible birthday. Drop us a line at vallejoshakespeare@gmail.com to be put on our email list and receive the announcement. 

Vallejo Shakespeare in the Park is proud to bring professional live theater to the residents of Vallejo, Martinez and Oakland. Our aim is to provide an inspiring and educational experience for our audience through intensive preparation and high quality performance.  

Find us on Facebook at Vallejo Shakespeare.  

Performance opportunities for the Bay Area theater community!

One of our goals is to provide professional performance opportunities through non-traditional casting to Bay Area actors of color and varying backgrounds. Our casts are made up of multi-ethnic and diverse actors from around the Bay Area. Characters in the plays are often switched from male to female, as well as casting females to play male roles, providing more acting opportunities for women. Smaller roles are also given to novice actors to give opportunities to a wide range of actors at every level. We want our productions to reflect our diverse community where we perform and help our audience connect to classical theater with exciting contemporary staging.

We pay our stupendous actors a small stipend for their hard work and time, but we need help to do this. Please help. Thank you.

All photos are from our 2014 production of A Midsummer Night's Dream. Photos taken by Clinton Vidal and Dede Scrivner.

story:
IN YOUR FACE THEATRE is an Edinburgh based Theatre Company,
set up by Greg Esplin, with the views to push theatre past its boundaries. In
Your Face work hard on knocking down the fourth-wall so that the audience are
truly encaptured within the performance. We do not believe in actor/audience
separation. We want you to experience our stories with more impact than 3D
television. It is our ambition to allow the audience to forget they are
watching a "show", you are watching an event unfold in front of you -
and if you want to move out of the way, or move even closer to the action (if
you don't mind us breathing down your necks) then feel free, but be warned, you
might not want to get too close to some of our characters.

So why are we asking for funding I hear you say....

After a very successful 65-show-run at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, IN YOUR FACE THEATRE will be taking Trainspotting to the King's Head Theatre in London from March 17th - April 11th.
This has given the company a boost in the right direction, and are really on their way to making an impressive mark on the industry.

 However, we can't do it alone.

What will your money go towards? To help a Scottish based theatre company not only to perform a run of shows in London but to continue creating 5* productions in the future.

Previous shows IN YOUR FACE THEATRE has successfully produced are: 

THE HARD MAN (Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2013. Edinburgh, Glasgow, Dundee Tour. 5*)

LIEUTENANT OF INISHMORE (Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2014. 5*)

TRAINSPOTTING (Edinburgh, December 2013. Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2014. 5*)

Here are some of the reviews received for Trainspotting:

"I'm not big on reading or watching my old stuff but was blown away by @IYF_Theatre production of Trainspotting at the festival. ‪#‎topshaggers" (Tweet response from Irvine Welsh)

"I thought it was a great show. They really breathed new life into the old dog."

"Great production and hugely talented cast - they will go on to do more great things."

Irvine Welsh

.......

"Headed by a compelling Gavin Ross as Renton, this large cast work hard and generously, playing things for real (and in-yer-face) but skillfully resisting the temptation to provoke and thus alienate the audience. Hence they ensure it is the graveyard humour in Welsh’s masterpiece that shocks most of all."

The Stage 

.......

"Gavin Ross’s Renton was a bundle of sinewy intensity; Chris Dennis’s Begby made Robert Carlyle’s film version seem a little Disney in comparison."

"This production of Trainspotting is bold, innovative and delivered with passion, justifying the ‘In Your Face’ moniker"
"It was at times terrifying, at times heartbreaking."
BroadwayBaby

......

"The best support comes from Erin Marshall as desperate Alison, whose shock at a cot death that might well have been avoidable is chillingly realistic."

British Theatre Guide

.......

Rather than creating a page only to ask for money, we thought we would make things a bit different....
You will not only be contributing but sponsoring the whole of the Trainspotting cast to take part in a cycle from Glasgow to Edinburgh on March 7th!!

IN YOUR FACE THEATRE also runs a Variety Performance night called "Open Up". This is held at the Tron Pub, Hunter's Square, Edinburgh.  Every session has been incredibly successful with young performers from Edinburgh and Glasgow coming to practice their monologues, songs, poetry, stand up, and improvisation. The donations collected at this event will also be going towards this exciting venture!

Anything you can give, big or small, know that your contribution is helping to promote Scottish Theatre!

Thanks from all of us at IN YOUR FACE THEATRE!!

P.S if you find yourself in London between 17th March - 11th April you can come and see the cast in action. So get your tickets here...

www.kingsheadtheatre.com

for funding I hear you say....
After a very
successful 65-show-run at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, IN YOUR FACE THEATRE
will be taking Trainspotting to the King's Head Theatre in London from March
17th - April 11th.
This has given the company a boost in the right direction, and are really on their
way to making an impressive mark on the industry.
 However, we can't do it alone.
What will your money
go towards? To help a Scottish based theatre company not only to perform a run
of shows in London but to continue creating 5* productions in the future.
Previous shows IN YOUR FACE THEATRE has successfully
produced are: 
THE HARD MAN (Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2013.
Edinburgh, Glasgow, Dundee Tour. 5*)
LIEUTENANT OF INISHMORE (Edinburgh Fringe
Festival 2014. 5*)
TRAINSPOTTING (Edinburgh, December 2013.
Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2014. 5*)
Here are some of the
reviews received for Trainspotting:
"I'm not big on
reading or watching my old stuff but was blown away by @IYF_Theatre production
of Trainspotting at the festival. ‪#‎topshaggers" (Tweet response
from Irvine Welsh)
"I thought it was
a great show. They really breathed new life into the old dog."
"Great production
and hugely talented cast - they will go on to do more great things."
Irvine Welsh
.......
"Headed by a
compelling Gavin Ross as Renton, this large cast work hard and generously,
playing things for real (and in-yer-face) but skillfully resisting the
temptation to provoke and thus alienate the audience. Hence they ensure it is
the graveyard humour in Welsh’s masterpiece that shocks most of all."
The Stage 
.......
"Gavin Ross’s
Renton was a bundle of sinewy intensity; Chris Dennis’s Begby made Robert
Carlyle’s film version seem a little Disney in comparison."
"This production
of Trainspotting is bold, innovative and delivered with passion, justifying the
‘In Your Face’ moniker"
"It was at times terrifying, at times heartbreaking."
BroadwayBaby
......
"The best support
comes from Erin Marshall as desperate Alison, whose shock at a cot death that
might well have been avoidable is chillingly realistic."
British Theatre Guide
.......
Rather than creating a
page only to ask for money, we thought we would make things a bit different....
You will not only be contributing but sponsoring the whole of the Trainspotting
cast to take part in a cycle from Glasgow to Edinburgh on March 7th!!
IN YOUR FACE THEATRE also runs a Variety Performance night called
"Open Up". This is held at the Tron Pub, Hunter's Square, Edinburgh.
 Every session has been incredibly successful with young
performers from Edinburgh and Glasgow coming to practice their monologues,
songs, poetry, stand up, and improvisation. The donations collected at this
event will also be going towards this exciting venture!
Anything you can give,
big or small, know that your contribution is helping to promote Scottish
Theatre!
Thanks from all of us at IN YOUR FACE THEATRE!!
P.S if you find
yourself in London between 17th March - 11th April you can come and see the
cast in action. So get your tickets here...

www.kingsheadtheatre.com

story:
FEATURING:
Sean Geoghan, *Bruce Hermann, *Hannah Scott, Ollie Oliver
*Denotes actor appearing courtesy of AEA 

Scenic and Props - Skye Worthington-Bunn
Sound by Jack Horowitz
Stage Manager - Emily Goforth

At Home In Oil  is a three-part cycle of plays that takes place inside the home of the Estes family: a family that draws its sustenance from the crude beneath their feet.

In The Dinner Table, playwright Sawyer Estes depicts himself at a family meal of his childhood. There, Mommy and Daddy investigate Sawyer’s lack of appetite while competing for the opportunity to feed him.

In The Pool, the family leaves the dining room for the backyard. While Da speculates over the value of a pool filled with crude oil, Ma awaits the arrival of a Pool Man with more intimate exploits in mind. And Saw—now a toddler in a stroller—prepares to discover his place in the family affairs.

In The Living Room, Mother and Father have aged severely. They are now restricted to wheelchairs and dependent upon their son and hospice nurse—both the same Sawyer—for their livelihood. But another Sawyer, the playwright himself, is narrating the events overhead as they occur, causing strife and confusion as Mother and Father recede into death at the care of their only son—Sawyer.


Oil on a Budget

We have 30 days to secure the funding we need to make sure this New York City Premier is a smashing success on Opening Night, which is February 6th, 2015.
Expenses include: audition space, rehearsal space, and performance venue rental in Midtown Manhattan ($$$), scenery and props, lighting and video projection, costumes, advertising, liability insurance to meet the requirements of the actors' equity union (AEA), advertising costs, and of course, we need to pay the creative team a little something for their time and talent (actors, designers, stage manager).
We estimate that our total expenses for this production will be $4500.
Our goal is to raise at least $3500 through this fundraising campaign. Your support today ensures that we will reach (or exceed) our fundraising goal and makes it a realistic possibility that we will recover the rest of the expenses through ticket sales. Without your support, we may not be able to recover costs through ticket sales alone. All of the above expenses are non-negotiable and anything not covered by your generous support will have to be paid out of personal pockets, at a loss.

Why Now?

With oil and its impact on the environment and economy at the forefront of social and political discourse - plummeting gas prices, the Keystone XL pipeline, fracking, global warming, an unrelenting war in the Middle East - plays about oil are timely.
Raised in a third-generation Texas oil family, playwright Sawyer Estes brings a new insight to these polemical debates. By exploring oil through the lens of the family unit - seemingly his own family unit - he approaches the resource on a startlingly personal basis and raises awareness of the impact oil can have on family life. By doing so, he invites us all, as audience members and participants in this democracy driven by crude oil, to look at our own intimate relationship with this resource beneath our feet, at our fingertips, and in our skies.


Advance Ticket Sales

To purchase your tickets today, click the early-bird PERK for a price of $18.
Then shoot us an email to athomeinoil@gmail.com to reserve the night you wish to attend!
Otherwise, tickets will be sold at the door on the evening of the show.

When?

February 6th, 7th, 13th, 20th, and 21st @ 7:30pm

Where?

Stage Left Studio
214 West 30th Street, New York, NY 10001


You Can Help

Review the PERKS, donate all you can to our cause, and claim your reward today!

story:
The Evolution of Alice 

Alice started off as an adaptation for the proscenium stage that started back when Leyla was in high school. Like our dear protagonist, Alice evolved over time into an immersive theatre piece. 

This project is a world of its own, where audiences will be able to smell, feel and react to the characters living within it. With your help we will be able to increase the believability of this landscape, and Alice's mind will become a reality. 

The Impact

Alice gives an opportunity for the audience to get involved with a show unlike any that has come before. Our extensive advertising program will involve the audience before they even set foot in the performance space. Alice encourages the audience to re-live childhood again and rediscover that curiosity when entering an unknown world. This show will make you consider how you see the world and approach it, giving you a new lens into your life. 

What We Need & What You Get

Alice will be taking place throughout the Humanities building, on the Purchase College Campus. The space that we are using has already been given to us, so the funds that we raise will go towards building the world of Alice with:

  •  Props and set pieces ($1000) 
  •  Costumes and makeup for the characters ($800) 
  •  Bringing people to the project with our marketing plan ($200) 

We have awesome perks to offer, ranging from buttons and pins that have been designed specifically for Alice; personalized card decks with signatures from the cast and crew, as well as quotes from Alice's Adventures in Wonderland; to behind the scenes photography and design sketches of the show. All of the perks that we are offering are created or designed by the cast and crew of the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, we understand! Please help spread the word about this show and get excited!! There are sharing tools through Indiegogo that you can use as well. If you can, fall through the rabbit hole and become a part of the project.

story:
Secession 2015

We are thrilled to announce that our next collaborative project, Secession 2015, is in rehearsals!

Secession 2015 takes the work of some of the greatest Viennese painters and musicians of the early 20th century and challenges contemporary artists to create work inspired by some of their more pivotal pieces.  

This August, the world of the Vienna Secession will be brought to life, transforming a Victorian house on Governors Island into an immersive artscape of visual and performance experiences.

Our audience will be lead into a living gallery to explore the stories behind the paintings, traversing inside the minds, lives, and worlds of the artists.


When?

                                             August 15th - September 25th

                                       Shows every Friday at 3:30PM

                                                               and

                                  Saturdays & Sundays at 2PM  & 4PM


Our Story

The Exquisite Corpse Company LLC is a multidisciplinary performance art company based out of Brooklyn, New York. Our mission is to develop new, multi-disciplinary performances borne of collaboration between Brooklyn based artists. In doing so, we create a transformative, immersive event wherein theater, film, visual installation, music, and dance collide, repel, and interweave.

This is our third year as a company. We premiered our first production, an original play by company member Tess Howsam, at the NYC International Fringe Festival and the Encore Series at the SoHo Playhouse. In the following years we mounted 2 immersive collaborative projects; ODD.A.SEE; an ambitious retelling of Homer's classic in a 4,500 sq foot space, involving over 30 artists. And most recently, WareART:SubTerra, a three week multi-media performance event and play series produced in collaboration with HERE Arts Center NYC.

Above all, we believe in creating a community of young artists in New York who inspire and create together, and who forward our mission of making theater approachable and newly relevant to everyone.

Why We Need Your Help!

Now that we've assembled our team of artists and collaborators, we need YOU!

Thanks to you, ECC is in her third season!  Without you we could never have made it this far.

In order to make Secession 2015 a reality, we need to raise $8,000.

Not to mention: Everything you donate is tax deductible!!

That's good news for your taxes, but it also means that we have an external organization providing intense oversight of how every dollar is spent. In other words, you can be sure that every dollar you donate will be put to good use for the company and this production.

How You Can Help

Every little bit helps, and we can't do this without you! Please consider donating whatever you can.

As thanks for your donation, you'll get one of these super awesome gifts (shown on the right) from our creative team.

We will build Secession 2015 from your generosity, and are extraordinarily grateful for any contribution you can make.

Other Ways to Help

Come see Secession 2015 and spread the word!

Share this campaign with your family and friends on Facebook, Twitter or wherever else you make yourself known. We are so grateful for any and all help we can get, so thank you in advance for your generous support! Find us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram!

To You

We are supremely confident in the merits of this project, and we have put together an incredible team of collaborators-- writers, actors, designers and crew. We know this is an ambitious undertaking but we are energized by the challenges, and excited to share this brilliant project with YOU!

Love and Thanks from the Core Corpses,

Tess Howsam, Dana Steinhoff, Blaire O'Leary, Emma Walton, Blake Bishton, Tara Elliot, and Sarah Gosses.

 ...and the cast, writers, and artists of Secession 2015.

story:
Who We Are

The Young Americans' Theatre Company is Seattle's only entirely youth run theatre company. Founded back in 2008 by a group of High School students, YATC's mission is to produce work that speaks to, inspires, and authentically provokes discussion within the young Seattle community. Every summer we produce a full season, including a festival of one acts and two main stage shows, which has become a vibrant, award winning and unique part of Seattle youth culture and the theatre community. 

There are no adults involved with YATC. Instead, we provide artists between the ages of 14 and 21 with the opportunity to act, direct, tech and design the shows. Through YATC, youth also get the opportunity to learn about business, marketing and management via the summer intern program and board of directors. Each year, a new board of students takes over the company’s administration, keeping it fresh and relevant. 

The opportunity to learn about business, marketing and program management is absolutely critical for high school students who are attempting to decide what their passions are and what to pursue later in life. As the only program of it's kind in Seattle, working with YATC can be life changing.

As we get ready to kick off Season 8, we need your support!


Where Does Your Money Go? Here is the break down:

  • Venue: Every year, we rent a real theater space to keep our shows professional. This year we are performing at Eclectic Theatre located in the heart of Seattle on Capitol Hill.
  • Rights: We are dedicated to producing quality theatre that directors are excited about, which means that play rights can sometimes be a little pricey.
  • Marketing: We want to extend our impact on the Seattle community through outreach and publicity. 
  • Intern Program: Our Summer Intern Program gives teens a chance to learn about all the aspects of running a theatre company and help out with the season.
  • Tech: We want to make sure that the technical elements of our performances are as high quality as the acting and directing that we put so much work into. 
  • Design: This year, we are launching a brand new design team! This team will work on sets, costumes and props for the shows, getting more teen artists involved in YATC and improving the quality of our season. Starting a new program is difficult and our design team needs resources to work with to do it's job.

This is why, this year more than ever, we need your generous donations to help YATC be the best it has ever been.


The Impact

 At YATC, we go beyond non-profit. Participation with YATC in any capacity is completely free. This means that teenagers from all over Seattle get the opportunity to participate in the arts without having to pay for expensive summer camps. Instead, we rely on funds from ticket sales, concessions, and donations to keep YATC up and running.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unabe to donate this year, there are other ways that you can help:

  • See a Show: We have an amazing season coming up this July.
  • Spread the Word: Tell your friends about YATC and share this campaign. 

And that's all there is to it.

Learn More

Visit us at http://www.youngamericanstheatreco.org/

story:
Dance+Theater+Ice

Established in 2007, Brownbody is a non-profit performing arts repertory company. It's artistic work combines modern dance, figure skating, theater, and a multitude of other artistic genres.  Brownbody’s on ice and stage work focuses on stories and topics relevant to communities of color. It is interested in extending the translation of bounded realities to tell stories. Brownbody extends these boundaries by making the ice a viable medium for cultural expression. Some of Brownbody's past artistic work includes Aunt Sara's Escape, a work exploring the exploitation and visual objectification of Saartjie Baartman (also known as the "Venus Hottentot") and Living Past (Re)memory, a piece focused on Toni Morrison's classic novel, Beloved and the theme of (re)memory.

Brownbody's newest work, Quiet As It's Kept, explores narratives rooted in the Reconstruction era. It uses the ice to capture the complex and layered nature of this period and the rise of Jim Crow. This work is developed in collaboration with celebrated Twin Cities actor and vocalist, Thomasina Petrus. It will take place at Victory Memorial Ice Arena (1900 42nd Avenue N., Minneapolis) on Friday May 1st and Saturday May 2nd.

Help us match our grant funding and ticket sales

We're extremely grateful to our supporters, including the Metropolitan Regional Arts Council (MRAC) and corporate sponsors of the event. Expenses for ice practices and performances, and much more is costly.  We are in need of an additional $20,000 to insure the success of this event. Your contribution would help cover:

Icetime Rental for Practices and Performances
Staging for Audience Seating
Theatrical Staging in the Arena

We've been selected to receive a grant, however, we are required to raise outside money to earn their grant -and that is where YOU come in!

Your gift will support a unique experience for college and high shool students

This production includes three performances and post show discussions for Minneapolis and Saint Paul Public high school and college students. We're committed to showing them art that breaks all preconceptions of how story and art can come together. We are excited to see the creativity unleashed by this new experiences. For many, this will be the first time seeing this unique means of telling a story.

Help bring that moment of discovery to students and general audiences alike!

Sure, you can just buy a ticket.

We'd love for you to be part of our next performance. If contributing here isn't right for you, please visit Brownbody.org to learn about tickets for the performances. 

At minimum, we invite you to share the message about this work! Please, use the social links to share this on Facebook and Twitter or anywhere else you share what matters to you.

At minimum, we invite you to share the message about this work! Please, use the social links to share this on Facebook and Twitter or anywhere else you share what matters to you.

story:
Short Summary

Every year at Italia Conti Academy of Theatre Arts the 2nd year BA Acting students fundraise in order to take two plays to the famous Edinburgh Fringe Festival.

They spend the entire academic year fundraising, with no financial aid from anyone, at the same time as studying 5 days a week at the drama school.

This year, we are doing exactly that and we need your help! We are a group of 28 acting students age 19-25. We are performing two shows (yet to be decided) from 24th-29th August 2015 at a great venue called 'The Space.' So far we have held quiz nights, parties, bake sales, set up fundraising bars at events etc. We hope that, with help from family and friends, we can use our Indiegogo page to help us raise £2000 towards our total.

What We Need

We need to raise £12,000 in total and would like to raise £2,000 of that via our Indiegogo page...
  • This is to cover the cost of; venue hire, registering our shows, accomodation, transport, promotion etc...

The Impact

The importance of taking our shows to Edinburgh is so great...here are a few reasons why....

  • The experience of performing in public before we embark into our final year is so valuable. Up until now our shows have been 'in house'. This is our first public performance before we start rehearsing and performing our final year shows, where we invite agents/casting directors, so to have already performed to a paying, public audience would be so useful and perhaps make 3rd year seem less daunting!
  • The experience of working as a company, and organising not just one but two shows would be so helpful! Once we graduate as actors in the 'real world', we are very aware that there will not always be enough acting work for us all, so the ability to be able to create and fundraise our own theatre and work is crucial!
  • The experience of working as a team and an ensemble is essential in this industry! We must know how it feels, and how to cooperate as a team in order to get the job done and ensure we can produce the best piece of theatre possible.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that you may not be able to financially contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

    • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
    • Please use the Indiegogo share tools, if you know of anyone who could help!
    • Please come and watch our plays at The Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2015! In the new year we will have more details of how you can book tickets!


    Thank you so much for taking the time to read this!

    All our love,

    The Italia Conti Academy of Theatre Art's 2nd Years x

story:
Who we are:
We are STaG and this year we are taking our 2015 New Works winner, Styx, to the Edinburgh Fringe. STaG is the largest student theatre company in Scotland based in the University of Glasgow. We put on a variety of shows each year ranging from Shakespeare to new pieces written by our own members such as Styx. We have taken a new show to the Edinburgh fringe for the past eight years and we want to make sure we continue to bring new pieces of theatre to life on stage at the Edinburgh Fringe, with the murderously funny Styx. 


STYX:
Styx is a tragi-comic thriller about love and accidental murder. James Orphan musters his courage and ventures to the windswept and isolated village of Styx. His mission: to win back ex-girlfriend Eilidh and prove that he isn’t nearly as wet as everybody thinks. However, the weather is foul and he must first negotiate a fearful prophecy, cantankerous villagers and the malevolent plotting of disturbed local post-boy Eric Spinge. Can James accomplish his mission before tragedy strikes? Will disaster ruin any chance of love and a happy ending? Will the egg of fate be overcooked? 

Winner of the 2015 New Works Festival, Styx is not to be missed; expect thrilling grotesquery, whirlwinds of emotion and occasional bad puns in this tragi-comic tale of love and murderous intent.



What your money will go to:
Going to the fringe is not easy and costs quite a bit. When you donate you will be helping cover the cost of the venue, giving our cast and crew a place to live while in Edinburgh as well as the licence to allow us to perform at the fringe! Any amount of money you want to donate to the show will be greatly appreciated by all of the Styx crew.


Other ways to help:
You don't have to donate to help us out, simply sharing our show on Facebook and twitter would also help us out hugely! So go give us a like and follow us and spread the word!

story:
We've reached our Phase 1 Goal! Help us reach our Phase 2: Artist Stipend Goal of $7,500.

 

2015 marks the fifth anniversary of Spark Movement Collective, and Chelsea Koenig and the dancers of Spark will premiere two new dance productions to celebrate.

The Golden Shoe opens April 18 at the Town School on the Upper East Side with original music by Justin Reardon. This new work tailored for children explores two versions of the classic fairytale Cinderella.  The performance begins with the story of Rhodopis, set in ancient Egypt, and continues with Ella, which takes place in a modern high school.  Together, these pieces address themes of empathy, anti-bullying, and compassion, exposing new audiences to the power of storytelling through dance.  

Spark returns to the Actors Fund Arts Center in Downtown Brooklyn September 18-19 with an evening-length work focusing on identity.  This innovative piece features new choreography by Artistic Director Chelsea Koenig and Assistant Artistic Director Matt Dittes.  


For the past five years, Spark has achieved its mission of providing accessible dance experiences due to the generosity of family, friends, and patrons.  Now more than ever, we need your support to help fund our most ambitious season.  A tax-deductible donation of any amount will bring us closer to our goal!


We've reached our Phase 1 Goal and have received a $2,000 challenge grant!
(The $2,000 award is not included in Indiegogo's total on the upper right)

Phase 1: Venue Rental
Goal: $4,600

Spark must raise $4,600 to cover operational costs associated with the production, which includes the rental fees for the Town School and the Actors Fund Arts Center in addition to the rehearsal space needed to create both shows.  

Phase 2: Artist Stipends
Goal: $2,900

The second phase of our campaign provides stipends for the artists. Spark’s dancers are incredibly talented and creative performers who are so dedicated to their craft and the company that they donate their time. Our dancers spend months in rehearsal studios developing and refining choreography, including 50+ hours preparing for each show. This goal also includes musicians, costume designers, and other crucial personnel.  


Q: If you are selling tickets to the performance why do you need to raise money outside of the Box Office?

A: Ticket Sales typically cover a very small percentage of production costs for most performing arts organizations. Spark relies on contributions from private donors to be able to produce affordable performances for the public.


Q: How long does it take to create a performance like this?

A: Spark rehearses 3-6 hours a week for 5 months when developing a new work. Chelsea Koenig also works independently with composers and graphic designers to integrate additional art mediums into the show.

Help spread the word about Spark and our campaign on Facebook. The bigger our reach, the bigger our impact.

story:
What WDMC Is Up To Now

After receiving praise from audiences and critics alike for their smash hit productions of Much Ado about Nothing and Romeo & Juliet in 2014, Queens Shakespeare in partnership with What Dreams May Co brings audiences part 2 of its 2015 Season with a controversial, brutal, modern re-imagining of the classical theatre’s most horrifying yet soul searching work. Join us as we shine the looking glass on men worshiped as gods, vengeful gods walking amongst men, and the destructive might of men turned mob. Next up…Euripides’ The Bacchae.

Director Christina Sheehan (Director of 2013’s critically acclaimed Macbeth) brings audiences back to a ravaged world always on the brink of chaos. Featuring the world premiere of a modern one-act prequel to The Bacchae, The Sisters of Semele by Chris Rivera and set in the same post-apocalyptic universe explored in Julius Caesar, we now Journey to the land of Thebes. A young king is newly come into his rule and a young demigod has newly come into his power. The conflict between these two cousins pitting man VS Maenad, and force VS faith, is at its core two boys throwing a tantrum in trying to prove themselves to the world and to their families. When such squabbles occur between gods and kings the stakes become dangerous, the consequences become deadly. 


Classics for a Cause

Every Thursday & Saturday at 10:00PM after the performance of The Bacchae will be a special benefit production of Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead by Bert V. Royal. 50% of all proceeds will benefit The Trevor Project, the leading national organization focused on suicide prevention efforts among lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning and other queer youth. 

Co-Directors Chris Rivera (Director of 2014’s critically acclaimed Romeo & Juliet and our smash hit production of Julius Caesar earlier this season) and Bloo Rodriguez (Assistance Director of Julius Caesar and Assistant Director of The Secret Theater’s sellout production of Macbeth) take us back to a time in which millennials where called something different, high school students. A place where labels turn whole people into nothing more than their respective cliques: jock, bully, stoner, geek, and queer. Using the fashion and musical stylings of the late ‘90s/early 2000s and asking the question “what if the eternal children from the comics we read grew up?” provide the perfect vehicle for a flashback to a time where things should have been simple, but never were. A time where you were “different” in a school filled with people who all pretend to be the same.

DOG SEES GOD has not been authorized or approved in any manner by the Charles M. Schultz Estate or United Features Syndicate, which have no responsibility for its content.

Why Do We Need Your Help?

We are performing right in the heart of Times Square!  We are so excited to be producing at John DeSotelle Studio this winter!  Now that our rent is going up, any help you can give will be felt even more deeply.  Here's a breakdown of what you can do:

If you donate $90 you will be covering the price of a week of rehearsals.

If you donate $150 you will be covering the price of our programs.

If you donate $200 you will be covering the price of our photographer.

If you donate $1000 you will cover half a weekend of performances.

If you donate $2000 you will cover a full weekend of performances.

A contribution of any size will help us to make things happen, and makes you a part of the artistic process! So choose your favorite perk and join the team!

Who Is WDMC?

Founded in 2011, What Dreams May Co. is dedicated to making the classics accessible to all. Simple, minimalistic productions leave the focus on the language and characters, challenging the actors in the company to reach new levels and expand their knowledge of the classics. Passionate performances delve to the heart of the text, bringing the story to life in a way that connects with and immerses modern audiences. After all, “What dreams may come, when we have shuffled off this mortal coil, must give us pause.” With our productions, we hope every person has a chance to experience that moment to pause, be touched by the beauty of the language, and carry that experience with them into the world.

Who Is Queens Shakespeare?

Founded in 2005 by Nanette Asher, Queens Shakespeare, Inc. is a not-for-profit professional theatrical company, which serves Queens County and the greater New York City area. Its aim is to act as a laboratory for actors of all ages and experience levels to explore classical works and to perform in fully produced, accessible, and innovative productions. Each season one production is developed as an educational tour which is then presented at different venues throughout the state. Producing and touring in this fashion allows the company to actively contribute to the growth and vibrancy of the developing Queens arts scene, while at the same time exposing classical works to modern audiences through the educational tour.


Your friends at WDMC and Queens Shakespeare,

Chrissy and Jonathan

story:
Please note: Some of our contributors have been having trouble processing donations. We apologize for the inconvenience and suggest you try donating and second or third time until the transaction is made. (This seems to work.) The site are aware of this issue.

Short Summary

Founded by a group of two young artists in the early stages of a career in opera, Piccalilli Opera Company aims to bring opera to areas within the UK where people have not had the opportunity to enjoy the art-form, beginning with Scarborough, the company’s home. In doing this we are joining with others to combat exclusivity within the performing arts. Piccalilli is also intent on offering opportunities for young artists in the early stages of their career who are keen to gain valuable experience in what is a highly competitive industry. 

Our first project, planned for Summer 2016, will celebrate the 400th Anniversary of Shakespeare’s death, highlighting how composers such as Verdi, Purcell, Handel and Britten strove to set the words of this profound playwright to music. We are in the process of applying to Arts Council England for a £15,000 grant to support this venture. 

For this production to be a success, however, we must firstly establish our identity within the local community and raise awareness of the company and its ambitions. We are delighted to have the support of local resident Lady Heather Ayckbourn, actress and local artistic figurehead, who has agreed to become head patron for the company. With her support, we plan to launch the company in Scarborough on the 20th February 2016. The launch will showcase the talent of a number of young singers, directors and designers, together with a short presentation of our short and long term aspirations for the company.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise a total of £1500 which will be used to facilitate the travel and accommodation of the artists as well as other event costs. If you think you might be able to donate any amount to help us raise these funds and support the company at this early stages, we would be extremely grateful.
In return for your contribution we have all sorts of perks in store from personalized thank you letters, free tickets to our first production and the service of our talented singers at a private event.
If you feel unable to provide us with any financial support, we would still be more than happy to keep you up to date with the progress of the company and any upcoming events. All we ask is that you spread the word about Piccalilli by visiting us on Facebook and Twitter!

story:
WHAT?

The second production of NYC-based company The Woolgatherers, Genesis 22 seeks to unlock new layers of meaning from a classic tale of humanity and faith.  Is Abraham, the father who nearly sacrifices his son, Isaac, a man of faith or a brutal killer? With a diverse group of young, ambitious artists, we're also experimenting with collaboration and a new method of making theater. Our creative team features six directors, each of whom approaches their art with a distinct style and methodology. By exploring an old story through the intersection of their artistic forms, we hope to discover a deeper understanding of this story of faith.

WHERE?

We will spend the month of July working and performing in 408A Colonels Row on Governors Island, a residency granted to us by the Trust for Governors Island.  The structure was originally established as housing for officers and their families in the 1870s. We invite our audience to meander, skip, and run through the grand architecture of this historic space as they join us in exploring an iconic story.

WHY?

Genesis 22 will hold open rehearsals every week and offer pay-what-you-can ticketing in order to create a theatrical environment that is participatory, challenging, and accessible to all.  By prioritizing stylistic, racial, and cultural diversity, we strive to subvert expectations and cast old narratives in a new light as we explore visceral honesty, ecstatic spirit, and communal empathy. The Woolgatherers always seek to make theater that shatters assumptions about the heights storytelling can reach. 

WHO?

We are thrilled to have assembled a team consisting of both old friends and new collaborators! Part of The Woolgatherers' mission is to foster a community of like-minded artists in New York City who support, engage with, and inspire each other, no matter their approach, technique, or methodology. This team is a giant step towards establishing and growing that community.

HOW?

Art could never happen without the support and generosity of its audiences. This summer, we're exploring how to craft a big theatrical experience from a tiny budget. But we still need some funding for our minimal set, publicity, rehearsal space before our residency starts. We ask that you give within your means and garner yourself a little #ArtKarma along the way, or if you're unable to give financially, help us out by spreading the word on social media. And, of course, we hope to see you on Governors Island come July!

But we still need some funding for our minimal set, publicity, rehearsal space before our residency starts. We ask that you give within your means and garner yourself a little #ArtKarma along the way, or if you're unable to give financially, help us out by spreading the word on social media. And, of course, we hope to see you on Governors Island come July!

story:
Masterclass Jan Fabre Teaching Group -

Projet

« The series of exercises focuses on systematically refining and optimising the quest for the potential of the physical acting (also known as ‘physiological’ acting). The exploration of the evocative imagination of the ‘body as a whole’ is a leitmotif here. In exercises with titles such as ‘the old man’, ‘the tiger’, ‘the insect’, or ‘rice paper/fire’, it’s neither the imitation nor the psychological aspect which takes centre stage, but the exploration of the physical potential of the transforming body. Here, Fabre attaches great importance to breathing, the use of explosive energy, and the articulations of head, torso, and limbs. A lot of input is drawn from the kinetics of cold and warm-blooded animals. »

Ce stage est très important pour moi et la démarche artistique que j’entreprends. Ce que Jan Fabre fait est directement enligné avec ce que j’aspire à faire. Je veux ramener plus de Fabre à Québec

L’art performatif mélangé avec le théâtre, c’est ce que je fais. Fabre aussi. Lui et moi on est fait pour se rencontrer.

Plus précisément, ma démarche se définie par la recherche formelle sur la performance et le théâtre. J’approche toujours les créations par une question qui m'amène de plus en plus près d’une définition du théâtre, de la performance, de l’art. C’est ce qui me nourrit, c’est ce qui me donne une raison de créer. Je cherche donc des opportunités qui pourraient nourrir ma démarche et la rendre intelligente. L’état créateur (pour moi) passe par la recherche constante, le doute, la nuance et n’est jamais statique; c’est comme ça qu’il reste vivant! Et je tiens à ce qu’il reste vivant. Le théâtre mort ne m’intéresse pas, même en tant que spectatrice.

Objectif

Ce merveilleux stage coûte 800 euros. En canadien, ça tourne autour de 1200$

J’ai donc pour objectif de ramasser 800$ en vendant des dessins et/ou en ramassant des dons

Contreparties

Dessins

Dessins personnalisés : En échange d'un don, je vous envoie un dessin personnalisé. 

J’aime beaucoup cette option, car ça me donne l’occasion de prendre le temps penser à la personne pour lui faire un dessin qui la représente bien!

Reproduction : Avec cette option, vous devrez faire un choix parmi les dessins disponibles pour la reproduction. La section ''reproduction'' de mon site web expose les choix disponibles.

Originaux: Avec cette option, vous devrez faire un choix parmi les dessins originaux que j'ai. La section ''originaux'' de mon site web expose les choix disponibles.

La dernière fois que j’ai fait ce type de levée de fond, j’ai réussi à amasser plus de 500$. J’ai beaucoup aimé mon expérience et je pense que les gens ont apprécié leur dessin également! Je n’ai pas encore réussi à les distribuer tous. Cette fois-ci je ne me ferai pas prendre; Si je ne vous croise pas, je vais vous les envoyer par la poste.

Activité

Atelier: Pour ceux et celles qui pourraient être intéressé.es, j’aimerais organiser un atelier de partage où j’aurais la possibilité de transmettre ce que j’aurai reçu. Selon les personnes qui manifesteront leur intérêt, l’endroit et le moment seront à déterminer


Pour avoir une idée de ce que je fais

Vous pouvez consulter mon site web au https://claudellehlabrecque.wordpress.com/dessins/

story:
Our Baby Grew Up So Quickly

Hard to believe, but this is the 5th year for the Improv Festival of Cincinnati, lovingly nicknamed "IF Cincy," brought to you by OTRimprov. Over the years, our goal has remained the same: to bring the world's best improvisers to Cincinnati for one weekend of unforgettable performances and intimate workshops for all levels. The Queen City has a remarkable passion for the arts, and that includes improv. As our festival audiences have continued to grow year after year, it's clear Cincinnati is ready for more! 

2018 is a big year for IF Cincy - not only are we turning 5, but we're also moving to a new venue (Memorial Hall OTR) and adding even more performances! There better be cake.

Play Nice with Your Friends    

IF Cincy is a festival everyone wants to attend. Past performers have commented on how beautiful our city is and how welcoming the audiences are. Audiences share the delight of enjoying a broad range of troupes from all over the world. But we can't do it alone. In order to continue to produce a festival that attracts artists and audiences from all over, we need help from our generous supporters to help fund IF Cincy. 

 

Make Good Choices

We couldn't wait to start lining up performers for year 5! So while everyone else has been freezing their popsicles off this winter in Cincinnati, we've been hard at work booking improv troupes. We're proud to announce our headliners for IF Cincy 2018 --

Broke Gravy (Portland, OR)

Bearded Company (Minneapolis, MN)

Working Title (Atlanta, GA) featuring Amber Nash and Kevin Gillese of Dad's Garage Theatre Co.

Emily Fightmaster (Chicago, IL)

Remember, It's Always Nice to Share!

If you can't support our campaign by donating, it's cool! But please consider spreading the word about IF Cincy 2018 to the masses. This is the one time we'll tell you it's okay to talk about other people - and by "other people" we mean us! Check out our website, follow us on social media, and tell your friends to come see a show.

story:
Help us take Petrichor to the 2012 SummerWorks Performance Festival in Toronto.

It's a great opportunity for us, and we need your help to do it.

Petrichor is a new play written by Erin Brandenburg (Reesor, Pelee) with music by Andrew Penner (Sunparlour Players) and Henry Adam Svec (CFL Sessions, Folk Songs of Canada Now, Peter Mansbridge and the CBC's) that tells the story of a family of Mennonite migrant farm workers on a vegetable farm in Southern Ontario. Told with original music and played on handmade instruments made from recycled and reclaimed materials, Petrichor tells a story of work and land, home and loss and how you can find love hoeing a row of tomatoes. 

Featuring performances by Monica Dottor, Shannon Taylor, Andrew Penner, Kevin MacDonald, Henry Adam Svec, and David Tompa with instruments made by Iner Souster (The Sixth) and images and animation by Howie Shia (PPF House).

    

Here's What We Need:

Your contributions towards our goal of $2200 will help to cover the basic costs of putting up a show for this festival.  

These include: 

Rehearsal space rental - $750

costumes, set materials, props - $240

festival fees - $735

transportation - $25

script printing - $50

Posters/postcards/publicity - $400

This way all box office revenue can go to the artists.  

Any amount is appreciated and to help get the donations rolling we've added some great perks.  Check them out to your right.

 

About Kitchenband

Kitchenband made its company debut in April 2009 as part of HATCH: emerging performance projects at Harbourfront Centre with a workshop presentation of Petrichor.  Our group first began working together in 2007 to create Reesor (“NNNNN – grass roots theatre at its best”, “**** Reesor points Canadian theatre in the right direction”), written by Erin Brandenburg and Lauren Taylor with music by Andrew Penner.  We most recently presented a project called Detroit Time Machine, an instrument and video installation and music performance project at the 2011 Rhubarb Festival in Toronto and at Nuit Blanche North in Huntsville, ON in July 2011.  From 2010-2012 Kitchenband has been a company in Residence at The Theatre Centre where we have been developing a new project called Boblo that combines musical performance, radio transmission, images and design to tell the history of an abandoned amusement park on an island in the Detroit River.  This will be premier in a co-production with the Theatre Centre in fall 2012. 

If you can’t donate, please help us spread the word about our indiegogo campaign!

story:
Our Story

Pipeline Theatre Company closes its 3rd season with Timberlake Wertenbaker's The Ash Girl in April of 2012 at the Connelly Theatre in New York City. 

PIPELINE THEATRE COMPANY is a downtown Manhattan-based non-profit theater company, comprised of 25 emerging actors, directors, writers and designers. Pipeline hopes to produce stories that stick somewhere in your heart, your brain, or your guts.  Productions include: The Love of the Nightingale, Tim Chawaga's Sleepless City (World Premiere), Psycho Beach Party, Alex Mills' Shakespeare the Dead (World Premiere, 2010 Dream Up Fest at Theater for the New City), Bekah Brunstetter's Fat Kids on Fire (directed by Tony nominee Peter Frechette), The Caucasian Chalk Circle (Winner! 2011 NYIT Awars for Original Music, Cormac Bluestone - Composer, and Nominated for 2011 NYIT Award for Lighting Design) and Colby Day's Felix & The Diligence (World Premiere).


Our Brave New Works, Whisper & SHOUT, and Hung Up series, produced in tandem with our mainstages, develop and support adventurous original material and deepen connections with our ever expanding network of artists.

  

The Impact

Pipeline prides itself on our collectivity and the empowerment of our peers by offering the opportunity for full-scale, fully funded, fully organized and realized Off-Off Broadway productions.

We thrive on adventure and believe no story is worth telling without a little risk. We love our villains as much as our heroes, especially in those puzzling moments when we can’t quite tell them apart. The Ash Girl promises to engage your imagination and take you on a unique, and unexpected journey. 

 

What We Need

We've almost reached our goal, but we need a little help to raise the last $2000 of our budget. 

Your donations will directly go to the purchasing of materials, props, costumes, etc.

 

$20 will pay for two hours of rehearsal space 

$50 will provide a full costume for one of our cast members

$100 will pay for enough wood to build half of the set

 

Any amount, big or small is greatly appreciated and incredibly helpful!

To claim your ticketing perk, e-mail fcontreras@pipelinetheatre.org for verification and availability. **Must be chosen as a perk through IndieGoGo

Thank you for helping to make this wonderful show a reality!

                 

-The Ash Girl Team

story:
Our Story

The Santa Barbara Ring Shout Project has been invited to participate in the historical first closeout of the Lorenzo Dow Turner's exhibit, July 23, 2011. The event will be held at the Smithsonian Institute's Anacostia Community Museum, Washington, D.C.   

 

Ring Shout was a dance-like form of religious worship done by African-American slaves, mostly before the Civil War.  It involves moving in a counterclockwise circle, call & response singing, clapping, stomping and beating on the floor rhythmically with a stick or broom.  Our blues, jazz, and rock & roll stem from Ring Shout.  Today Ring Shout is being revived into a cultural art form. 

 

Frances Moore of will be one of the delegates to this event where they plan to create the largest Ring Shout circle in history by having all four of the U.S. Ring Shout performance groups in attendance.  There are three groups in and one in .  The S.B. Shouters will be representing all of in this celebration.  We look forward to becoming an item in the Guinness Book of World Records.  We are planning on leaving for on July 19, 2011.

The Impact

Today, Ring Shout is being revived into a cultural art form.  The goal of the revival is to have a Ring Shout group in every state so that African Americans can celebrate and pass on to future generations this part of their rich heritage.

 

What We Need & What You Get

The Santa Barbara Ring Shout Project needs your financial assistance to provide transportation and hotel accommodations for ten local ring shout dancers from the ages of four to sixty seven to participate in this historical event in  from July 19th - July 25th. 

 

Our participation will enable us to learn all we can from the few remaining practitioners of Ring Shout, and the people who have studied and written about Ring Shout. We will learn to do Ring Shout in as authentic a manner as is possible. Upon our return to , we will continue a small performance troupe which will incorporate our new skills and demonstrate and share Ring Shout at local schools, churches, and special events. 

Other Ways You Can Help

events The SB shouter hosted a dance to the Sounds of Motown on Friday, May 27th in the Multi-purpose room of Trinitty Episcoal Church and will have several small performances at the Saturday Farmer's Market in downtown Santa Barbara.  All proceeds from our fundraising activities will go towards the Shouters trip to Washington, D.C.

story:
Short Summary

There is a social crisis in America right now: POVERTY.

Growing up poor in Detroit, Michigan I experienced first-hand the affects of poverty on an individual, a family, and a community. As an actress, playwright, and community organizer, I've worked to use performance to help people in poor communities grow.

I'mma Do Me is a one-woman show I wrote 7 years ago while in college in response to poverty in America. 13 characters ranging in age, ethnicities, gender, & socio-economic backgrounds come to life to offer their persepctive on this social crisis and the "self-preservation" mentality that's prevalent in society today.

After trillions of dollars spent to address poverty, hundreds of government bailouts, fifteen script drafts, and a recession, it's finally time for I'mma Do Me to take the stage. This production needs sound, lights, video (and people to run it all) 

So please give a lot or a little to help this story/these stories be told.

story:
Re:Definition is a play inspired by Glenn Gordon's real life experiences after discovering his ancestry through DNA testing.  The mundane way this monumental information of his ancestry was received by parents, friends and strangers produced a hilarious and musically entertaining commentary on race, history and identity that questions the meaning of "blackness" and personifies the white supremacy ingrained in African Americans.  It is a pleasing blend of musical and comedic timing, able to heal past wounds across ethnicities with the medicinal benefits of laughter. 

It's a pleasing blend of song, dance and humor, all of which carry medicinal qualities.

 Chadwick Boseman, a veteran of the hip hop theater aesthetic, came to a closed reading of Re:definition in its infantile stages, and fell in love with the work. 


 "I knew right away that it was something that I wanted to do.  It was important work.  It was fun work. I knew that an audience would have a good time receiving the satirical catharsis this play offers." - Chadwick Boseman (director)

The Impact

It would simply be a shame for this piece to reach the eyes and ears of its potential audience at a diminished quality.  When the play has been described in the past, many make the mistake of thinking that it's a one person piece.  Yet, after several industry professionals saw the workshops of the material, they agreed that a one-person play approach is the wrong tactic for tackling this work.  


It's like Euripides, because it's satire and you need the Greek chorus, and the lead actor.  On another level, you can do it with projections and the whole nine.  But bare minimum, you need these other characters, who Glenn names The Rhythms, to understand the divisive effect of race within the individual.  The two beat boxers and two singers are all parts of Glenn.   Like an Anna Deveare Smith or Sarah Jones, Glenn is switching in and out of characters, which allows you to dually experience the double consciousness that is described by Fanon and Dubois, while the rhythms create a soundscape pop culture through which the ancestral voice speaks to him.  Watching this exorcist while you're laughing definitely helps the point

Watching this exorcist while laughing makes you forget that you too are being Re:Defined.

Just a "Black Thing"?

Far from it.  One of the most damaging wounds of chattel slavery, the middle passage and the miseducation of enslaved Africans has been the inability to claim specific lineage in Africa.  Without being preachy, Glenn's play advocates the importance in gaining this information.  After watching this play, I'm positive that many people of African descent will become open to taking their own DNA tests.   At the same time, the play invites people of other ethnicities into the dialogue/joke.  The bottom line is that it's good art with social validity.   


Re:definition's humor, music and social commentary give it the potential to have a long life in the theatrical circuit.  It's style could give it relevance in a lot of non-traditional houses.  But we believe, if given the proper attention, that it could have legs in an intimate Broadway house.  And we believe your contribution is aiding us in that goal.  Shows like "Bridge and Tunnel", "Fela" and "Passing Strange" show that a play like this can have a viable audience on the Broadway stage.  

What We Need & What You Get

La Mama, the theater house of this production and The Hip HopTheater festival, the presenting agent will provide some publicity and some of the technical needs for the show, but the Re:definition team must cover most of the cost of development, which includes payment of actors, cost of rehearsal space, cheap amps and microphones for rehearsal, performance level microphones for the beat boxing and vocal soundscape during tech and performance. Performance level microphones have not been honored in our tech writer along with the lights and sound that the presenter and house will provide. will be a meager payment for the five actors (Glenn and the four rhythms), provide sufficient rehearsal space for four weeks of musical and movement oriented rehearsal.  Rental of the microphones and purchasing them is nearly the same price, approximately $1300, so it may be beneficial for the Re:definition team to buy this item to ensure the quality of future manifestations of the production in off-Broadway houses as we seek our Broadway goal.  


If we don't reach our entire goal, the money will go towards a lesser version of Re:Definition, yet another workshop, which honestly would be counter productive to the plays development.


TIERS OF CONTRIBUTION


Angel - Those giving $50-$199 will receive special mention in the play program and the Re:Definition EP CD with songs from the play.


Sponsor - Those giving $200-$499 will receive program mention, the Re:Definition CD and a signed copy of the script.


Associate Producer - Those giving $500-and above will receive program mention, shout out on the cd, the CD, signed copy of the script and two tickets to the play.  Add to or begin your entertainment career with this authentic credit, which will be honored as such in our program. 


Producer/Developers - Those giving $1000-and above will receive the Motherland Package, which includes the prizes in the lower tiers of giving and your own personal DNA test so you can have your own Re:Definition experience.  Add to or begin your entertainment career with this authentic credit.  You will be honored in our program as a producer of this production and forever be named in the manifestation of future productions as a Developer.    


Other Ways You Can Help

You may also help if you have a rehearsal space in New York City.  A good rehearsal space is as good as money, because it will cut rehearsal costs considerably.  We will value your rehearsal space and place it in its proper tier based upon usage.   You can also get the word out about the play and our campaign to raise money for the play.
story_txt:
Re:Definition is a play inspired by Glenn Gordon's real life experiences after discovering his ancestry through DNA testing.  The mundane way this monumental information of his ancestry was received by parents, friends and strangers produced a hilarious and musically entertaining commentary on race, history and identity that questions the meaning of "blackness" and personifies the white supremacy ingrained in African Americans.  It is a pleasing blend of musical and comedic timing, able to heal past wounds across ethnicities with the medicinal benefits of laughter. 
It's a pleasing blend of song, dance and humor, all of which carry medicinal qualities.
 Chadwick Boseman, a veteran of the hip hop theater aesthetic, came to a closed reading of Re:definition in its infantile stages, and fell in love with the work. 

 "I knew right away that it was something that I wanted to do.  It was important work.  It was fun work. I knew that an audience would have a good time receiving the satirical catharsis this play offers." - Chadwick Boseman (director)

The Impact
It would simply be a shame for this piece to reach the eyes and ears of its potential audience at a diminished quality.  When the play has been described in the past, many make the mistake of thinking that it's a one person piece.  Yet, after several industry professionals saw the workshops of the material, they agreed that a one-person play approach is the wrong tactic for tackling this work.  

It's like Euripides, because it's satire and you need the Greek chorus, and the lead actor.  On another level, you can do it with projections and the whole nine.  But bare minimum, you need these other characters, who Glenn names The Rhythms, to understand the divisive effect of race within the individual.  The two beat boxers and two singers are all parts of Glenn.   Like an Anna Deveare Smith or Sarah Jones, Glenn is switching in and out of characters, which allows you to dually experience the double consciousness that is described by Fanon and Dubois, while the rhythms create a soundscape pop culture through which the ancestral voice speaks to him.  Watching this exorcist while you're laughing definitely helps the point
Watching this exorcist while laughing makes you forget that you too are being Re:Defined.
Just a "Black Thing"?
Far from it.  One of the most damaging wounds of chattel slavery, the middle passage and the miseducation of enslaved Africans has been the inability to claim specific lineage in Africa.  Without being preachy, Glenn's play advocates the importance in gaining this information.  After watching this play, I'm positive that many people of African descent will become open to taking their own DNA tests.   At the same time, the play invites people of other ethnicities into the dialogue/joke.  The bottom line is that it's good art with social validity.   

Re:definition's humor, music and social commentary give it the potential to have a long life in the theatrical circuit.  It's style could give it relevance in a lot of non-traditional houses.  But we believe, if given the proper attention, that it could have legs in an intimate Broadway house.  And we believe your contribution is aiding us in that goal.  Shows like "Bridge and Tunnel", "Fela" and "Passing Strange" show that a play like this can have a viable audience on the Broadway stage.  

What We Need & What You Get

La Mama, the theater house of this production and The Hip HopTheater festival, the presenting agent will provide some publicity and some of the technical needs for the show, but the Re:definition team must cover most of the cost of development, which includes payment of actors, cost of rehearsal space, cheap amps and microphones for rehearsal, performance level microphones for the beat boxing and vocal soundscape during tech and performance. Performance level microphones have not been honored in our tech writer along with the lights and sound that the presenter and house will provide. will be a meager payment for the five actors (Glenn and the four rhythms), provide sufficient rehearsal space for four weeks of musical and movement oriented rehearsal.  Rental of the microphones and purchasing them is nearly the same price, approximately $1300, so it may be beneficial for the Re:definition team to buy this item to ensure the quality of future manifestations of the production in off-Broadway houses as we seek our Broadway goal.  


If we don't reach our entire goal, the money will go towards a lesser version of Re:Definition, yet another workshop, which honestly would be counter productive to the plays development.

TIERS OF CONTRIBUTION

Angel - Those giving $50-$199 will receive special mention in the play program and the Re:Definition EP CD with songs from the play.

Sponsor - Those giving $200-$499 will receive program mention, the Re:Definition CD and a signed copy of the script.

Associate Producer - Those giving $500-and above will receive program mention, shout out on the cd, the CD, signed copy of the script and two tickets to the play.  Add to or begin your entertainment career with this authentic credit, which will be honored as such in our program. 

Producer/Developers - Those giving $1000-and above will receive the Motherland Package, which includes the prizes in the lower tiers of giving and your own personal DNA test so you can have your own Re:Definition experience.  Add to or begin your entertainment career with this authentic credit.  You will be honored in our program as a producer of this production and forever be named in the manifestation of future productions as a Developer.

story:
Our Story

Le Navet Bête or The Daft Turnip are 5 young men from the South West creating and performing work that they love. After studying together at the University of Plymouth, they now pursue a passion in creating new and essentially ‘fun’ work designed to appeal to people of all ages and backgrounds. The performances do not require the audience to have any knowledge of theatre and are based on the idea of ‘play’ and clowning. Developed and created with the intention to entertain, amuse and most importantly, appeal to everyone. Until now Le Navet Bete has self-funded their UK and international tours but they now need your help.

Our van - 'The Bete Mobile' gave us the ability to tour across the UK and Europe with very low expenses, this meant that in turn we could perform for free a lot of the time. However, the Bete Mobile is no longer with us. This campaign will help us buy a new van that will help us transport ourselves and props to various venues around the UK and abroad. 

Currently rehearsing our new show, Napoleon; A Defence we will be previewing in April and touring the whole of the UK from May.



The Impact


Without a van our ability to provide affordable or free performances and workshops is seriously impaired due to the high cost of hiring a vehicle. We love what we do and would hate for this to be the only reason that we couldn't show our work to as many people as possible.

What We Need & What You Get

$3000 dollars will buy us a second hand van in order to travel to venues and perform.
If we dont reach our goal we will have to hold off on our national tour until we save enough money by doing street shows around our local area.

Rest assured that this wont stop us performing, it will just slow us down in our attempt at world clowning domination!

Other Ways You Can Help


If you cant afford to donate we understand but please take the time to check out our website or youtube videos and recommend them to all your friends and even those that aren't your friends. 

You can find us here - www.lenavetbete.com or here http://www.facebook.com/lenavetbete

story:
Dear Friend, 

I am embarking on a venture that is the fulfillment of a longtime dream: Joining 

some of Austin’s most acclaimed stage veterans to form the new SPECTRUM 

THEATRE COMPANY (STC). Austin is long overdue for a group that will tell African 

American stories from our perspective and with uncompromising commitment to 

the highest production quality. 

We’re in the early stages of structuring our organization and building alliances with 

other theatre professionals, but are happy to introduce our Company Principles 

who collectively share over 75 years of experience and multiple wins of virtually 

every theatre award in the region: 

Jacqui Cross, Billy Harden, Carla Nickerson and Janis Stinson 

A crucial goal of STC is to network with other Black theater groups and put Austin 

on the national map. That goal is in sight, as we’ve been invited to perform at the 

Atlanta Black Theater Festival (ABTF) on October 3-6, 2013! 

Many of you have expressed interest in supporting an African American theater 

company. Now is the time—now is your opportunity to support a company with the 

established reputation, commitment and ability to usher in the era of quality Black 

theater in Austin Texas.

story:
Aloha & Axe

Aloha to my family and friends in and from Hawaii, and Muito axe to my "camaradas" in the world of Capoeira. My name is Kalani Ho'opai. I was born in Honolulu, Hawaii (or more specificaly, in Kalihi). I have been learning and loving capoeira for about 19 years, and 13 of those have been here in Japan . Capoeira Narahari is our group, and those of you that know us and know Mestre Beiçola, you know our history. For those who don't, our concept of training capoeira is much the same as anywhere else, but Mestre Beiçola's concept of life is based in vedic culture - helping  one another, being true to oneself, and being good to people. I can relate to that because that is basicaly what "Aloha" means.

 

This event is for no personal gain; I do not make any money what so ever. My goal is to provide an opportunity for the people of Toyama (the small country town I live in) to be exposed to the beauty of Brazilian culture and, at the same time, break the stereotype that Brazil is just soccer and scantily clad women dancing in the streets with fruit baskets on their heads. I am giving free workshops in capoeira, dança afro, and percussion, and ending the day with Toyama's first "presentação da cultura Brazileira" (presentation of Brazilian Culture), complete with Capoeira, Maculelê, Bossa Nova, Samba, and Batucada.

I have been teaching Capoeira in Toyama for 3 years. I have put on  many of my own shows with my students, but we just dont have the "star power" to pull off a show like this by ourselves.  That's why I need to bring in professionals whom I have been working with over the last 13 years to help make this an unforgettable event. In all honesty, I need much more than I am asking for in this campaign. (The entire event is going to cost, in Japanese Yen, the equivalent of 3,500 US dollars, but this campaign will help me raise $1000.) The International Association of Toyama is donating $1000 to us, and the remainder of the money I am trying to raise myself through numerous fundraisers, cook-outs  and bake sales. Sponsers are hard to come by, but that's not going to stop me from trying.

 

As I said this will only cover a portion of the entire event but every little bit helps enormously. However, even if you are unable to donate money, please be a conduit and pass this on to someone who might be able to lend a hand in some way. Moral support is also greatly appreciated.

 

Capoeira Narahari Japan Branch

Kalani Ho'opai

story:
Help us to keep our theatre going!

King's Town Players is a totally independent company that has always been privately funded...no grants! To enable us to stage the quality productions that we are known for takes far more money than you might probably imagine. Ticket sales and advertising only account for a portion of our income so we have to raise the rest by fund raising events and personal donations.

We need your help to keep our company going!

And, in exchange, we can offer you:

The satisfaction of helping to keep arts and artists in the Kingston community alive and kicking... oh and tons of tickets and other perks too!

Why We Need Your Help

King's Town Players was founded in 2010 with the belief that we love what we do and want to share that love of theatre with Kingston. In three short seasons we have produced fifteen plays, four beer dinners, one radio show and one 'found space' production. We have brought one original play to the stage and four Kingston premieres (with several more planned for this season). We have worked (played) together with several other local theatre groups, and we believe that working together is the best way to ensure our collective futures.

But something is missing... A Home. We want to develop a space where not only the King's Town Players can continue its growth, but a space where we can bring the Arts Community together. A place where ideas can be shared and developed.

We are currently working on finding that home. A spot that rehearsals, set building and Community projects can take place under one roof. Our current fundraising campaign will help us achieve this goal, but only with your support.

Please help if you can... spread the word.

Mission Statement

We created the King's Town Players with the goals:

  • To produce engaging theatrical presentations of the highest possible quality for our audience;
  • To entertain, inspire and enrich the cultural life of our community by providing rich theatre experiences;
  • To educate and nurture community members by providing hands-on learning experiences in various aspects of theatre arts for youth and adults;
  • To celebrate the creativity of those involved in theatre as actors, technical crew, playwrights, etc.; and
  • To join with other community theatres and artists for mutual assistance and enrichment.

We feel strongly that theatre is a vital part of the cultural fabric of the community and that the practice of theatre can provide an outlet for creative community involvement.

Our promise to you is that King's Town Players will continue to work hard to present top quality arts programing. We will strive to be an inclusive group working with the whole of the arts community in Kingston.

The sky's the limit. Thank you.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute financially?  Share Our Story on Facebook, Twitter, Email, Any way you can! Tell your friends! Talk us up! 

https://www.facebook.com/KingsTownPlayers

http://www.twitter.com/kingstownplayer

We thank you for your support and look forward to bringing you an amazing season!
