story:
Save the Stage!

The Stage was built in 1903 as the Farman Theater and began showing films in 1911. Over the years, the theater has gone through several renovations and name changes. We are now a non-profit theater, unique in offering both film and live performances in our large 450+ person auditorium. Our mission is to provide quality, affordable entertainment to our community and the surrounding areas.
 
We depend on our income from first-run films to continue serving our community. Unfortunately, Hollywood is making the switch to digital distribution, meaning that 35mm films are much more difficult to obtain and our current projector will soon be obsolete. Without a new projector, we'll be forced to close our historic theater.

How you can help:

We need $15,000 for the down payment and installation of a new digital projector. We've already raised part of the money, but we need at least $8000 more before we can begin. Even the smallest donation can help us stay afloat.


What will you get in return? Besides knowing that you've contributed to a great cause, your name will appear on our website with one of the perks below. If you prefer, we'll send you memorabilia from one of our many shows in place of tickets.

  • For a donation of $25, you will receive 2 VIP passes, good for any show at The Stage.
  • At the $100 mark, you'll receive 2 VIP passes, and a beautiful The Stage t-shirt (black with our logo).
  • For a $500 donation, you will receive 2 season passes, two The Stage t-shirts, a signed poster from The Stage Players, and your name on the big screen! You can also elect to showcase your business or cause on the big screen for a whole year.
  • Pledge $2500 or more and you'll get a private screening or event at The Stage for up to 400 people! You will also receive two season passes, two The Stage t-shirts, a signed poster from The Stage Players, and your name will appear on the marquee and in our lobby as a contributor. You can also elect to showcase your business or cause on the big screen for a whole year.

If we don't meet our goal, the funds gained will still go toward the projector upgrade and we will continue to raise funds throughout our community.

How your contribution helps:

We are the only year round theater in Wyoming County, New York and the contiguous areas of five surrounding counties. We offer a variety of entertainment options to our community, including first run and classic film, live theater, music performances (we've recently hosted Lone Star, Tracey Lawrence and Kendall Phillips), fundraisers, and children's activities and events.
 
Without the income from first run films, we can no longer afford our operating expenses and will be forced to close. Our community will no longer have access to local, quality entertainment, and Warsaw will have a large, empty building on Main Street. Your contribution can directly help the arts in a small town.

Other ways you can help:

How else can you help? We are always looking for volunteers! You can also share this campaign and spread the word to your friends and family. Even a quick post on Facebook might make the difference if we are able to make our goal or not!

story:
Welcome To Kim Maxwell Studio

A permanent, practical and affordable studio to develop the stories of Ventura County’s illustrious Word-Nerds.

Our Mission:

We teach people to launch their stories loudly and unapologetically into the world; to laugh more, risk more and have bigger lives. 

Kim Maxwell Studio workshops are home to the adult in transition, the pre-teen/teen perpetually in transition and our underappreciated, unheard, unsung friends and neighbors. These are the folks that have filled my workshops for over twenty years.  From absolute beginners to seasoned professionals, they are newly unemployed, empty nested, recently divorced and beautiful to the bone. And helping them write and perform their own stories is the best job ever. 

Many Hands Make Light Work:

I embark on this venture with the Random Acts play-reading nerds Leslie Paxton, Sasha Heslip and Margo Haas; the General Eclectic comedy group headed up by Jim Lashly, Valerie Levett, Kit Stolz and Cary Odes; and Rain Perry with her brilliant Songwriting for Civilians class. Yup -- pretty much all my favorite artists developing stories under one roof. 

We’re Almost There:

We have 900 square feet of divinely air-conditioned, vaulted-ceiling heaven – on the MAIN street in the heart of downtown Ojai! Thanks to an anonymous patron and my story telling cronies above we have our rent, insurance and monthly operating costs covered for the duration of our 2-year lease. Add that to the extremely generous efforts of licensed and talented, volunteer contractor Patrick Lashly, and we have well over ½ our start-up costs and operating expenses covered for 2 years.  With a rigorously reviewed business plan that keeping our resources focused on low cost development and away on high cost productions, we stand the best possible chance of spinning yarns in our beautiful county for a very long time. 

But We Still Need You:

We need your stories, your humor and your money. $35,000 of it to be specific. This will cover the other half of our start-up costs of filling our studio with lights, comfortable chairs, an office, sound-proofing and the software/hardware do-dahs that make administrators squeal with delight. This will cover the other ½ of our start-up costs and create a dazzling, permanent home for Kim Maxwell Studio so we can continue to “Launch stories loudly and unapologetically into the world!”

So, spend impulsively, and come see your contributions at work at our Grand Opening, Sept 6 – 8, 2013

Love,

Kim

 

"Kim brings out the very best in her students; the freedom to dream and not just dream, but to seize what is possible for them… Good teachers are the only miracle left in American life now. They are idealists and beacons. Kim shows her students how to trust themselves, and their voices, and most of all - their potential. "

~ Jon Robin Baitz, Award Winning Playwright & 2012 Pulitzer Finalist

 

“It’s terrifyingly awesome. You learn how to sing, dance, scream, cry and be comfortable in your own skin. You learn the terrible woes of everyone else, and you realize that they are not that much different than your own.”

~ Jan Lashly, KMS Alumnus & Actor

 

 “Okay, so you could say that Kim is teaching theater, but she’s not. She’s really teaching being alive.” 

~ Peter Bellwood, Screenwriter & Parent of Alumnus
story_txt:
Welcome To Kim Maxwell Studio
A permanent, practical and affordable studio to develop the stories of Ventura County’s illustrious Word-Nerds.
Our Mission:
We teach people to launch their stories loudly and unapologetically into the world; to laugh more, risk more and have bigger lives. 
Kim Maxwell Studio workshops are home to the adult in transition, the pre-teen/teen perpetually in transition and our underappreciated, unheard, unsung friends and neighbors. These are the folks that have filled my workshops for over twenty years.  From absolute beginners to seasoned professionals, they are newly unemployed, empty nested, recently divorced and beautiful to the bone. And helping them write and perform their own stories is the best job ever. 
Many Hands Make Light Work:
I embark on this venture with the Random Acts play-reading nerds Leslie Paxton, Sasha Heslip and Margo Haas; the General Eclectic comedy group headed up by Jim Lashly, Valerie Levett, Kit Stolz and Cary Odes; and Rain Perry with her brilliant Songwriting for Civilians class. Yup -- pretty much all my favorite artists developing stories under one roof. 
We’re Almost There:
We have 900 square feet of divinely air-conditioned, vaulted-ceiling heaven – on the MAIN street in the heart of downtown Ojai! Thanks to an anonymous patron and my story telling cronies above we have our rent, insurance and monthly operating costs covered for the duration of our 2-year lease. Add that to the extremely generous efforts of licensed and talented, volunteer contractor Patrick Lashly, and we have well over ½ our start-up costs and operating expenses covered for 2 years.  With a rigorously reviewed business plan that keeping our resources focused on low cost development and away on high cost productions, we stand the best possible chance of spinning yarns in our beautiful county for a very long time. 
But We Still Need You:
We need your stories, your humor and your money. $35,000 of it to be specific. This will cover the other half of our start-up costs of filling our studio with lights, comfortable chairs, an office, sound-proofing and the software/hardware do-dahs that make administrators squeal with delight. This will cover the other ½ of our start-up costs and create a dazzling, permanent home for Kim Maxwell Studio so we can continue to “Launch stories loudly and unapologetically into the world!”
So, spend impulsively, and come see your contributions at work at our Grand Opening, Sept 6 – 8, 2013
Love,
Kim
 
"Kim brings out the very best in her students; the freedom to dream and not just dream, but to seize what is possible for them… Good teachers are the only miracle left in American life now. They are idealists and beacons. Kim shows her students how to trust themselves, and their voices, and most of all - their potential. "
~ Jon Robin Baitz, Award Winning Playwright & 2012 Pulitzer Finalist
 
“It’s terrifyingly awesome. You learn how to sing, dance, scream, cry and be comfortable in your own skin. You learn the terrible woes of everyone else, and you realize that they are not that much different than your own.”
~ Jan Lashly, KMS Alumnus & Actor
 
 “Okay, so you could say that Kim is teaching theater, but she’s not. She’s really teaching being alive.” 
~ Peter Bellwood, Screenwriter & Parent of Alumnus

story:
About Our Campaign

CMU Raasta strives to preserve Indian culture and promote diversity not only within the Carnegie Mellon campus but also throughout the Greater Pittsburgh community. 

CMU Raasta also competes in intercollegiate competitions held nationally throughout the course of the academic year. Through competitions, we bring recognition and prestige to Carnegie Mellon by projecting a respectable image of our university alongside some of the nation's premiere universities. However, as with starting and maintaining any competitive dance team, there are several ﬁnancial obligations and responsibilities that require our attention. Thus, we are seeking any monetary contributions that would aid us in achieving our goals. We would greatly appreciate any ﬁnancial support that you could provide to us.

As a nationally-recognized dance team, we beneﬁt our sponsors by bringing their organizations to the attention of college students, faculty, and alumni locally and nationally. On the next page, we have outlined several sponsorship levels, however donations of any value are greatly appreciated. Please keep in mind that all donations to Carnegie Mellon organizations are tax-deductible.

Thank you for your time and please do not hesitate to contact us with any questions or concerns. We greatly appreciate your support and look forward to hearing from you soon!


Sponsor Perks!

Any amount will help, but we have perks for sponsors and everyone who contributes gets a personal thank you letter!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our campaign via social media and tell your friends!

story:
Photo and article by Cameron Graves, published in the Shelburne Falls and West County Independent Arts Section. Click here to read/download.


WHY TO BEE OR NOT TO BEE ?

In 2006-2007, U.S. beekeepers lost 50% of their bees. Since then, honeybees have continued to struggle as a result of factors including pesticide use, loss of habitat and stress. Meanwhile native bee species are simultaneously disappearing.

Our response is the creation of a dramatic, comic, beautiful & simple performance that inspires wonder and curiosity about honeybees and by extension the natural world. The show will raise awareness about the honeybee's plight and give children and adults tools for helping bees thrive in their communities.

STORY
Told with two actors, puppets, live music, movement, beautiful visuals and plenty of audience participation, To Bee is fable about a farmer-beekeeper named James who gradually replaces his diverse crops with corn in order to fill a growing corporate demand for corn bi-products. The action opens with a traveler returning to the farm in search of the wonderful honey she remembers from her childhood only to find farmer and farm in despair - James now paints pictures of the past to console himself. Only after recounting his tale do the traveler and James realize that by reviving the land, his bees will again be able to thrive. Part of their discovery leads directly into a real world grassroots campaign launched in connection with the show.

10% FOR THE BEES

We will distribute seeds for planting bee gardens at the end of every performance! This campaign's early collaborators include local environmental group Greening Greenfield and Vermont's High Mowing Seeds. Seed and information distribution will encourage the replanting of 10% of lawns with bee friendly habitat and transitioning to organic lawn care methods.


WHEN AND WHERE?

The world premiere for To Bee is set for our 3rd annual SYRUP: One Sweet Performing Arts Festival on March 17, 2012 at Memorial Hall, Shelburne Falls MA. The show will then begin touring to a growing list of potential venues including:

  • Amherst Sustainability Festival
  • Boston Playwrights' Theatre
  • Bridge Street School, Northampton
  • Colrain Central School
  • Greenfield Energy Park
  • Greenfield Public Library
  • Lt. Clayre P. Sullivan School, Holyoke
  • Orange Town Hall (Preview Performance Feb. 26)
  • R.K. Finn Ryan Road School (Florence)
  • Springfield Museums
  • SYRUP: One Sweet Performing Arts Festival (World Premiere, March 17th - Memorial Hall, Shelburne Falls)
  • Turners Falls RiverCulture Cherry Blossom Festival

SEE PERKS FOR THE OPPORTUNITY TO UNDERWRITE THE SHOW OF YOUR CHOICE!

If we reach our campaign goal we will be able to perform at all of the above venues.

BUDGET

Here's a big picture breakdown:

Salaries â€“ Artistic & Technical: 70%

2 Actors ï¿½ 1 musician ï¿½ Playwright ï¿½ Choreographer ï¿½ Design (Set, Lighting, Costumes, Props) ï¿½ Carpenter ï¿½ Light and Sound Board Operators (at theatre venues)

 

Materials: 10%

Set Materials ï¿½ Costume Materials ï¿½ Prop Materials

 

Publicity: 10%

Poster/ Flyer/ Postcard Design and Printing ï¿½ Paid Listings/Advertisements ï¿½ Postering ï¿½ Website Design and Maintenance

 

Rental & Other Costs : 10%

Recording Studio ï¿½ Theatre Rental ï¿½ Script Copying ï¿½ Ticket and Program Printing



VISION

Our vision for this play is to train other teams from the U.S. and internationally who will bring To Bee to schools and theatres in their region. This goal will not be achieved by reaching the crowdfunding goal of this campaign, but we want you to know where we're going! In the near term, we will translate the production into French for touring in Switzerland and France in 2012 - 13.

HIVE

Founded in 2004 by American playwright/performer Jonathan Mirin and Swiss choreographer/designer Godelieve Richard, Piti Theatre Company is an interdisciplinary performance troupe based in Shelburne, MA and Les-Ponts-de-Martel Switzerland. Piti (pronounced "pea-tea") is an ancient Indian (Pali) word which can be translated as joy or rapture. Our aim is to create work which lends itself to the happiness of artists and audiences. The company has been nominated twice for an Independent Reviewers of New England Award.

Piti is collaborating with Northampton MA singer-songwriter Carrie Ferguson who is both writing music and performing in the show. Carrie released her debut album Riding on the Back of the Wind in 2010 and has toured the U.S. "Let me just say it: this album is great . . . Ferguson's tales seem to leap from the speakers." - Christopher Wiley, Northeast Performer Magazine. (See the Carrie Ferguson House Party Perk!).

We're also receiving expert puppet counsel from world renowned Sandglass Theater and Chicago/W. MA based puppeteer Emmy Bean.

BUZZ LEADING UP TO THIS

In 2008, we received a grant from the Art Angels of Western MA, a group of women philanthropists, to begin work on our dance-clown-theatre nature fable Elmer and the Elder Tree. Today, Elmer continues to tour and has been enjoyed by thousands of children and families in New England. Funding has been received from sources like the Community Foundation of Western MA, the New England Foundation for the Arts and Western Massachusetts Electric Company to bring this "artful, arboreal fable"  to many schools and community venues who would not be able to present it otherwise (Beverly Creasey, Theatermirror.com). Smaller-scale Piti productions like Salmon Falls and Time Flood about the Connecticut River Watershed have toured to schools, libraries and festivals since 2009.

The Art Angels have again provided a $2,000 grant to begin development of To Bee or Not to Bee. Since then, beekeepers, honey makers, and other businesses and individuals have stepped forward to help make this new show possible. Please (please!) join the hive and help us complete this critical first round of funding. We feel confident that money invested now, as was the case with Elmer and the Elder Tree, will be successfully leveraged to give this important production a regional and later, national and international impacts.



Thank you for supporting and sharing this campaign!

www.ptco.org/bee

story:
Hi! I'm Kiva Hewett, professionally known as burlesque performer Sheila Starr Siani. I have been dancing since I was a little girl, specializing in the forms that are for and about being feminine and sensual. My students are moms, wifes, teachers, police officers, professionals all trying to stay in touch with their inner temptress. I teach everything from pole dance and striptease to hula and latin jazz. I also hold workshops on how to walk in high heels, lap dance and the art of flirting.

For the last 4 1/2 years, I have been teaching out of various studios, simply renting time and space. I have been for the most part managing one of them for a couple years now. All this experience under my belt has been great in learning ropes of how to run a space, but limits me in what I can do in the space.

Last year, I decided it was time for Velvet Circus to have a home so I can fully serve my students all that I have to offer in the realm of feminine arts and dance.

In order to start I need to secure the space, put in flooring, mirrors, poles (for the striptease and pole dance classes), ballet bars, get yoga mats, hook up sound, get some sort of signage and advertising.

I have found a space. It is double the size of the studio I have been managing with parking and enough space for students to wait inside (as opposed to out in the cold like they do now). In order to secure it, I only need $1200 more. I will be signing a 1-year lease.

Floors I have priced at about $2500. Mirrors at about $1000. Poles I would need four more (I have one) and they tend to run at about $350 each. The rest of the needs can wait. plus I have a little funding coming in.


I want to open up March 1st. If I can get at least the floor and mirrors in, I can do a soft open. So I am offering a bunch of perks for people who are in the area and may want to take classes. The biggest being a who year of unlimited classes. For those of you not in the area or who are male, I have T-shirts and am working on a couple of other perks for you and will post those soon.

I really appreciate your support and even consideration. When i started teaching dance I didn't know how much I would love it. I really didn't expect that teaching dance would expand to include educating and empowering women in what we were built to be... Sexy! It is amazing.

story:
Our Story

Hi! We are a group of student actors, designers, and directors at Northwestern University. But, together, we are the team of GERYON, a strange and exciting new play that's coming to Evanston this November!


The Impact

We can guarantee that you have never seen anything like Geryon before! Our production is going to be site-specific, which means that we'll be performing somewhere besides a traditional theatre, specifically, at the Coach House (one of Evanston's beautiful, big, old buildings). Also, our actors will be using some unconventional performance techniques. Instead of a play filled entirely with simple dialogue and "traditional" blocking, they'll be using music, movement, and DANCING to interpret the story! 
We cannot wait to show this amazing production to the world, but because we're an independent student group, we need to come up with all of our own funds... And that's where YOU can help us!


What We Need & What You Get

So, our total budget is only $500. It's not much, and we are not wasting a single dollar! No matter what, the show must go on, but if we don't have enough money, then our production will not be at the quality we want it; our designers might not be able to provide necessary props, costumes, or set pieces. Oh no!

Literally any donation helps! Think of it this way, your contribution could become that cool mask that one actor wears, or maybe it will power the speakers through a dance sequence. The possibilities are ENDLESS! (okay, not endless. We promise we won't use your money to buy candy if we get bored at rehearsal...)


Note: Check our "Perks" section! You'll be entered in a drawing for some fabulous prizes if you donate a minimum of $10!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you're willing to contribute to our production, thank you thank you thank you a million times! No matter what, though, you are invited to our performances. They will be the evenings of November 11, 12, and 13... at the Coach House: 225 Greenwood; Evanston, IL 60201. (Can't WAIT to see you there!)

Finally, you can help us by spreading the word. PLEASE talk to people about Geryon! If you couldn't tell, we are beyond excited to bring Geryon's story to the world, but we need your help to share it with as many people as possible!


THANK YOU!!

story:
About the Play

ROEBLING: The Story of the Brooklyn Bridge brings to the stage the human drama surrounding the herculean construction effort to complete one of the most endearing and enduring engineering icons in the world. German immigrant John Roebling sets out to build the most ambitious engineering project of the Industrial Revolution—The Brooklyn Bridge. This would be the longest, tallest bridge in the world with new, innovative construcion techniques required for successful completion. But the effort is beset with setbacks and tragedies that leave the Roebling family and the bridge project in crisis.

After the sudden death of John Roebling and then the debilitating illness of his son Washington who took over as chief engineer, it becomes Emily Roebling, Washington’s young wife, who provides a surprising response and challenges all 19th century assumptions about the abilities and traditional roles of women.

Our Goal

Our goal is to have an New York City equity showcase production of ROEBLING in March 2013. This may be preceded by an additional production(s), readings and/or other promotional events to raise awareness and/or additional funds to facilitate production.

Funds raised from this IndieGoGo campaign will be directly used to facilitate this goal.

Why Support ROEBLING?

  1. Important and entertaining, ROEBLING is a truly American story of the dream of the amazing Roebling Family whose legacy is significant to all those who came to this country in search of greater opportunity. Particularly significant is the incredible contribution of Emily Roebling who surprised all 19th Century assumptions about what women are capable of.
  2. Our goal of a March 2013 production is significant as 2013 marks the 130th Anniversary of the Brooklyn Bridge and March is Women's History Month suitbaly honoring Emily Roebling.
  3. With the right support, ROEBLING has the potential to make it to Broadway.
  4. Your donation is tax deductible.
  5. Get great perks!

How The Money Will Be Spent

  • Pay our actors and creative team.
  • Hire a publicist: A publicist helps arrange press coverage and can get theater reviewers to see ROEBLING
  • Tech/Lighting/Sound: Engineers will need to be hired and equipment rented
  • Insurance: Nothing can happen without liability insurance
  • Hire a project manager to coordinate production tasks in NYC.
  • Marketing Materials: Website Design, Posters, Postcards, Print Ads, Programs, Promo Videos etc
  • Performance & Rehearsal Space: Being a non-profit usually brings costs down a bit, but theater space in New York City can be quite pricey.

What You Get

We've assembled a a fine collection of perks listed to the right.

We'd love for you to help us make this dream a reality!  On the right hand side you can see what you'll receive for your generous contribution.  Any amount is important to the success of ROEBLING and is greatly appreciated.

A Short History of Development of ROEBLING

ROEBLING has been performed twice previously. In 2009 it played to sold-out crowds as a non-equity premiere at Actors NET of Bucks County (PA). In 2010 it ran in the town of Roebling, NJ in conjunction with the Roebling Museum.

Prior to production, ROEBLING had two workshop readings at Kelsey Theater (NJ) and Villagers Theater (NJ).

Other Ways You Can Help

By sharing this link www.indiegogo.com/roeblingplay on Facebook, Twitter, email and through word of mouth. To donate larger amounts, please contact us through www.RoeblingPlay.com.

More Info

RoeblingPlay.com
theatertogo.com
markvioli.com
More on the true history of the Brooklyn Bridge

See the Gallery tab above for phtots, bios and even more info.

About the Roebling Artifacts

LEFT: Examples of Roebling Factory Artifacts courtesy of the Roebling Museum

LEARN MORE ABOUT THESE UNIQUE ITEMS

Artifacts range in size from 4" - 11" or more and will be chosen and awarded randomly.

 

Special Thanks

We wish to thank The Roebling Museum and Clifford Zink for their support and contributions.
story_txt:
About the Play
ROEBLING: The Story of the Brooklyn Bridge brings to the stage the human drama surrounding the herculean construction effort to complete one of the most endearing and enduring engineering icons in the world. German immigrant John Roebling sets out to build the most ambitious engineering project of the Industrial Revolution—The Brooklyn Bridge. This would be the longest, tallest bridge in the world with new, innovative construcion techniques required for successful completion. But the effort is beset with setbacks and tragedies that leave the Roebling family and the bridge project in crisis.
After the sudden death of John Roebling and then the debilitating illness of his son Washington who took over as chief engineer, it becomes Emily Roebling, Washington’s young wife, who provides a surprising response and challenges all 19th century assumptions about the abilities and traditional roles of women.
Our Goal
Our goal is to have an New York City equity showcase production of ROEBLING in March 2013. This may be preceded by an additional production(s), readings and/or other promotional events to raise awareness and/or additional funds to facilitate production.
Funds raised from this IndieGoGo campaign will be directly used to facilitate this goal.

Why Support ROEBLING?

Important and entertaining, ROEBLING is a truly American story of the dream of the amazing Roebling Family whose legacy is significant to all those who came to this country in search of greater opportunity. Particularly significant is the incredible contribution of Emily Roebling who surprised all 19th Century assumptions about what women are capable of.
Our goal of a March 2013 production is significant as 2013 marks the 130th Anniversary of the Brooklyn Bridge and March is Women's History Month suitbaly honoring Emily Roebling.
With the right support, ROEBLING has the potential to make it to Broadway.
Your donation is tax deductible.
Get great perks!

How The Money Will Be Spent

Pay our actors and creative team.
Hire a publicist: A publicist helps arrange press coverage and can get theater reviewers to see ROEBLING
Tech/Lighting/Sound: Engineers will need to be hired and equipment rented
Insurance: Nothing can happen without liability insurance
Hire a project manager to coordinate production tasks in NYC.
Marketing Materials: Website Design, Posters, Postcards, Print Ads, Programs, Promo Videos etc
Performance & Rehearsal Space: Being a non-profit usually brings costs down a bit, but theater space in New York City can be quite pricey.

What You Get
We've assembled a a fine collection of perks listed to the right.
We'd love for you to help us make this dream a reality!  On the right hand side you can see what you'll receive for your generous contribution.  Any amount is important to the success of ROEBLING and is greatly appreciated.
A Short History of Development of ROEBLING
ROEBLING has been performed twice previously. In 2009 it played to sold-out crowds as a non-equity premiere at Actors NET of Bucks County (PA). In 2010 it ran in the town of Roebling, NJ in conjunction with the Roebling Museum.
Prior to production, ROEBLING had two workshop readings at Kelsey Theater (NJ) and Villagers Theater (NJ).


Other Ways You Can Help
By sharing this link www.indiegogo.com/roeblingplay on Facebook, Twitter, email and through word of mouth. To donate larger amounts, please contact us through www.RoeblingPlay.com.
More Info
RoeblingPlay.com theatertogo.com markvioli.com More on the true history of the Brooklyn Bridge
See the Gallery tab above for phtots, bios and even more info.
About the Roebling Artifacts
LEFT: Examples of Roebling Factory Artifacts courtesy of the Roebling Museum
LEARN MORE ABOUT THESE UNIQUE ITEMS
Artifacts range in size from 4" - 11" or more and will be chosen and awarded randomly.

 
Special Thanks
We wish to thank The Roebling Museum and Clifford Zink for their support and contributions.

story:
Our Project: Wings by Arthur Kopit

At the Hollywood Fringe Festival (June 13-30)

This is an incredibly beautiful story about a woman (Emily, played by Rocky Lane) who is having a stroke.  What is unique is the play takes place from her point of view, while she is having the stroke.  

Ms. Lane is supported by an ensemble including Charles Dent, Andy Her, Diana Pascau, Nadine Bedrosian, and Vocals by Ana Avila.  

Production Team: Naomi Bennett (Director/Sound Designer); Heather Fipps (Production Designer); Jessica Morataya (Lighting Designer); Erik Boccio (Projections Designer); Crystal Gonzalez (Assistant Sound Designer); and Kayla Burchatz (Vocal Coach).

The Concept:

  • Reality, time and space shatter
  • Action is no longer a linear event
  • Slowly, Emily pieces her conciousness back together, fitting the pieces into a type of reality

 

Using dance, physical theatre, visual projections, soundscaping, and integrated set design Wings sets out journey with Emily as she makes her way through this strange new world her body has become.

Who are we?

We are a group of students from California State University, Los Angeles.  A combination of graduate, undergraduate, and alumni, we are working together to bring Kopit's work to life for YOU, The Audience!

  • We cannot do it without you!
  • Every dollar you give will go directly into the production!

Why should you donate?

  • This production is immensely important to all of us, both on personal and artistic levels.  
  • As people, we all deal with grief, loss, and tragedy.  One way to explore and deal with those feelings is through theatre - but this cannot happen without your support!
  • With your help, we can make this production the best it can be - unfortunately nothing happens without money, and that's where you come in!

What We Need?

Basically, we need a little starter money to get the show up and running.  Your funds will go towards things like:

  • Paying for the performance rights - so we can legally put up this production!
  • Programs, posters, and other publicity
  • Set design - this is a huge part of this show!

 

What You Get?

 

  • For any size donation, you'll get a HUGE THANK YOU!!!
  • For any donation over $10, you'll get TICKETS TO THE SHOW!!!  (Getting tickets this way is cheaper for you, and helps us with MONEY Up Front!)
  • For $100, we'll also buy you Drink after the SHOW!!!  (how can you beat that?...)

The Impact

Is simple.  Helping support local art and the future generation of artists. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have a buck to spare?  We are also looking for VOLUNTEERS in the following areas:

  • Street Team: Help pass out flyers and spread the word during the Fringe Festival (June 13-30)
  • Crew: Either prep before the show or help during the show - let us know your availability and we'll find something for you to do!
  • Spread the Word: HELP SPREAD THE WORD through Twitter, Facebook, Email, etc... tell your friends!!!

And lastly...

Thank you for checking out our project!

story:
Short Summary

Pony World Theatre is a small, independent theatre company that specializes in unique performances that employ original text, compelling design, and physicality. 

A Compelling, Unknown Force is a new, short performance piece (approximately 20 minutes) that will premiere at the NW New Works Festival at On The Boards.  The play explores the tragic and mysterious events of February 2, 1959 that resulted in the unexplained deaths of nine hikers in Ural Mountains of Soviet Russia. 

The NW New Works Festival brings together companies and individual artists from around the Northwest to premier original, short pieces to highlight the challenging, creative, and exceptional work being created in the NW.  It is an excellent opportunity for PWT to demonstrate our work, to increase our visibility in the regional theatre community, to come together with other artists, and to experiment with a story that has interested the company for over a year. 

Taking part in this festival is a rare and exciting opportunity for our small company, and we thank you for considering funding our project!

What We Need & What You Get

All ticket sales go to On the Boards, the company producing this big festival. OtB will provide PWT with a stipend, which is very helpful, but only covers a portion of our expenses. What are our expenses?

  • Rental of rehearsal space
  • Stipends for the artists working on our show
  • Materials for props, costumes, etc.

Approximately 2/3 of our costs will be covered by the OtB stipend and our own funds.  This campaign is to help us raise the remaining funds so we can perform alongside some of the NW's greatest artists and showcase our small, determined company!

We have four levels of giving (but you can choose any amount you like!). 

  • $10 — A signed thank you card from the cast (plus a big hug from one of us if you live in the Seattle area!)
  • $25 — The thank you card (and hug for Seattle donors!) plus a NW New Works brochure signed by the cast, and a poster from our latest mainstage production.
  • $50 — All the above, plus a booklet assembled by the company about the mystery and the various theories and conspiracies.  
  • $100 — All the above, and your choice of a personal bit of theatre art made jsut for you, either a monologue from Brendan Healy or a one minute dance performance (live if you live in the Seattle area or by Skype for those far away) by director & choreographer Gabrielle Schutz!  

If we do not meet our goal, all funds will still go to this project.  Any difference between our goal and actual funds raised will have to be made up by the company, possibly leaving us in debt or necessitating a delay in future programming.  No matter what, all funds donated through this campaign will go towards A Compelling, Unknown Force.

The Impact

Pony World Theatre makes original performances with uncompromised integrity.  Simultaneously, PWT is dedicated to keeping theatre economically accessible to everyone and compensating the artists who make our work possible.  

This work wouldn’t be possible without support from generous people such as yourselves who share the same values. 

The NW New Works Festival is a fantastic opportunity to share our company and our work with a larger audience.  If we meet our goal, this campaign allows us to take advantage of this opportunity without delaying or cutting future programming, but as you can imagine, creating original work that is affordable to everyone, while compensating the artists, is an economically challenging model.  If you share these same values, we hope you’ll consider contributing to this campaign—even small amounts are extremely helpful and deeply appreciated.

story:
PLAYLAB NYC IS BRINGING A BLIZZARD TO
THE NEW YORK INTERNATIONAL FRINGE FESTIVAL

Blizzard '67
by Jon Steinhagen

Four carpooling businessmen are lost in the horrific 1967 Chicago blizzard.
When they happen upon a stranded car, should they assist a stranger or protect themselves? Their decision is sure to haunt you long after you've left the theater.

An award winning playwright 

Back home, Jon Steinhagen is a staple of the independent theater scene. He is known to Chicago theater goers as an actor, playwright, composer, and pianist.  He has received four Jeff Awards, five Jeff Nominations, and six After Dark Awards for musical direction, writing or acting. He was a finalist for the first Noel Coward Award (2010) and winner of the Julie Harris Playwriting Award in 2009 for his comedy The Analytical Engine.  He received a producer-author initiative grant from NAMT in 2005 and received an After Dark Award for Best New Work for his musical The Teapot Scandals.

We are very lucky to have had a lot of history with Jon, and his work as a playwright is near and dear to us.  In 2009, we produced Perfectly Natural, four fables from a different perspective, and a reading of his musical The Arresting Dilemma of Mr. K at the TRU Voices New Musical Series under the direction of Gorilla Rep’s Christopher Carter Sanderson.  In 2010, we brought Jon’s unusual portrait of composer Erik Satie, The Altoona Dada Society Presents: The Velvet Gentleman to FringeNYC.  While earlier this year we had a reading of his torn from the headlines one-act play Seventeen Heads at O'Hare.

Blizzard's Beginning

The Chicago Blizzard of 1967 struck on January 26, 1967 with a record-setting 23 inches of snow falling before the storm ended the next morning.  The snow storm stranded tens of thousands of people and left an estimated 50,000 automobiles abandoned on the city streets and expressways. 

Playwright Jon Steinhagen used local papers, as well as friends and family for background for the play, “It wasn’t hard to get people talking about the storm at all. Everyone had a story, a memory, photographs.”

Blizzard '67 centers on four men who share a carpool every day to and from work, not friends, but coworkers for a large corporation.  Trying to drive home during the horrific snow blizzard, the coworkers find themselves caught in the snow and lost. When they happen upon a stranded car, should they assist a stranger or protect themselves?

Steinhagen said, “Nothing else tests our humanity towards others or reveals our inhumanity quite like our response to natural disasters; likewise, when we do the right things for the wrong reasons (and vice versa), can we live with our choices?”

How You Can Help?

A show that is as ambitious as this one takes a great deal of passion and resources.  We have a put together a fabulous team of designers and actors to bring this play to New York.  Your pledges will help us cover our festival fees and support production and marketing costs.  This includes things like: rehearsal space, costume pieces as well as compensating our crew and artistic staff for their tireless help during the production.

Here is a breakdown of our costs to help you see how your donation will assist us:

Actors/Artistic Team/Crew:  $2700

Rehearsal Costs: $1000

Production Costs: $400

Office /Marketing Costs: $1300

Total Costs:  $5400

As you can see, we're looking to raise less than what it will cost to actually produce this show.  This is because we know it's hard.  Money is a delicate topic, and putting on a show is a hard sell, so we're trying to make it as easy as possible.  You can pledge a $1 or $100 toward our project!

Join Us

Blizzard ’67 will be appearing at FringeNYC

Venue #16: The Robert Moss Theater at 440 Studios on:

Tuesday 8/13 at 2, Thursday 8/15 @ 8:30, Saturday 8/17 @ 2:30, Tuesday 8/20 @ 8:45, and Saturday 8/24 at 4:15.


Our Creative Team

The cast of Blizzard ’67 includes:William Franke* (Henkin) who was seen in last year’s FringeNYC presentation of The Abduction of Becky Morris; Graham Halstead (Emery) who appeared in West Lethargy at FringeNYC in 2010; John Pieza* (Lanfield) who is returning to acting after having directed Poe-Dunk – A Matchbox Entertainment at 2011’s FringeNYC; and Andrew David Rabensteine* (Bell) making his New York International Fringe Festival debut.

 

The Blizzard ’67 staff includes:Jennifer Linn Wilcox (Lighting Designer), Trevor Dallier (Sound Designer), and Bernadette Schoenborn* will serve as Stage Manager. The Blizzard '67 logo was created by Robert Ullman at www.atombombbikini.net.

*courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

 

When you donate to our indiegogo campaign you’ll get rewards that we’ve selected to help keep you cool this summer! 

Thanks for your consideration.  We look forward to seeing you around during The New YorkInternational Fringe Festival August 9th - 25th.  For show tickets visit http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=B#Blizza 

Sincerely, 

Kevin and Jennifer
Playlab NYC 
(taking fun way too seriously)

 

Who We Are

Playlab NYC was founded in 2008 by Kevin P. Hale and Jennifer Linn Wilcox.  We concoct, unleash and support enjoyably absurd and absurdly enjoyable amusements that engage artists and audiences in the spirit of play.  We have presented work at festivals including the Midtown International Theater Festival, FRIGID New York, FringeNYC, Figment New York, Great Small Works Toy Theater Festival, and The Players Theatre’s Short Play and Musical Festival.  In addition to having co-produced shows with Wide Eyed Productions and Coffee Black Productions, Playlab NYC has presented work at Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City and at the TRU Voices New Musical Series.  We are a member of Fractured Atlas. At Playlab NYC we are taking fun way too seriously. For more information visit www.playlabnyc.org. 

 

Playlab NYC is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of Playlab NYC must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Not Too Tame 

presents

'Early Doors'


Not Too Tame are an ensemble company of professional actors who are firmly founded on the belief of ‘Theatre for All’, focusing specifically in creating work that breaks the boundaries of tame, polite theatre and aims to engage those who feel that theatre isn’t a place where they belong.

Early Doors is a celebration of community and pub culture. From the very off you get a sense that this is something quite different from your normal theatrical experience. ‘Early Doors’ lives and breathes amidst the four walls of a real pub and the eclectic community that inhabit it.  Focus is pulled from one character’s story to another following their tales of love, loss and hope.  This is not a play with a stage and an interval, but an hour long site specific experience with all the great qualities of a gig; uplifting, unpretentious, electric and with a bevy in hand!


What We Need

We need to raise £20,000 - at least £5,000 of which we are hoping to acquire from donations by you lovely people.


We need to fund;

  • Transport

  • Boarding

  • Marketing

  • PR

  • Some humble subsistence to keep 11 actors fed and watered.


What You Get

Each donation comes with a unique gift ranging from personalised messages, signed posters, tickets to the show and even a character renamed after you!

You will also automatically be entered into our Prize Draw and at the end of the campaign have a chance to win;

  • 2 xTickets to 'Ubi Roi' (Cheek by Jowl) at the Barbican Centre London
  • 2 x Tickets to a 'Secret Theatre' show at the Lyric Hammersmith
  • A Family ticket to the Christmas Show 'The Nutcracker and the Mouse King' at the Unicorn Theatre London
  • Private 1hr Yoga sessions for you and up to 5 of your friends
  • Caricature of yourself by top UK Artist
  • Signed poster from Cheek by Jowl's 'Tis Pity She's a Whore' Cast & Crew
  • Cds, tickets, T-shirts from Rock 'n' Roll band SlyDigs

And much, much more...


How your contribution will make a difference...

“I’d like to think this is a worthy cause for anyone’s money. The show’s message looks to celebrate and build community through it’s audiences, and what bigger audience than Edinburgh Fringe Festival?! I mean, sometimes we need a form of escapism. How many people come home from work, or back from their search for work and have said “Put something funny on, will you?”. We need entertaining, we need to laugh and we need to see our own dilemmas explored by others in front of us – so perhaps, we don’t have to! I mean why do millions of us watch soap operas?  This show does so many things, and has so many things to say, but we don’t ram it down people’s throats, instead, we just go ‘get a load of this’ through different forms of live entertainment that are familiar to us. Then we add a ‘Not Too Tame’ spin on things; a Rock’n’Roll flare to lyricism and some poetry to pub a brawl, and so far people can’t get enough of it! And I mean people who wouldn’t normally be seen dead in a theatre, are now, finding themselves laughing shoulder to shoulder with your regular theatre goers - so we must be on to something?!”

Jimmy Fairhurst (Artistic Director)



- Other Ways You Can Help -

Please spread the love, share the link and make some noise about our campaign!

igg.me/at/earlydoors



Special Thanks to 

Lydia Wilson, Peter Morton, Paris Erotokritou, Cheek by Jowl, Lyric Hammersmith, Slydigs, Applecart, Carla Turner, Graham 'Picasso' Griffiths and Orlando James at Conduit Productions


Tracks by Slydigs - www.slydigs.co.uk

 @slydigsband
story_txt:
Not Too Tame presents'Early Doors'Not Too Tame are an ensemble company of professional actors who are firmly founded on the belief of ‘Theatre for All’, focusing specifically in creating work that breaks the boundaries of tame, polite theatre and aims to engage those who feel that theatre isn’t a place where they belong.Early Doors is a celebration of community and pub culture. From the very off you get a sense that this is something quite different from your normal theatrical experience. ‘Early Doors’ lives and breathes amidst the four walls of a real pub and the eclectic community that inhabit it.  Focus is pulled from one character’s story to another following their tales of love, loss and hope.  This is not a play with a stage and an interval, but an hour long site specific experience with all the great qualities of a gig; uplifting, unpretentious, electric and with a bevy in hand!What We NeedWe need to raise £20,000 - at least £5,000 of which we are hoping to acquire from donations by you lovely people. We need to fund;
Transport
Boarding
Marketing
PR
Some humble subsistence to keep 11 actors fed and watered.
 What You GetEach donation comes with a unique gift ranging from personalised messages, signed posters, tickets to the show and even a character renamed after you!You will also automatically be entered into our Prize Draw and at the end of the campaign have a chance to win;
2 xTickets to 'Ubi Roi' (Cheek by Jowl) at the Barbican Centre London
2 x Tickets to a 'Secret Theatre' show at the Lyric Hammersmith

A Family ticket to the Christmas Show 'The Nutcracker and the Mouse King' at the Unicorn Theatre London
Private 1hr Yoga sessions for you and up to 5 of your friends

Caricature of yourself by top UK Artist

Signed poster from Cheek by Jowl's 'Tis Pity She's a Whore' Cast & Crew
Cds, tickets, T-shirts from Rock 'n' Roll band SlyDigs
And much, much more...How your contribution will make a difference...  “I’d like to think this is a worthy cause for anyone’s money. The show’s message looks to celebrate and build community through it’s audiences, and what bigger audience than Edinburgh Fringe Festival?! I mean, sometimes we need a form of escapism. How many people come home from work, or back from their search for work and have said “Put something funny on, will you?”. We need entertaining, we need to laugh and we need to see our own dilemmas explored by others in front of us – so perhaps, we don’t have to! I mean why do millions of us watch soap operas?  This show does so many things, and has so many things to say, but we don’t ram it down people’s throats, instead, we just go ‘get a load of this’ through different forms of live entertainment that are familiar to us. Then we add a ‘Not Too Tame’ spin on things; a Rock’n’Roll flare to lyricism and some poetry to pub a brawl, and so far people can’t get enough of it! And I mean people who wouldn’t normally be seen dead in a theatre, are now, finding themselves laughing shoulder to shoulder with your regular theatre goers - so we must be on to something?!”Jimmy Fairhurst (Artistic Director)- Other Ways You Can Help -Please spread the love, share the link and make some noise about our campaign!igg.me/at/earlydoorsSpecial Thanks to Lydia Wilson, Peter Morton, Paris Erotokritou, Cheek by Jowl, Lyric Hammersmith, Slydigs, Applecart, Carla Turner, Graham 'Picasso' Griffiths and Orlando James at Conduit ProductionsTracks by Slydigs - www.slydigs.co.uk @slydigsband

story:
AT THIS TIME WE ARE SOLD OUT OF PERKS AND TICKETS FOR THE CONCERT- PLEASE CHECK BACK FOR UPDATES ON TICKETS

FWD Theatre Project - Discovering, Developing and Delivering the new American Musical in Chicago.

We produce concerts, readings, workshops and educational seminars that provide unique opportunities for exposure to unknown shows, writers, talent and creatives. 

Why 14 for FWD?  Perhaps because "Money for Musicals" or "Funds for Footlights" or "Benjamins for Broadway" didn't quite capture how special this opportunity is.

14 for FWD is a unique opportunity to help give birth to the next, great American musical.

$14,000 is what FWD Theatre Project needs to simply start moving forward. It is a small portion of the $40,000 necessary in operating our inaugural year.

Your generous support of 14 for FWD creates opportunity for musical theatre artists and provides new exciting works to Midwest audiences. Raising $14,000 provides essential seed money to sustain the business foundation of our non-for-profit.


On September 22, 2014,  FWD Theatre Project will officially launch with a concert at City Winery, introducing 5 new musicals that will be featured in our inaugural reading series throughout 2014 - 2015. The concert will feature songs from each show performed by leading and emerging voices in Chicago and Broadway theatre.

What will the money pay for?  Money will pay for actors, directors, musical staff, writer stipends, scripts, scores, binders, musicians, rehearsal space, copies, marketing & PR materials, performance venues, a web site, a graphic designer..... and more.

What's in it for you?  The opportunity to play an essential role in this exciting and new journey of finding and developing new musicals.   You have an opportunity to support, meet and engage with artists in the developmental process. Best of all, you'll have the bragging rights to say you saw or heard it first before it becomes the next Broadway hit!

If that isn't enough, check out the perks offered below in our 14 for FWD Campaign.  

Here are just some ways your contribution matters:

$25 - An average script and score is 420 pages.  $25 pays for an actor to have one copy of the script and score.
$50 - A new show = edits and new pages.  $50 lets us distribute new pages to the cast.
$75 - We can print up some programs and feedback materials for our audiences.
$100 - Pays for an accompanist the night of a reading.
$150 - Sponsors a director, stage manager, music director or actor for 25 hours of rehearsal and performance.
$200 - Sponsors a writing team developing their project. 
$500 -  Lets Market a Show!
$1000 - Rehearsal Space for show development.
$2500 - A venue to perform the reading with sounds and lights
$5000 - An official sponsor of a new musical!

Everyone has a story to tell.  For our launch concert, we received over 200 submissions from Seattle to New York and across the globe.  200!  No, that is not a typo!

All these creative people long to tell, sing and dance their story.  With your help, we can tell these stories in highly collaborative artistic experiences by giving them a voice, development and forward momentum.

Chicago is the second largest theatre community in the nation with an active and diverse audience and nationally recognized theatre critics.  This accomplished theatrical community holds enormous resources for playwrights to collaborate and develop new works. The city offers affordable rehearsal and performance spaces, exceptional talent, and a market primed for embracing and propelling creativity.  It is THE ideal place to create, explore, and develop the new American musical.


If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Become an active proponent for FWD and share this campaign.
  • Attend our readings and concerts.
  • Talk with and about us.
  • Visit us on social media (see video for information).
  • Email us and volunteer your time and expertise.

Thank You for helping us move FWD in 2014!

story:
Over the last year I have been writing a one man show which will be entitled "The Happiest Story I know".

I am at the point where I am ready to start performing and touring the show. I will be applying to and performing in fringe festivals.

I need your help to get started. I have spent the last 4 months working as an intern doing motivational speaking at high schools. Although my heart is full and my life feels rich I am cash poor!

It costs money to apply and perform in fringe festivals and I could use your help to get started.

Thank you!

story:
It all begins with the story of This beautiful song and dance masterpiece is adapted from the 1985 novel “My Love, My Love” or “The Peasant Girl” by Rosa Guy which was based off of Hans Christian Andersen's “The Little Mermaid.” Set in the French Antilles in the Caribbean Sea, the story explores the life of Ti Moune, a peasant girl, who lives on a tropical island whose population is separated between different social classes. A Source of Joy Theatricals has taking this production to a new heights by training and educate young adults from a different background and enter into a new life of friendship and the power of the arts.

A Source of Joy Theatricals has an opportunity to take this production on the road and take young people from the community and share their gifts and talents with others across the country.

This in show Ti Moune rescues and falls in love with Daniel, a member of the upper grand-hommes class from the other side of the island. When Daniel is returned to his people, the fantastical gods who rule the island, guide Ti Moune on a quest to test the strength of her love against the powerful forces of prejudice, hatred and death. Told through music, song and dance, the musical explores universal issues, which affect us all - love, anger, forgiveness, faith, maturity, and mortality. 

How Donations Be Used

Your donation will help make this possible.  Reaching our goal provides essential funding for Travel, Venue, Costuming, Small Stipends, Cast and Crew Needs for two months, including Camera for logging the adventure for future use, Production Design, Technical personnel, meals, royalties, etc.

After intense research, we have identified that $125,000.00 as the amount needed to make this tour and filming happen.


TRAVEL                                             31%    $38,750
VENUE                                               20%    $25,000
COSTUMING                                    1.4%    $1,750
SMALL STIPEND                            1.9%    $2,375
CAST SUPPLIES/NEEDS            16.2%    $20,250
MEALS                                                14%    $17,500
PERSONNEL                                    8.5%    $10,625
ROYALTIES                                           3%    $3,750
CAMERAS & FILMING SUPPLIES  4%    $5,000
                $125,000.00  TOTAL

 

How will funds be used if goal is surpassed:

  • Editing and post-production Cost
  • Selecting additional cities for the production
  • Purchasing Merchandise items to give away

TOURING LOCATIONS

  • LAS VEGAS
  • CALIFORNIA
  • ARIZONA
  • NEW JERSEY
  • BALTIMORE
  • WASHINGTON DC
  • VIRGINIA
  • NORTH CAROLINA
  • SOUTH CAROLINA
  • FLORIDA

The Purpose of this Tour (Development In The Arts)

Involvement in the Arts is an unparalleled means for young people to develop the strength, resiliency, and self-image that allows them to participate in society on healthy terms.

Characteristics identified as contributing to their success and efficacy.  Intensive youth participation in making Art.  Young people are not limited to being an audience for the arts, they are creators.

Having professional artist working as mentors and teaching in a range of discipline.  Apprenticeship relationship between youth and professional artists.

Sustain youth participation over time, throughout multiple years, and long-term projects.  Obtaining youth responsibility for exhibiting, performing and publicly presenting their own work, in groups and solo.

Giving the provision of safe and secure space for self-expression and artistic and social development.

story:
First Draft 

Dear all you people out there, friends and supporters,

We are Open Heart Surgery a new and innovative theatre company and I am Coleen MacPherson the Artistic Director.   After leaving Paris having studied physical theatre for two years and writing, I have decided to launch into making work in London.  Open Heart Surgery came out of a desire to make original theatre that is both physical, poetic and also experimental in form and content.  I want to bring stories to audiences that are visceral and relevant, to invigorate debate and ignite the desire to share our lives with each other!  I want to tickle you and make you ponder while also opening your hearts to imagining this world in a new way.

The first play I wrote was First Draft, a play that stimulated debate in Toronto and won several awards, and a standing ovation at Hart House Theatre to a sold out crowd.  It was a happening of sorts, as it was something that happened and then disappeared but people then talked about it and wondered when it would happen again.  The play grew out of the team at the time and of course the incredible talent of now Film Director Sarah Warren, whose simplicity in direction and striving for authenticity is truly admirable.   

Sarah and I find ourselves in London now and we thought:  why not bring this play to London audiences, a newer version with the same spirit of experimentation and devising process of creation!  

And so this is what we did ... and this is why we need you!  But, before telling you what we are hoping your contribution can help with.  Let me tell you a little more about our play, it's evolution, and what we hope for the future.

First Draft written by Coleen MacPherson is a play that explores a fast-paced world in contrast to a future world that exists in a protection unit far away from the Earth's surface.  Inspired by conversations on the street about war and EM Forster's The Machine Stops, First Draft brings you into a visceral world that speaks against the apathy of our time.

The play invites its audiences into a very special world, an empty space where characters emerge and disappear and speak about a world that exists far into the future where everything has become deserted and empty, where a student yearns to see the sky again after so many years of darkness.  Directed by Sarah Warren and Performed by up and coming talented actors Charlotte Baseley and Louise Callaghan, the two grace the stage and flit between characters taking us through a whirlwind of people and places ... from a morning bicycle ride to a date in a jazz bar filled with the music of Miles Davis we hope to tickle our audiences while simultaneously riling them up.

****************************************************************************

"We have been given very powerful tools ... to think ... to believe in world peace, to love ..."  (from First Draft)

****************************************************************************

Our London debut ... First Draft will be playing at the Camden People's Theatre as part of the Camden Fringe this August 2014.  

21, 22 and 23rd at 7:30 pm to be precise.

What Theatre Professionals have said:

"First Draft is a play that uses the empty space, directed with admirable simplicity ...  it is a piece I could watch again and again" (Steven Bush, Toronto)

"This is a very unique play, it is genre-less; its style is an experiment and a dialogue.  It’s a little like Meredith Monk …  It’s a play that makes you think and also moves you … ”  (Graham Cozzubbo, Assistant Artistic Director, Banff Centre for the Arts)

I am very excited for First Draft’s London Debut at CPT. This play began out of questioning the necessity of war and has now grown through it’s rework into a satirical play of many voices, jumping from present to future and journeying through big questions like – can politicians be honest? Or is war truly a means for peace?  As I consistently watch in the media: a world of violence seems more and more the status quo.  This play speaks against this reality and tries to open our hearts and minds to another world and the possibilities for peace.

Running time: 45 minutes | Suitable for ages 16+

www.firstdrafttheplay.com

@firstdraftplay | #firstdraft| facebook.com/firstdrafttheplay

Camden People’s Theatre, 58-60 Hampstead Rd, London

www.camdenfringe.org


Coleen MacPherson is a playwright, poet, actor and director and current member of the Arcola Theatre’s Writers’ Group 2014.  Newly arrived to London, she has trained at École Internationale de Théâtre Jacques Lecoq, where she mentored with French playwright Michel Azama and Susana Lastreto.  Coleen’s plays have been performed in Montreal, Toronto, and soon London with First Draft as her London Debut.  MacPherson has worked with various theatre companies in Toronto, touring work to Shangai, China (International Contemporary Theater Festival) and performing work at Canadian Stage, Summerworks Festival and Nuit Blanche Toronto and Paris.  She currently works with internationally renowned touring theatre company, Wet Picnic performing in The Birthday Party on their UK tour this year, and is developing a new work in Toronto called This is why we Live ... with the support of the Canada Council for the Arts.

Sarah Warren is an Actor, Writer and Director for theatre and film.  Her first feature film, Moments Before, premiered to festivals in LA and Toronto. Trained in Acting at the University of Toronto, and filmmaking in London, Sarah was a selected actor for a specialized course focusing on interdisciplinary art taught by Director and film icon Atom Egoyan who has specifically encouraged Sarah's comedic voice.  She created theatrical pieces for the Fringe Festival circuit and performed at the Piccolo Teatro in Milan. Her short film Guilt, Or was selected as top 10 for the TIFF Showcase and then went on to show theatrically in Canada before Roman Polanski's, Carnage. Her play Side Dish was a finalist at The Lost Theatre this past year.  Sarah also works as a Lead Tutor for Onscreen Acting at the MET Film School as well as having lectured at Central St. Martins and the London Film Academy. She just completed her latest feature film, MLE, which she wrote, directed and acted in. MLE is a comedic spy film featuring Paul Haggis and Mike Figgis.

Performed by Louise Callaghan and Charlotte Baseley

We need you :)

Your contribution will help us:

  • Help pay towards the theatre rental fee of £600
  • Rehearse in an equipped theatre rehearsal space in Camden
  • Help build two giant flats for the show
  • Help towards the purchase of props and costumes
  • Publicity and Marketing and the printing of postcards
  • Paying the Camden Fringe entree fee
  • Funds will also contribute to an honorarium for each member of our team
  • Any remaining funds that we collect we would like to donate to: War Child

Impact of your contribution

Your contribution will go a long way!

  • This project speaks out against war and apathy, and is a piece that we believe can have an impact on the way we view our world, and we hope that through your contribution we will be able to further develop the legacy of this piece
  • Our goal is to tour the play after this initial development phase at the Camden Fringe
  • In Toronto we were able to gather audiences, support and the play was a huge success.  We hope to take this play further, across the UK and Canada with the purpose of sharing this work with as many people as possible.
  • As a new an upcoming theatre company we must produce our own work to be seen.  As we are unknown in the big city of London it is important that we begin to build contacts and support, but we cannot do this until producers have seen our work.  Your generosity is a way of helping us take that next step.

Putting ourselves out there

We know that whenever you put up a show there is a risk. What if people do not come?

  • We have a great team and have produced work before, Sarah has fully produced two feature films, and therefore we know we can build an audience to see our show in London
  • Coleen has been reaching out to producers, theatres, the public at large in order to connect with potential audiences
  • We are part of the Camden Fringe which will help us build an audience:  www.camdenfringe.com
  • Check us out on the Camden People's Theatre Website: http://www.cptheatre.co.uk/show/first_draft.php#.U8KX11aaLwI

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that sometimes you cannot contribute at this time, and that is ok!

  • Please spread the word about our campaign, make some noise, shout in the streets perhaps, and email this to all your friends and family, and those you could imagine being able to contribute in some way.
  • Use the Indiegogo Share tools :) 
  • Help us get people out to see the show by sending this link to all the people you know in London: http://www.cptheatre.co.uk/show/first_draft.php#.U8KX11aaLwI

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this and we hope to see you at First Draft in London or beyond!

xo

Coleen and Sarah

"This is a very unique play, it is genre-less;
its style is an experiment and a dialogue. 
It’s a little like Meredith Monk … 
It’s a play that makes you think and
also moves you …
”  (Graham
Cozzubbo, Assistant Artistic Director, Banff Centre for the Arts)
I am very excited for First Draft’s London Debut at CPT. This play
began out of questioning the necessity of war and has now grown through it’s
rework into a satirical play of many voices, jumping from present to future and
journeying through big questions like – can politicians be honest? Or is
war truly a means for peace?  As I
consistently watch in the media: a world of violence seems more and more the
status quo.  This play speaks against
this reality and tries to open our hearts and minds to another world and the
possibilities for peace.
Running time: 45 minutes | Suitable for ages
16+
www.firstdrafttheplay.com
@firstdraftplay | #firstdraft| facebook.com/firstdrafttheplay
Camden People’s Theatre,
58-60 Hampstead Rd, London 
www.camdenfringe.org

Coleen MacPherson is a playwright, poet, actor and director and
current member of the Arcola Theatre’s Writers’ Group
2014.  Newly arrived to London, she has
trained at École Internationale de Théâtre Jacques Lecoq, where she
mentored with French playwright Michel Azama and Susana Lastreto. 
Coleen’s plays have been performed in Montreal, Toronto, and soon London
with First Draft as her London Debut. 
MacPherson has worked with various theatre companies in Toronto, touring
work to Shangai, China (International Contemporary Theater Festival) and
performing work at Canadian Stage, Summerworks Festival and Nuit Blanche
Toronto and Paris.  She currently works
with internationally renowned touring theatre company, Wet Picnic performing in
The Birthday Party on their UK tour this year, and is developing a new work in Toronto called This is why we Live ... with the support of the Canada Council for the Arts.
Sarah Warren is an Actor, Writer and Director
for theatre and film.  Her first feature
film, Moments Before, premiered to festivals in LA and Toronto. Trained in
Acting at the University of Toronto, and filmmaking in London, Sarah was a
selected actor for a specialized course focusing on interdisciplinary art
taught by Director and film icon Atom Egoyan who has specifically encouraged
Sarah's comedic voice.  She created
theatrical pieces for the Fringe Festival circuit and performed at the Piccolo
Teatro in Milan. Her short film Guilt, Or was selected as top 10 for the TIFF
Showcase and then went on to show theatrically in Canada before Roman Polanski's,
Carnage. Her play Side Dish was a finalist at The Lost Theatre this past
year.  Sarah also works as a Lead Tutor
for Onscreen Acting at the MET Film School as well as having lectured at
Central St. Martins and the London Film Academy. She just completed her latest
feature film, MLE, which she wrote, directed and acted in. MLE is a comedic spy
film featuring Paul Haggis and Mike Figgis.
Performed by Louise Callaghan and Charlotte Baseley   We need you :) Your contribution will help us: 
Help pay towards the theatre rental fee of £600
Rehearse in an equipped theatre rehearsal space in Camden
Help build two giant
flats for the show
Help towards the purchase of props and costumes
Publicity and Marketing and the printing of postcards
Paying the Camden Fringe entree fee
Funds will also contribute to an honorarium for each member of our team
Any remaining funds that we collect we would like to donate to: War Child

 
Impact of your contribution
Your contribution will go a long way! 
This project speaks out against war and apathy, and is a piece that we believe can have an impact on the way we view our world, and we hope that through your contribution we will be able to further develop the legacy of this piece
Our goal is to tour the play after this initial development phase at the Camden Fringe In Toronto we were able to gather audiences, support and the play was a huge success.  We hope to take this play further, across the UK and Canada with the purpose of sharing this work with as many people as possible. As a new an upcoming theatre company we must produce our own work to be seen.  As we are unknown in the big city of London it is important that we begin to build contacts and support, but we cannot do this until producers have seen our work.  Your generosity is a way of helping us take that next step. 
  Putting ourselves out there  We know that whenever you put up a show there is a risk. What if people do not come? 
We have a great team and have produced work before, Sarah has fully produced two feature films, and therefore we know we can build an audience to see our show in London Coleen has been reaching out to producers, theatres, the public at large in order to connect with potential audiences
We are part of the Camden Fringe which will help us build an audience:  www.camdenfringe.com

Check us out on the Camden People's Theatre Website: http://www.cptheatre.co.uk/show/first_draft.php#.U8KX11aaLwI
 
  Other Ways You Can Help We know that sometimes you cannot contribute at this time, and that is ok! 
Please spread the word about our campaign, make some noise, shout in the streets perhaps, and email this to all your friends and family, and those you could imagine being able to contribute in some way. Use the Indiegogo Share tools :) 
Help us get people out to see the show by sending this link to all the people you know in London: http://www.cptheatre.co.uk/show/first_draft.php#.U8KX11aaLwI
 
 Thank you so much for taking the time to read this and we hope to see you at First Draft in London or beyond!xoColeen and Sarah

story:
This May Be a Flop. That’s O.K.

My name is Seth Lepore. I’m a solo theater artist, provocateur and absurd humorist on the edge of shifting from emerging artist to mid-career performer. This actually means something to people in the field but the point of this project is to lay out the sorry state of affairs in the performing arts and the possible mortality of my chosen profession through Kickin’ Ass and Takin’ Names, a 12 hour live streaming web-a-thon fundraiser on December 7th from 10AM to 10PM EST!

Originally meant as a scripted finalé to my trilogy on the underbelly of the self-help movement, I decided to open my creative process to the public as a mash-up workshop/ laboratory/ talk show/ performance experiment in order to find the essence of what will become an interactive touring piece. The audience will have a first hand account of what it’s like to create a show under an extreme amount of pressure, and insights into what is usually not seen until the final end product.

The Show/ Fundraiser/ Documentary/ PR Stunt will deal directly (in real time) with the fact that this piece could be an utter and complete flop, blowout success or worse… neither. It will ultimately try to accomplish too much at once on purpose. I will embrace and simultaneously repel America’s fascination with social success and rubbernecking train-wrecks.

My goal is to raise $10,000 in the half-day span. That very goal is in itself an examination of failure and/or success in the moment.

Watch the live stream December 7th from 10 AM to 10 PM (EST) right here. 

Download the full schedule of topics and special guests.

I Lose My Mind. You Get to Keep Yours.

As solo performer Mike Daisey recently said during a keynote address I attended, “The arts are in major trouble… This is the hardest time to be an artist.” I couldn’t agree more and as we all scramble to achieve our dreams, we are in a narrow chasm, trying to figure out how to survive. This funding will help keep me afloat while I continually build my career trajectory towards actual sustainability. I spend 40-50 hours week working to mainly build relationships with arts presenters who will hire me while playing exhausting festivals and smaller venues, including self-produced runs, that hardly cover my expenses.

Your contributions go directly to keeping The Seth Lepore Project afloat and covering a little over half of the monthly administrative costs which includes all the time I spend marketing and promoting my work, researching the best festivals to work with as well as the hours it takes to develop relationships with the media and arts presenters who are the gatekeepers to the industry.

This is what $10,000 will afford me:

A guarantee of $833.33 per month for 2014 that I don’t have to scramble for.

I know it’s simple math and you’re like, huh? Let me explain. Over the last few years there have been four to five months during each year where I bring in zero dollars. I have times of year where I make a few thousand but I’ve never gone over $10,000 in the last five years in income because I spend so much on the expenses. Seems ridiculous? It is. 

$1600 is the minimum it really takes to just run the operation and sometimes that doesn't even happen so you're helping me get a little over half of that taken care of which is a big big deal.

Check it. I’ve got some perks because people like perks, and perks get people excited, and we all like excitement.

What happens if I don’t reach my goal?

I have this set up as a flexible funding campaign so no matter how much I make during this 12 hour madness, I will still be able to use it towards my monthly nut. Your donations will go a long way because I’m an artist and know how to stretch money.

I Am Nothing Without You.

We could get all existential and say that I’m nothing regardless of you or not, but let’s face it: Without an audience, without people who have a stake in my work, who show up and participate in the experience, there is... No. Point. You, then, are everything.

We’ve reached jaw-dropping statistics: the theater audience has grown -12% since 2008, the audience itself has dropped over 50% in the last decade. This whole campaign is an experiment in understanding the future of theater. Questions I’m positing:

  • Can I cut through the noise to get enough attention so people know about the web-a-thon, never mind actually watching it?
  • Can I demonstrate the strange notion of commodified theatrical “value” through the process of an end of the year fundraiser?
  • Can I show the full scope of possible actions in terms of failing and succeeding on a cultural level, as well as the process of personal past reflections and observations?
  • Can I… Do I make an impact with my work? Can that be measured? Does it need to be measured?
  • Is the live streaming of live theater the “answer” to the future of theater?

I don’t know so help me out and take part!

Other Ways You Can Help the Cause

  • Facebook and Tweet the shit out of this campaign to raise awareness before it begins. Use the hashtags #newplay and #theater when you talk about it.

  • Use the same hashtags (#newplay and #theater) the day of the web-a-thon on December 7th to create conversations and drive people to watch it.

  • Send an email and/or text to your peeps about the live streaming web-a-thon. Emails and texts are even more effective than social media because they are more directive.

Thanks doesn’t cut it but it’ll have to do for now.
