story:
Femme Fatale is a group of young female trail blazers ages 12 - 18 from Atlanta GA. who kick butt on and off the stage. A descendant of the theatrical hip hop dance group Darlin Nikki, Femme Fatale is not your ordinary teenage dance crew. Femme Fatale rules the stage with their over the top personalities, choreography, precision, always on top fashion and their infamous hair whip. Off stage they are smart strong leaders who are individuals but lead as one. Although Femme Fatale is a performance dance group, each young lady continuously strive to perfect there other talents such as modeling, acting, singing, cheer leading and fashion design. Femme Fatale members have had the opportunity collectively and individually to grace the stage with Fantasia Barrino, Dru Hill, Joe, and Mindless Behavior. The girls have had the opportunity to perform during The Atlanta Dreams WNBA halftime show and to appear in music videos such as Mykko Montana’s “Do It” and TI’s “Go Get It”. Femme Fatale members have also had the opportunity to attend the prestigious Alvin Ailey Dance Camp in Atlanta Georgia and the opportunity to perform in Step Stewart's “A Soulful Christmas” and the Universoul Circus. Not to mention all the wonderful performances around the city and beyond with some of Atlanta greatest artist and performers. While attending different schools in the metro Atlanta area, Femme Fatale strive to make a difference in the community by helping to raise money for different charities, giving a helping hand to non-profit organizations in the community such as the AIDS Walk Atlanta and the Salvation Army, and promoting the Anti-Bullying Movement. Femme Fatale is working hard as a group and as individuals to leave their mark in this world. 

Femme Fatale has been invited to numerous events but none in which they could call their own. Femme Fatale has decided to host its very own dance concert this spring. With your help Femme Fatale will be given the opportunity to showcase the important values of dedication, hard work, self-esteem, team building and self-worth to other young girls around Atlanta and beyond through dance and the performing arts. 

Although these young ladies have had the opportunity to perform with and for great people, the opportunities were not easy. Every performance has been sponsored by dedicated parents in which all are raising these girls in nontraditional homes as single parents. With that being said contributors will help to take a huge burden off the parents who have worked so hard throughout the years to assure the success of Femme Fatale.

Your donations will contribute to the cost of the venue, promotional items, DJ, Photographer, Videographer, Hair, Makeup, wardrobe and refreshments for the guest.  The perks as a contributor depending on the donation bracket will be a Femme Fatale Fan T-shirt, Your name/company name/or logo on the photo backdrop, a special choreographed dance by "your" favorite artist dedicated in your name, a You Tube thank you shot out, a "fashion Find", Video of the Concert, your name in the program, and a autographed photo of Femme Fatale. 

Femme Fatale understands that everyone who may want to contribute may not be able to, so the other ways that you can help is to help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. 

Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

We would like to say thank you in advance!

story:
Short Summary

Help make annual summer ecstatic dance camps happen in the Northwest. We'll build and run them together, by consent, with transparency, wildness, shared energy, and of course, FUN! See all the details at: Dance Camp Northwest.

This first year's camp will draw upon and deepen an already amazing community. We have so much going for us: an incredible location, and the enthusiastic participation of many dancers, dances, facilitators, DJ's, workers, cooks and gifted teachers. 

But we also face real challenges: We're running on volunteer time and energy, without much money yet. And due to scheduling constraints at beautiful Ft. Flagler, this first year's camp has to be held during the week, Monday through Friday. We were so lucky to get time at an amazing spot like Ft. Flagler, but this will certainly limit participation and income this first year.

So we need your help. Please. Make a contribution, spread the word, and invite your friends!

We are already planning next year's longer camp at Fort Worden in Pt. Townsend, with the help and partnership of the Madrona Mind Body Institute. But we need this year's camp to go well so all our future summer camps, and winter dance weekends too, can become open windows into dance-topia.

Dance Camp Northwest is based on the hugely successful Dance New England which helped birth all the ecstatic, free, and barefoot dance communities peppering the planet today, including the Northern California Dance Collective. We now join the movement toward creating dance camps everywhere to serve, deepen and evolve humanity by interweaving our tribal roots into one earth community.

We are asking for $1,000, though we'd be more comfortable with $3,000 and will be grateful for everything and anything. Any money not needed for basic, volunteer-infused and non-profit level operating expenses will go to financial aid.

Please consider donating so this fledgling can take wing and soar. Just a little from you can do so much. Together we can make the dream of bigger, more connected, more vibrant dance community come true.

 
We see many festivals throughout the year. Sometimes new ones pop up and they need some assistance to get the ball rolling. I know this is a great thing to contribute to and my wish is that they receive plenty of donations to make Dance Camp Northwest take off for many many years! Even if you just throw $1 (or more) at them it will help! Every little bit!  ~Cary Whitehead

story:
¿When the sky cracks open, what’s gonna fall out?

Baby Blue: an extraterrestrial experiment is a multimedia theatrical experience that blends elements from rock concerts, opera, dance, and theatre. This stage translation of the albums Baby Blue and Revelations, by Puerto Rican singer/songwriter Gian Perez (University of Michigan), tells the story of a boy coming into contact with worlds unknown.

In 2017, Perez released his psychedelic, funk-rock concept album about the eponymous Baby Blue and the different degrees and disguises of solitude. Revelations, released the following year as a sister album, continues the character’s journey; featuring meditations on change, time, and what home means.

After having the idea to translate the two albums to the stage, Perez united with New York City based creator Pedro Hernandez (Marymount Manhattan College Alumni) to bring the story to life. Together, the two conceptualized the piece for many months, recontextualizing the albums’ music and lyrics as a theatrical narrative.

What they concocted is a science-fiction epic which sees Baby Blue abducted by other-worldly visitors, experimented on, and returned to his natural habitat. When faced with the immediate impact of his newfound form, Baby Blue struggles to find a sense of belonging and normalcy on Earth.

The next step in the process is to workshop the piece with an ensemble of dancer/actors in order to see the material on its feet before producing it. Over the course of 10 days, in July 2019, Perez and Hernandez will stage a skeletal rendering of what the piece will become. 

The workshop will require $3,000 to come to fruition.

All funds will go towards:

Studio Space Rental

Actor/Stage Manager/Choreographer Fees

Basic Rehearsal needs (Props, minimal set, etc.)

The end goal is to bring this piece to the New York City stage as a fully realized production in the near future. By donating, you would be a crucial part of our journey! Thank you all so much for taking the time to read our pitch! Peace, Love and Soul! 

Listen to the music of Baby Blue: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=OLAK5uy_m...

Listen to the music of Revelations: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=OLAK5uy_n...

story:
Youth America Grand Prix (YAGP)

YAGP is the world's biggest competition for young dancers and performing in the New York Finals is an incredible opportunity for our students to be seen by the best of the best in the dance world. Being exposed to directors of the world's most renowned dance companies could open up so many doors for our students and we can only do it with your help!

You can make the difference in the lives of our students by helping them take advantage of this wonderful opportunity they were presented with in reward for their hard work. 

Yuri Grigoriev School of Ballet

Students of the the Advanced 2 program at YGSB competed at Youth America Grand Prix 2017 in Las Vegas this past February. 

  • KINA (performed by Kamala McDaniels, Grace Trpin, João Ducci, Jackson Knappen, Coco Williams, Clara McNeal, Madeline Kelley, Ariana Kalamaros) received 3rd place in the Ensembles Category and was invited to perform at Finals in New York City in April
  • Duet HISLER  (performed by Coco Williams and Jackson Knappen) was also invited to the NYC Finals

Both choreographed by our Modern/Contemporary teacher Seda Aybay.

Seda has received Best Choreographer Award at YAGP for 2 years in a row. (2016 for FACETS and 2017 for KINA)

This campaign is our hope to gather enough money to make this happen for our students. All money gathered will go towards instructor's travel expenses, accommodation, rehearsal space, registration fees, transportation and costumes. 

As little as $5 can make a huge difference in our campaign and can help us reach our goal! The more you can donate the better. Please also share this with your friends, coworkers and family members and have a positive impact in the lives of our young dancers!
story_txt:
Youth America Grand Prix (YAGP)
YAGP is the world's biggest competition for young dancers and performing in the New York Finals is an incredible opportunity for our students to be seen by the best of the best in the dance world. Being exposed to directors of the world's most renowned dance companies could open up so many doors for our students and we can only do it with your help!
You can make the difference in the lives of our students by helping them take advantage of this wonderful opportunity they were presented with in reward for their hard work. 
Yuri Grigoriev School of Ballet
Students of the the Advanced 2 program at YGSB competed at Youth America Grand Prix 2017 in Las Vegas this past February. 


KINA (performed by Kamala McDaniels, Grace Trpin, João Ducci, Jackson Knappen, Coco Williams, Clara McNeal, Madeline Kelley, Ariana Kalamaros) received 3rd place in the Ensembles Category and was invited to perform at Finals in New York City in April
Duet HISLER  (performed by Coco Williams and Jackson Knappen) was also invited to the NYC Finals


Both choreographed by our Modern/Contemporary teacher Seda Aybay.
Seda has received Best Choreographer Award at YAGP for 2 years in a row. (2016 for FACETS and 2017 for KINA)
This campaign is our hope to gather enough money to make this happen for our students. All money gathered will go towards instructor's travel expenses, accommodation, rehearsal space, registration fees, transportation and costumes. 
As little as $5 can make a huge difference in our campaign and can help us reach our goal! The more you can donate the better. Please also share this with your friends, coworkers and family members and have a positive impact in the lives of our young dancers!

story:
A message from the Playwright..

Luft Gangster is a play based on the true story of my relative Louis Fowler. Lou was operating as a waist gunner on a B-24 Liberator when his plane was shot down during a bombing mission for Steyr, Austria. What ensued is truly a remarkable story and sure to live with you long after the performance ends. After meeting Lou for the first time in 2009 and learning about his incredible story, I decided I had to do something to share it with a larger audience. I have spent the last eight years crafting this play through readings and workshops, and have finally found the perfect theater for production in New York City. 

With just under 6% of World War II veterans still alive today, our greatest generation will soon be gone. These are the individuals I greatly admire. The brave souls who pulled themselves up by their bootstraps and persevered to overcome the odds. Luft Gangster is my tribute to all those brave souls.

With Utmost Appreciation,

Lowell Byers

****

We feel this story is too important not to be heard. Each passing day we are losing more and more World War II veterans, their stories, and our own history along with them.   

We have a great team on board for this production including the absolute dream director, Austin Pendleton, at the helm. After the brief, but very successful sold out workshop production of Luft Gangster in 2013, we have been eagerly awaiting the day for a longer run. When the generous offer from the Sheen Center arrived to be featured in their theatre season about war, we gladly accepted. We are thrilled to be in collaboration with Cloverleaf Collective, founded by the playwright, Lowell Byers. Now we need your help in whatever way you can offer it. Please help us to share this inspiring story and give Luft Gangster the full scale production it deserves. 

We think this compelling story deserves a beautiful presentation. And of course we need the funding to do it and do it right! We need you, the community - because after all, what is theatre without a supportive community? 

Nylon Fusion Theatre Company, now entering it's 10th Season, in association with Cloverleaf Collective, a brand new company made for up and coming writers, are both tremendously excited to be mounting this terrific play.  We need your help to reach our $19,600.00 goal to fund this project. Here is the breakdown of where your support will go: 

Theatre Rental - we need $9,000 - this is only 50% of the rent. 
Rehearsal Space - An estimated $1,500 of our fundraising we'll use for various spaces to rehearse with a cast of 10 actors.
Costumes Design - $2,000 - There are 15 characters who will be played by 10 actors, so costuming is especially important because the life and verisimilitude of the play will be dictated by the period clothing the actors wear.  
Sets/Props - the budget of $2,400 will cover costs for our set. Although it will be minimal, we require the material and storage, as well as a lot of props - including weaponry. 
Lighting - $1,000 budget - The Sheen Center is a new facility with good lighting, but along with that, we will also need special lighting equipment for rental.  
Insurance - Like most theaters, we are required to have a $2 million insurance policy which will cost us $800. 
Marketing - $2,900 - because without good marketing, our audience will be scarce.  
Note: Reaching our GOAL of  $19,600.00 will only cover one third of our total budget for LUFT GANGSTER.

With your donation, you can get front row/premium tickets, concession drink vouchers, opening night party tickets, autographed material from our playwright, the cast, and the director Austin Pendleton, and even a special thank you from Louis Fowler himself! Two special donors will get a lunch with a beloved friend of the company, John Patrick Shanley. 

Risks & Challenges

With your help, we will be better equipped to meet and overcome whatever obstacles are left between us today and that magic moment when the house lights go down and it all comes together on opening night. If we don't raise the necessary funds, we will try a fundraising event, which will also cost money. There are many companies out there in need and we are one of them. Especially these days when producing Off-Broadway theatre means likely having to put up your own money. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a contribution, we understand. There are many ways to help. You can volunteer, buy a ticket, or simply promote the campaign and the show. We would love your help so please get involved! 

We thank you from the bottom of our hearts for your interest and we look forward to sharing this incredibly moving, visceral production. We hope to see you at the theater starting March 31st! 

 

PRESS from our 2013 limited workshop showcase production..

“Haunting and moving. Byers, Pendleton, and Nylon Fusion have quite a power piece here. One that is sure to move you.” - The Artswire

“Luft Gangster is a well-written, well-executed play.. The script is solidly written, emotional, with both beautiful speeches and sharp episodic scenes, and it comes to life effortlessly under Pendleton’s solid, decisive direction and thoughtful, committed concept.. Luft Gangster is a moving, warm play marked by bravery, camaraderie, and a loving look into the bond formed by good men in impossible circumstances. The show is thrilling, seamless, and real. Go to Luft Gangster and you will laugh, cry, and be impressed by the immaculate product of talented artists coming together under a clear vision.”- Theatre is Easy

“This is a well-written, tough play dealing powerfully with a tough subject. The ensemble acting is exemplary.” - Theatrescene.net

"Honesty, courage and loyalty are virtues valuable both during war and at times of peace. People of every generation sympathize with someone who is trying to survive in difficult conditions. And these are just a few things that make Luft Gangster memorable and exciting to watch." - ReviewFix

 

What our AUDIENCE had to say..

"Watching a recent production of Lowell Byers’ LUFT GANGSTER was an eye opening experience for me. Though the theatre was smallish, it couldn’t constrain the size and depth of the piece, a tribute to both Austin Pendleton’s inspired direction and Mr. Byers’ elegantly woven story. As I watched, I kept thinking that the play should feel “old-fashioned”, but it didn’t... at all. It felt relevant, heartfelt and emotionally intelligent. Well written. Well acted. Well directed. As soon as it was over, it made me want to do something I rarely ever want to do. It made me want to write." Academy Award Winning Screenwriter (Birdman) - Alexander Dinelaris

"One of the most brilliant shows I have ever seen!!! Congrats! - Helene Galek

“Such a powerful, moving script and production. This is a show not to be missed. Congrats to all the actors, director, producer and everyone involved.” - Donna Ross

“Really, REALLY terrific production. Not just a terrific performance, not just a terrific script - everything was very well done. Congrats!” - Cat Parker/Director

“What an incredible show, congrats Lowell, you had us all gripped from the first minute. This is genius work and should be on Broadway. I loved it and so did my friends” - Monica Wolfson

“From the moment the lights dimmed to the deserved standing ovation some two hours later, we were treated to an extraordinary demonstration of all pervasive theatrical talent. Writing, casting, direction, production and acting appeared to have individually demanded the very best of their specialty and then conspired as a team to present an experience that their peers should envy, and one that left this attendee convinced of having been in the right place at the right time in order to witness something very special. ” - Tony Child

"I can already say it was beyond all I could imagine or hoped it could be. EVERY aspect, from story line to dialogue, to the masterful acting, and all points between, engulfed my spirit in ways I didn't expect, and led me off to solitary places of contemplation. And isn't that what we want in a really great story and production? The acting was SOOOO damned good and deep. I will carry to the grave the sight of the 3 buddies shivering of cold and hate. That's a portrait of war, the human cost of war that I will never get out of my mind. That was my 'look away quickly and back' moment." - Jack Miller

story:
The Play

Shatter the past, uncover the future. 

Mirrors by Azure D. Osborne-Lee was a 2018 winner of The Annual Parity Commission and will have a wold premiere run for 22 performances at Next Door @ New York Theatre Workshop February 29 through March 22, 2020.

Our story begins in the fictional town of Etheridge, Mississippi in the summer of 1960 with Bird – a Black, queer woman (and the town pariah) who is mourning the death of her former love, Belle, and attempting to bond with Belle’s 17-year-old daughter, Alma Jean, who is now Bird's ward.

Though it began with an exploration of death rituals, Mirrors has become a work about the importance of love in the face of grief. And while it is funny and spiritual,  it also is an unsparing reminder as to what happens when a larger community deems someone “unacceptable.” Unfair judgments. Isolation. Violence. Discrimination and prejudice at all levels of society are far worse for LGBTQ+ Americans of color. (Still.)

Mirrors is a personal story about death and life in the American South, but it’s also a poignant contribution to the ongoing conversation on social and racial justice, and about the love we find for ourselves and each other when we have the courage to look.

At its heart, Mirrors reminds us of the importance of family and community, and about letting go of the past in order to let in the present (and love).

 

Our Story 

Parity Productions' mission is to elevate the voices of women and trans and gender nonconforming (TGNC) artists in the cultural dialogue of theatre. 

We produce compelling new plays that give voice to individuals who rebel against their marginalized place in society, and support artists’ work with two annual playwriting Commissions, with intense and dedicated play development, and by connecting and promoting artists with our advocacy programming.

With three productions under our belt, Parity is thrilled to be diving into Mirrors by Azure D. Osborne-Lee with a growing creative team, of which at least 80% will identify as women or TGNC artists. The play epitomizes our artistic mission, focusing on the experiences of often-ignored LGBTQ women of color, who refuse to change who they are no matter how forcefully society demands it. 

Mirrors was Azure's very first full-length play, and while it has received numerous staged readings and won multiple awards, Parity is thrilled to be able to give it its world premiere.

 

Why We’re Crowdfunding 

This play is Parity’s most ambitious production yet with a cast and creative team that is double the size of our past two productions, and some very special effects around The Mirror. (You’ll have to come to a performance to find out what happens.) 

Our full budget is $82K+, but we’re raising $10K here to raise money towards stipends for our creative team (playwright, designers, director, choreographer, etc.). 

If we reach our stretch goal of $15K we’ll be able to cover a portion of sets, props, and costumes! 

Theatre (even Off-Off Broadway theatre) is expensive: just one week of theatre rental is over $3K. So, as a small but mighty company, we need all the help we can get. 

As a company that advocates for theatre artists, we make it a priority to pay our artists fairly. Even if we don’t meet our full campaign goal, any money raised will go straight into the pockets of our our artists. 

 

Impact

The ultimate impact of Mirrors—as with all of Parity’s productions—is to increase the visibility of women and TGNC artists both on and off stage, proving that their stories are as popular, impactful, and important as those that already make up a significant portion of the American Theatre lexicon. 

Parity’s work is driven by the knowledge that, statistically, women and TGNC folx are less likely to stay in creative positions due to financial strain, pay inequity, and family responsibility. 

This production is not only about bringing an exquisitely touching script, breathtakingly talented cast, and stunning theatrical design to the stage. It’s also about inclusion. It’s about bringing this story to as many hearts as possible.  

Risks & Challenges

New York theatre is a brutal business.  If we don’t raise our full budget, we will adapt accordingly (because what are theatre makers if not adaptable?), but we have a very clear vision of the magic that can happen with our full budget, and we invite you to help us make it happen.  

Our producers have brought over two dozen plays to New York City over the last twenty years to audience and critical acclaim: the art is easy; the funding is the hard part. 

We have an incredibly talented cast and creative team who are bringing Azure’s brilliant play to Next Door @ New York Theatre Workshop in 2020. Help us share with you the fullest extent of their talents through Mirrors with a donation today.

 

Can’t Donate? You can still help! 

  1. Share the campaign with friends IRL or email it with the link at the top of this page. 
  2. Shout about it on social media with the Facebook and/or Twitter links at the top of the page (Make sure to tag @parityprods in your posts!)
  3. Just want to see the show? Buy tickets to the production opening February 29. 

  4. Not local to NYC? Forward the ticket link to NYC area friends! 

​If there is anything we know about independent theater it is that there is power in numbers.

story:
Short Summary

" When Anna, a troubled modern dancer struggling with the death of her mother, moves into a new basement suite for solace and solitude, she finds herself drawn into a tender relationship with Patrick, the helpful young man living above her. But why is she suffering violent behavior in her sleep? As her night terrors and sleepwalking intensify, both she and Patrick are sent down a spiral of fear and are soon caught in fracturing timelines—from a night spent observed in a sleep clinic to a violent dream-like accident. Anna must sort reality from dream and past from present and future, or she may never wake up. Part romance, part thriller, Any Night is a mind-bending puzzle exploring the thin line between trust and fear and the immeasurable power of the subconscious."

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for some help covering the costs of the royalties of the play (so that the playwrights get paid for their amazing work.) The cost is $430. 

Any and all extra funds will go towards renting the venue, rehearsal space, set, props, lights, etc., which will cost at least $500 more.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't spare any cash, that's okay! It would be extremely helpful if you could share the campaign on social media. Thank you for your support!

story:
Here's Our Story

Three years ago, a chance meeting of three theatre artists in New York spawned a dream.  A director from Italy, an actor from Colombia and an actress from Australia began an epic journey of cross-cultural collaboration. Our idea was to create a theatrical experience exploring the disparity between the rich and poor which would speak to a wide ranging audience. The result, Miss Julia, is a modern re-imagining of August Strindberg's Miss Julie, performed in English and Spanish. Our dream was to eventually perform in the Iberoamericano Festival in Bogotá. That came true in 2014. We have since traveled throughout Colombia, Spain and Italy and are so excited to be premiering in New York at La MaMa Theater.

This new bi-lingual adaptation by SITI Company's J.Ed Araiza brings together 7 artists from 4 different countries! Miss Julia is an international collaboration between renowned Colombian film and television actor Jhon Alex Toro, Australian theatre artist Tina Mitchell and Colombian actress Gina Jaimes. Music by US violinist Helen Yee and percussionist Martin Vejarano. Directed by Italian Stage Director Lorenzo Montanini.

The Project

La MaMa presents Miss Julia

June 8-25, First Floor Theatre, 74A East 4th St, New York NY 10003

Tickets on sale at www.lamama.org or on 646 430 5374.

Set in Colombia on Midsummer Eve, Miss Julia and her servant Juan have an encounter that will change their lives forever. As Juan tries to rise from the depths of his servile life, Miss Julia wants to escape the bonds that tie her to a meaningless upper-class existence. The result is a power play of love, lust and a battle of the classes which becomes violent and seemingly out of control.

Performed in English and Spanish, Miss Julia is a clash of cultures, a dance of death combining heightened physicality and rich naturalistic text. This unique take on Strindberg's text makes Miss Julia as profound today as it was 100 years ago.

Creative team:

Bilingual adaptation by J. Ed Araiza, based on the play Miss Julie by August Strindberg.                                                                                                                                                          

Created and performed by Jhon Alex Toro, Tina Mitchell and Gina Jaimes.                              

Directed by Lorenzo Montanini.                                                                                                                      

Music by Helen Yee and Martin Vejarano.                                                                                            

Costumes by Aidán Martínez.                                                                                                                      

Lighting design by Mike Ralston.                                                                                                                          

Set and graphic design by Andrew Thurman.                                                                                    

Assistant Director Agustin Scuoteguazza.                                                                                          

Producing assistant Terence MacSweeny.                                                                                              

Publicist Roger Gonzalez.

Co-produced by Vueltas Bravas Producciones and Mitchell Productions Inc.

About La MaMa

La MaMa is dedicated to the artist and all aspects of the theatre. The organization has a worldwide reputation for producing daring performance works that defy form and transcend barriers of ethnic and cultural identity. Founded in 1961 by award-winning theatre pioneer Ellen Stewart, La MaMa has presented more than 5,000 productions by 150,000 artists from more than 70 nations. A recipient of more than 30 Obie Awards and dozens of Drama Desk, Bessie, and Villager Awards, La MaMa has helped launch the careers of countless artists, many of whom have made important contributions to American and international arts milieus.

La MaMa’s 55th season celebrates the creative and collective histories of La MaMa’s local and global communities. Since its beginning, La MaMa has forged creative partnerships with artists based in different parts of the U.S., Europe, Asia, Africa and South America.  In recent years, these long-term relationships have taken on new life through distance collaborations over the Internet.  The 55th season embraces new pathways forged in performance and technology to connect the myriad experiences, politics, conflicts, aesthetics, intimacies and dreams of people and communities participating in an increasingly globalized world.

What We Need & What You Get

To make our dream of performing at La MaMa in New York a reality, we have to raise funds. International plane tickets, set construction and many other production costs. We have a number of exciting perks including unique photographs of our time in New York, personalized behind the scenes DVD's, a sunset sailing cruise on the Hudson river, unique Miss Julia t-shirts and personal concerts in your home. 

The Impact

Our goal is to promote cultural exchange between Colombia, the US, Australia and Italy by presenting a classic piece of drama that is accessible to both Spanish and English speakers and to those who are not regular theatre goers. Our goal is to reach as many diverse audiences as possible and New York marks our 8th season and 6th city to which we have toured. In today's political climate, the themes of class and gender disparity, inherent in the classic text continues to resonate with people from all walks of life and we believe that this important work will have a lasting impact.

Miss Julia was an ambitious undertaking from the outset. Creating high quality independent theatre is hard at the best of times, with international collaboration almost a pipe dream. We have worked tirelessly to make this project come to life and we are all greater artists and human beings as a result. A successful season at La MaMa will put us on the map as a company of artists committed to making high quality work that incorporates cultural exchange and help us leverage further performance opportunities here in the United States and across the world.

Levels of Support

All levels count - whether it's $10, $20, whatever. All contributions support our cause. We hope you’ll join our effort by donating, spreading the word, and coming to see us at the show in June.
story_txt:
Here's Our Story
Three years ago, a chance meeting of three theatre artists in New York spawned a dream.  A director from Italy, an actor from Colombia and an actress from Australia began an epic journey of cross-cultural collaboration. Our idea was to create a theatrical experience exploring the disparity between the rich and poor which would speak to a wide ranging audience. The result, Miss Julia, is a modern re-imagining of August Strindberg's Miss Julie, performed in English and Spanish. Our dream was to eventually perform in the Iberoamericano Festival in Bogotá. That came true in 2014. We have since traveled throughout Colombia, Spain and Italy and are so excited to be premiering in New York at La MaMa Theater.This new bi-lingual adaptation by SITI Company's J.Ed Araiza brings together 7 artists from 4 different countries! Miss Julia is an international collaboration between renowned Colombian film and television actor Jhon Alex Toro, Australian theatre artist Tina Mitchell and Colombian actress Gina Jaimes. story:
SYNOPSIS: Welcome to Independence, Iowa - the lifelong home of Evelyn Briggs, and generations' worth of familial misconnections. Evelyn's oldest daughter, Kess, a university professor, has long since decided to cut her family ties, but has come home at the sudden request of her sister; Jo, an incurable romantic, has become pregnant and is increasingly worried about Evelyn's mental health; while Sherry, salty-tongued and proudly amoral, wants only to finish high school so she can leave home for good. The sisters struggle to meet the expectations of their demanding mother, while the fight to pursue their individual aspirations for life and love test the bounds of family loyalty. INDEPENDENCE, by Lee Blessing, is a powerful, disturbing study of a family divided against itself.

 

About Us

ELIZABETH A. DAVIS* — Director: Elizabeth is a Tony Award & Drama Desk Award Nominee & an Innovative Theatre & NYMF Award Winner.

SUSAN FERRARA* — Evelyn: Susan is an award-winning actor and playwright based in Manhattan. Proud member of AEA, SAG/AFTRA and the Dramatists Guild.

ERICA KNIGHT* (Producer) — Kess: Erica is an actor whose work spans across NYC theatre, film, and tv. She produces this project with Teryn and Paige, marking her producing debut.

TERYN GRAY (Producer) — Jo: Teryn is a New York-based actor, singer, and online content project manager. She produces this project with Erica and Paige, marking her producing debut. BFA graduate of NYU’s Tisch School of the Arts, student of the Matt Farnsworth Vocal Studio.

PAIGE FELGER (Producer) — Sherry: Paige Felger is a NY-based actor who recently graduated with a BFA from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts '17. She produces this project with Erica and Teryn, marking her producing debut.

 

What We Need

In order to bring this production to NYC, we needed to raise a minimum of $3000 to cover playwrights' fees, insurance, and rehearsal space. Now that we've reached that goal, we're need to raise $5,000, to cover our venue fees and technical design fees!

Any donation, no matter how small, will make a difference to the quality of our experience with this piece—and will bring us that much closer to showcasing these female theatre-makers, while sharing important stories about women to New York audiences.

 

What You Get

To show our gratitude, there are a bunch of different cool perks you can choose from!

When you donate to our production, you can get behind-the-scenes videos, a signed playbill, your ad in the program, a collectible prop from the show - or even attend a rehearsal. There's something for everyone - and we'll be forever grateful.

 

The Impact You'll Make

We want to build a creative process that uplifts and showcases women in the industry, and your contribution will help to bring this exciting female-led project to NYC stages. INDEPENDENCE focuses on four unique women, their relationships with each other, and their individual struggles with independence, codependence, and interdependence.

Every dollar raised with this campaign will go directly to the show's expenses; primarily rehearsal and venue fees - and compensating all of our artists and crew members (something we're very passionate about)! Our total budget for this production sits at $11,000, so any dollar you can help us towards that goal would be so greatly appreciated.

 

Challenges

As young female theatre-makers, we face a few challenges in bringing INDEPENDENCE to life:

  • Paying our artists. It has been a commitment of this project from Day 1 that we compensate every artist who is involved with the piece. We have an incredible group of (primarily women) actors, directors, stage managers, technicians, graphic artists, and more! Making sure we keep this commitment comes as a challenge for a low-budget showcase project like this one. You can help!
  • Renting a theater. Finding a venue that suits our productions' needs and meets all Equity requirements costs money. That's the name of the game! Your contribution will help us raise the funds necessary to pay for the perfect theatre to bring this show to life. Our venue costs make up $5,000 of our budget.
  • Rehearsal space. In order to bring this production to its fully-realized potential, we need to rehearse! And for that, we need to rent rehearsal space. While on a slightly smaller scale than the performance venue, this is still such a vital piece to the INDEPENDENCE puzzle.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people can't contribute, and we completely understand, but there are other ways you can still help us!

  • Share this campaign! Share with the people you know! Share with the ones you don't! Just share! The more people we can reach, the closer INDEPENDENCE  is to becoming a reality. This one can make a huge difference!
  • Follow INDEPENDENCE! You can follow the show on Twitter, Facebook, and Instagram for updates and more.
  • Come see the show! If all else fails - we'll need an audience. We'd love to share with you this very special play. Ticketing info soon to come.

Thanks so much!

-

* These Actors are appearing courtesy of Actor's Equity Association

-

Artwork by Amanda Gay - @amandabeararts

story:
Hello!

"Fool For Love" is a SUNY Purchase student run production, that showcases what our Theatre and Performance seniors have learned throughout their program. We have been in production since September 2017, and we are constantly looking for ways to learn throughout our process. Our cast and crew are as follows (* = Senior Project Students):

  • Director - Catherine Pelkey*
  • Stage Manager - Casey Stabiner*
  • Assistant Stage Manager - Al Duncan
  • Fight Choreographer - Brian Bowyer
  • Lighting Designer - Caroline Jannace
  • Technical Director - Alex Theisen
     
  • May - Alexandria Watts*
  • Eddie - Sean Church
  • Old Man - Soren Correia 
  • Martin - Jack Boggan

The Budget.

Our goal is to reach $2500:

  • $1000 for set, props, and building equipment
  • $600 for costumes
  • $400 for the rights (we cannot put on this performance without the rights)
  • $500 for artist compensation, printing, and other additional costs

If our entire goal isn't obtained, we will purchase the rights of the play, and adopt a more minimalist set/props/costume concept. This will still allow us to perform, while challenging us to create a different vision with what we are given. 

Perks!

There are different kinds of perks that you can get depending on how much you donate to our production; you can look over on the side of this page to see the details of those perks. Besides the perks that we can provide you, but all donations are written off as a tax deduction on your taxes! Not only can we give you perks, but our government does as well!

The Ask:

The Theatre and Performance program at SUNY Purchase provides $0 to their senior project performances, requiring the students to strategize methods to raise the money themselves. We are asking you to donate whatever you can to our project. Even a donation as small as $5 can make a huge difference in our production and performance. However if you can't donate, you can always share this page on Facebook, Twitter, or Email; or, you can follow our Instagram or Facebook !

Thank You!

Thank you so much for taking the time to learn about our project. We hope you can support us and can see our show March 1-3 in the Underground Theatre at SUNY Purchase.
